form.definition: noun C or c is the third letter of the English alphabet.
noun In music, C is the first note in the scale of C major.
noun A cab is a taxi. If you miss the last ferry, catch a cab home.
noun A cabbage is a vegetable with a short stem and a large round centre. It has crinkly leaves that are tightly folded over each other. It is used in salads, especially to make coleslaw.
noun A cabin is a small hut, usually built of wood.
noun A cabin is also a small room on a ship where passengers or crew members sleep.
noun A cabin is also the part at the front of a plane where the pilots and navigator or flight engineer sit.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is cockpit.

form.definition: noun A cabinet is a wooden cupboard used for storing things such as glasses, china and ornaments.
The cabinet is a group of senior government ministers who meet regularly to decide government policy. The Prime Minister and Cabinet met for four hours today.
noun A cable is a very strong, thick rope made of metal or fibre thread. The cable snapped and the crate plunged to the ground.
noun A cable is a bundle of electrical wires insulated from each other.
3 cable car A cable car is a small passenger cabin which hangs from cables fixed above. The cables can pull it up a mountain or across a valley.
noun A cackle is a loud, harsh laugh, like the noise a hen makes after laying an egg.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb cackle The hens were cackling in the yard.

form.definition: noun A cadet is a young person who is being trained for a particular job. My brother's a naval cadet. The company takes on half ~a dozen management cadets each year.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cadet Rasha's a cadet journalist with a large city newspaper.noun cadetship All our cadetships for next year are filled.

form.definition: verb If someone cadges something such as food or money from you, they get you to give it to them. Often it is supposed to be a loan, but they don't intend to repay it. I'm not going to lend you any more moneyyou still owe me the $20 you cadged off me last week.
noun If a pregnant woman has a caesarean section, she has an operation in which her abdomen and uterus are cut open and the baby is taken out.
noun A cafe is a small restaurant where you can buy light meals and drinks.
noun A cafeteria is an inexpensive restaurant or snack bar. Usually it is self-service. Large companies, factories and department stores often have a cafeteria for their employees or customers.

dictionary.entry: cagekEIdZ noun A cage is a box made of wire or metal bars where birds and animals are sometimes kept. ... WORD FAMILYverb cage ...to cage a wild animal.adjective caged ...caged animals.

cagey`kEIdZi:cagiercagiest adjective If someone is cagey, they are unwilling to talk about a particular subject and they act as if they are keeping something secret. She's been so cagey about her exams that I'm beginning to wonder if she failed. ... WORD FAMILYadverb cagily noun caginess

form.definition: noun A cake is a sweet food made by mixing flour, butter, milk, sugar and flavouring together and baking them in an oven. Would you like a slice of cake? He brought a plate of small cakes. ...a birthday cake.
noun A cake of something is a small block or bar of it. We need a new cake of soap in the shower.

3 have your cake and eat it too If you want to have your ~cake and eat it too, you can't decide between two alternatives because you'll have to lose something. You want to have them both. I know you want to travel and you also like having money in the bank, but you can't have your cake and eat it too.
4 piece of cake In informal language, if you say that something is a piece of cake, you mean that it is very easy. Louise thought the maths test was a piece of cake.
5 sell like hot cakes If you say that something is selling like hot cakes, you mean that it is very popular and people are buying a lot of it.
noun Calamari is squid prepared as a dish for eating.
noun A calamity is a serious misfortune. The flood came as a calamity to farmers who were just recovering from the bushfire. Don't worryit won't be a calamity if you're a bit late.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective calamitous

form.definition: noun Calcium is an element. It is found in limestone, chalk, marble and some foods. People need calcium from foods such as milk and nuts to form healthy bones and teeth.
verb If you calculate something, you work it out by using numbers. He mentally calculated the cost of the meal.

verb If you calculate something, you work out the effects or results that a decision or action will have. Have you calculated the impact on the rest of your family if you take this job overseas? I'd calculated without Jenny wanting to come too. I decided to take a calculated risk.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See calculating. noun See calculator. noun calculation By my calculations, we should have enough money to pay for the fence.

form.definition: adjective A calculating person is someone who arranges situations so that they get what they want. She's so selfish and calculating.
noun A calculator is a small electronic machine that you use for doing mathematical problems, such as adding and subtracting numbers.

noun A calendar is a chart that shows the year divided up into months, weeks ~and days. I made a note of her birthday on my calendar. Let me just look at the calendaris the 13th a Tuesday? ...a desk calendar. ...a wall calendar.
noun A calf is a young cow, especially a young male cow. (A young .
noun Your calf is the fleshy part at the back of your leg below the knee.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: verb If you call someone something, you give them a name. We called our son David. Her new book's called 'Back to the Fifties'.

verb If you call someone something, you use a particular name for them. Her name's Susan, but her friends call her Sue. I hate it when he calls me 'honey'. c verb If you call someone something such as a liar, a cheat, or a fool, you describe them as that. Are you calling me a liar? He's been called the greatest composer of the twentieth century.
verb If you call a message to someone, you shout it. Usually you are trying to attract their attention. 'Mum', he called, when he got home from school. Jean called for help but nobody heard her.

verb If you call someone on the telephone, you ring them. Call me when you get there. Who's calling, please? Just a moment, I'll put you through. Joseph calledcould you ring him back? Your son wants you to call home.

noun A call is a communication that you receive or make on the telephone. Were there any calls for me while I was out? Is there a phone I can use to make a local call? Give me a call any time you're in town. I'm expecting an important call.

verb If you call someone, you send for them or ask them to come to see you for a particular purpose. She's pretty sickwe'd better call the doctor. The washing machine broke down so I had to call the repair service.
noun A call is a request to go somewhere for a particular purpose. Firefighters receive many calls that turn out to be false alarms.

verb If someone calls or calls in, or if they call on you or call in on you, they come to visit you casually, usually only for a short time. Mary says she called, but we were out. Let's call at Pippa's while we're nearby. Call round any time you're passing. I often used to call in on Sandy to see how he was going.

verb If you call something such as a meeting or an election, ~you arrange that it will take place. The Prime Minister has called an election for next month. They've called a special conference to discuss the proposal.

call back If you call someone back, you ring them again or you ring them in answer to their call to you. Please ask Mr Smith to call me back. It's a very bad linelet me call you back. He called back to cancel the meeting.
8 call for (a) If you call for someone, you go to their house to pick them up, so that you can go somewhere together. What time's Ivan calling for us?
(b) If you call for something, you collect it. Room service will call for the laundry later.

(c) If you call for something, you request it strongly and publicly. The negotiators called for a ceasefire. Various groups are calling for increased government spending. (d) If an event or process calls for something, that thing is needed or appropriate as a response. The project calls for additional staff. This calls for a celebration!
9 call off If you call something off, you cancel it. She called off her engagement three weeks before the wedding. The protest meeting has been called off due to lack of support.
10 call on If you call on someone to do something, you strongly and publicly ask them to do it. The Opposition called on the Government to make tougher laws against lighting fires in the bush.

11 call out (a) If you call out to someone, you shout to them. She called out to her children to come indoors. As the paramedics moved him, he called out in pain. (b) If you call something out, you say it loudly or shout it. The judge called out the names of the prize winners.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun caller There's a caller for you on line two.

form.definition: noun A callgirl is a female prostitute who arranges her appointments by telephone.

adjective If someone is callous, they think only of themselves and show no concern for others. They are selfish, insensitive and sometimes cruel. She was quite callous about leaving her sick friend behind.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun callousness

form.definition: adjective If someone is calm, they remain quiet and steady, and don't get excited or upset about things that happen to them. She was ~perfectly calm when she heard the news. He's a pretty calm sort of person. Keep calm, there's no need to panic. I tried to keep my voice calm.

verb If you calm someone, you do or say something to quieten them or to make them feel less worried. He gently calmed the nervous foal. The latest guarantees have calmed the workers' unrest. These tablets will calm you and help you to sleep.
adjective When water in a sea or a lake is calm, it is very still. There are no big waves because there is little wind. We can't surf today, it's too calm.
noun Calm is a period of quietness when there is no loud noise such as the sounds of wind, rain or traffic. After the storm there was perfect calm.
5 calm down If you calm down or if someone calms you down, you begin to feel less excited or upset. Calm down and tell me what happened.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun calmly Workers evacuated the building calmly. He calmly announced he was leaving.

form.definition: noun A calorie is a unit of measurement which shows the energy value that a food will give you. I'm on a diet of 2000 calories a day.
form.note: ... NOTEThe unit of measurement in the metric system is the kilojoule.

form.definition: verb Came is the past tense of the verb come.
noun You use a camera to take photographs or to make films or videos. Bring your camera so we can take some pictures of the family.

noun Camouflage is a disguise that makes you merge into the background, and which make it hard for an enemy to see you. Many insects use some form of camouflage to make it hard for birds to see them. The army uniforms have green and brown markings to provide camouflage in the bush.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb camouflage The soldiers camouflaged their camp and equipment.

form.definition: verb If you camp somewhere, you live there for a short time in a tent or caravan. We camped on the banks of the Macquarie River. The kids love to go camping in the summer.
noun A camp is a group of tents or huts that have been ~built to house people for a particular purpose. The army camp was 10 km from the town.
noun A camp is also a program of activities for a group of people who stay at a camp. The kids are going on a school camp next week. They learn basic skills at a 10-week training camp.
adjective In informal language, if you say that someone is camp, you mean that they are effeminate or flamboyant in their dress and manner.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective camping ...camping equipment.

form.definition: noun A campaign during a war is a series of planned attacks by a country's armed forces against another country. It is carried out in a particular area for a particular purpose.

noun A political or business campaign is a set of planned actions intended to get a particular result. The Prime Minister launched his election campaign at a press club lunch. ...an advertising campaign.

verb If you campaign for something or against something, you work to get a particular result, especially in public opinion or government policy. We're campaigning to get more drought relief for the farmers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun campaigner

form.definition: noun The campus of a university or college is the buildings and grounds where the teaching takes place. There aren't many students on campus during the vacation. The university has three campuses.
noun A can is a tin which contains something such as food, drink or paint. We took a dozen cans of beer to the party. I opened a can of baked beans.
verb If something such as food or drink has been canned, it has been put into a metal container and sealed. Do you like canned peaches?

verb When can is used with another verb, it means that it is possible for someone to do something or for something to happen. Can you reach the top shelf? I can get it for you cheaply. Joan said she can't come tomorrow. I'll make a hole so the water can drain away.
verb When can is used with another verb, it means that someone knows how to do something. Can you play the piano? I can't speak French as well as I used to.
verb When can is used with a verb of ~belief or opinion, it shows what you think. I can understand your point of view. I can't believe John would act like that.

verb When can is used with a verb of perception, it shows what is being perceived. I can see the others in the distance. Can you hear anything? I can feel a dull ache in my foot. You can smell the sewage from here.
verb Can is also used to show what sometimes happens. Pythons can grow to a length of ten metres. It can get pretty cold in July.
verb Can is also used instead of may to mean that someone is allowed to do something. You can cross the street nowthe light is green. Can I have the day off on Friday, please?
verb You also use can in requests, to ask someone to do something. Can you pass the salt, please. Can you please be quiet.
form.note: ... NOTEthat can in senses 2-7 is called a modal verb. It has a past tense form could.

form.definition: noun A canal is an artificial water route constructed for boats or ships to travel along, or to bring water to or take it away from a particular area. Her grandfather came to Australia on a ship which passed through the Suez Canal. Canals were dug to help irrigate the farms.
verb If you cancel an event, you stop it from happening although it's already been arranged. I called the dentist to cancel my appointment. We'll have to cancel the picnic if it rains really hard.
verb If you cancel something such as a cheque or a contract, you make it invalid. I lost my cheque book so I asked the bank to cancel all the cheques. They cancelled the contract by mutual agreement.
verb If you cancel something such as a ticket or a voucher, you mark it so it can't be used again. Put your ticket in this machine to cancel it.
verb If you cancel something such as a name on a list, you cross it out by drawing a line through it.

5 cancel out If something cancels something out, the two things are equal but opposite, so that together they add up to zero. You've just paid for the drinks, so that cancels out the cab fare you owe me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cancellation I have a cancellation at 2 o'clock. Would you like an appointment then?

form.definition: noun Cancer is a serious illness caused by the rapid growth of abnormal cells in someone's body. They form tumours and tend to spread from one part of the body to another. She's got cancer. The surgeon removed a huge cancer from his intestine.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cancerous Sometimes moles can turn cancerous.

form.definition: adjective If someone is candid, they speak to you sincerely without trying to hide anything. He was quite candid about the situation and told me there was very little chance of promotion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See candour.

form.definition: noun A candidate is someone who applies for a job. They interviewed about twenty candidates for the position.
noun A candidate is someone who puts themselves forward for election. The Labor candidate has a strong lead in the opinion polls. There are eight candidates for the five places on the committee.
noun A candidate is someone who is doing an examination. Candidates are not allowed to take books into the exam room.[qr

dictionary.entry:
candle`kAndl
noun A candle is a stick of wax with a piece of string (called a wick) running through the middle of it. When you light the wick, the candle burns for a long time. I keep a box of candles in case there's a power failure. The table was decorated with flowers and a tall green candle. 2 burn the candle at both ends If you say you burn the candle at both ends, you mean you get up early and go to bed late, so that you don't get enough sleep.
3 can't hold a candle to If you say someone or something can't hold a candle to someone or something else, you mean they are much worse. There is no comparison between the two. Jim's a good mechanic, but he can't hold a candle to Bob.

form.definition: noun Candour is being open and sincere, and not trying to hide anything. I appreciate your candour, although what you say comes as a bit of a shock.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is candor. ... WORD FAMILYadjective See candid.

form.definition: noun Cane is the thin stems of the sugar cane plant or of the plant called bamboo. It is often used for making furniture.
noun A cane is a wooden stick that you can lean on to help with walking, if your legs don't work properly because of injury or age. He leant heavily on his cane.

noun A cane is also a flexible strip of wood that is used to hit someone as a punishment. He was sentenced to half a dozen lashes of the cane. b verb If you cane someone, you hit them with a cane as a punishment.
noun Cane toads are a type of large poisonous toad. They were introduced into Queensland to control insects, but now they are a widespread pest themselves.
adjective Canine is a formal word that means 'having to do with dogs'.
noun Cannabis is a drug made from the hemp or marijuana plant, which is illegal in many countries, including Australia.
noun A cannon is a large gun on wheels which fires heavy ammunition.
2 cannon into If you cannon into someone, you bump into them with force. She hurtled around the corner and cannoned into her boss.
contraction of can not.
form.note: ... ANOTHER FORMof this contraction is can't.

form.definition: noun A canoe is a small light boat that you move through the water by using paddles.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb canoe We canoed down the river. I'm going canoeing this autumn.

form.definition: noun A canopy is a cover which is put over a place or a large object as a decoration or to provide protection from the weather. The honeymoon suite contains a four-poster bed with a huge canopy. There's a canvas canopy over the front door.
contraction of cannot. It is used most often in spoken language.
noun A canteen is a cafeteria in a factory, office or school where employees or students can buy and eat food.
verb When a horse canters, it runs fairly fast, but not as fast as when it gallops. We cantered across the paddock.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun canter We set off at a canter.

form.definition: noun Canvas is a strong cloth used for things such as tents, blinds, and awnings.
noun A canvas is a piece of cloth that has been stretched over a frame so that an artist can paint on it. Her studio was cluttered with unfinished canvases.
noun A canyon is a deep valley with steep sides. The Grand Canyon in Colorado is famous all over the world.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is gorge or ravine.[qr

dictionary.entry:
capkApcapscappedcapping
noun A cap is a soft flat hat which has a brim at the front.
noun A cap is also a lid for a bottle, tube or pen. It prevents the contents from drying up. Put the cap back on the sauce bottle, please.
verb If you cap something such as a story or an achievement, you improve on what you or someone else has previously said or done. She capped his joke with an even funnier one.
cap in hand If you go to someone cap in hand, you go very humbly to ask someone to do something for you. He came to me cap in hand and asked me for a loan of $1000.

form.definition: adjective If someone is capable, they show ability or skill at a particular thing, or they have the ability to do most things well. I wouldn't hesitate to put her in chargeshe's very capable. We need a capable manager to run the project. He's a capable administrator, but not very inspired.

adjective If someone is capable of doing something, they have it in them to do it. They do it sometimes, or it's possible that they may do it. He's capable of doing the wildest things when he's had a few drinks. He's a stern man, but capable of great generosity. I still can't believe her capable of such cruelty.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun capability (capabilities) I only want a chance to show my real capabilities.

form.definition: noun The capacity of something is the amount it can contain. The crate has a capacity of ten cubic metres. The new stadium has a capacity of 50 000. What's the engine capacity of your car? The hall ~was filled to capacitypeople were standing.
noun The capacity of something is the amount it can produce or deal with. The printer has a maximum capacity of fifty sheets per minute. We need new equipment to increase our production capacity.

noun Someone's capacity for something is the amount of it that they can deal with. I'm constantly amazed at his capacity for beeranyone else would be dead drunk by now. She has great capacity for hard work.
noun If you have the capacity to do something, you have the ability or power to do it. He has the capacity to do well, but he doesn't try. She has great capacity for success.

noun If you do something in a certain capacity, you do it in that role. In my capacity as chairman, I should like to welcome you all. I'm not here in my official capacity, but just on a private visit.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective capacity The final was played in front of a capacity crowd.

form.definition: noun A cape is a loose outer garment that has no sleeves and is fastened at the neck and hangs from the shoulders.
noun A cape is also a large piece of land jutting out into the sea. Cape York is the most northerly part of Australia.

noun The capital of a country or state is its main city or town, where the government is. Canberra is the national capital of Australia. The state capitals are Adelaide (SA), Brisbane (Qld), Darwin (NT), Hobart (Tas), Melbourne (Vic), Perth (WA) and Sydney (NSW).

noun A capital or a capital letter is a letter which in English is used at the start of a sentence or as the first letter of a name. Capital letters are written larger than other letters and many of them have slightly different forms. The names of the months have capital letters in English, but not in many other European languages.

noun Capital is a sum of money which you use in business to make a profit. He raised $200 000 as capital to start up the company. b noun A company's capital is its value. She runs a company whose capital exceeds $3 000 000. BHP has a market capital of over $31 000 000.

noun Capital can also be a sum of money you invest for interest in a bank or building society or for dividends in the stock market. He can live comfortably on the interest, without touching the capital. ~ 4a adjective Capital punishment is the death penalty.
adjective A capital crime is one which, because it is very serious, may be punished by death. Drug trafficking is a capital crime in some countries.
5 capital gain Capital gain is the profit that you make when something that you own increases in value. The Government introduced a tax on capital gains.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See capitalise. noun capitalism

form.definition: verb If you capitalise a letter or a word, you write it or begin it with a capital letter.
verb If you capitalise a business, you provide it with funds.

verb If you capitalise on something, you take advantage of it. The home team made several mistakes, and the visitors capitalised on that to build a good lead. You should capitalise on your language skills by working abroad.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is capitalize.

form.definition: noun Capitalism is the economic and political system by which business and industry are owned privately by people who run them in competition with others to make profits.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with communism. ... WORD FAMILYadjective capitalist Australia is a capitalist country.

form.definition: noun A capsicum is a vegetable often used in salads and sandwiches. It is a type of pepper. We added some red and green capsicum to give the dish flavour and colour.
verb If a boat capsizes, it turns over in the water. Their yacht capsized during the Sydney to Hobart race.
noun A capsule is a pill in which the dose of medicine is held within a case made of gelatine. You can buy aspirin either in capsules or in tablets.
noun A capsule is also the part of a space rocket that the crew are in. It detaches from the rest of the rocket in space and is the only part that returns to earth.

noun The captain of a ship or plane is the person in charge. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, this is your captain speaking. 2a noun In the army a captain is an officer of middle rank, below that of a major.
noun In the navy a captain is an officer of high rank.
~noun The captain of a team is its leader. I'm captain of the netball team at school.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb captain Enrico's going to captain our team this year.

form.definition: noun A caption is the words written underneath a picture or diagram to describe or explain it. The people in the photo are named in the caption.
noun A caption is also the words written at the bottom of a film or television screen so that people with impaired hearing or people who don't understand the language can follow what is going on.

verb If someone or something captivates you, they charm and delight you so much that your whole attention is fixed on them. She captivated the audience with her bright personality and outstanding musical talent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective captivating She has a captivating personality.

form.definition: noun A captive is a prisoner. The kidnappers released their captive on a deserted road.
adjective If you take someone captive, you make them your prisoner. Several of the rebels were taken captive by government forces.
adjective A captive audience is a group of people you can address easily because they are already in a particular place and don't have to come there especially for you.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See captivity.

form.definition: noun Captivity is the state of being a prisoner. What effect did the six years of captivity have on you? The hostages were released from captivity by a commando raid. We were taken into captivity by the bandits.
noun Captivity is also the state of an animal being in a cage or zoo. This is the first time this species has bred in captivity. I hate to see these lovely creatures in captivity.
verb If you capture someone, you take them prisoner. Government forces have captured ten rebel soldiers. I want them captured alive.
verb If you capture an animal, you catch it in the wild and keep it as your possession.
verb If an army captures a town, they take it by force from the enemy. The army took five days to capture the city and casualties were high on both sides.

verb If you capture a special atmosphere ~or moment, you record it on film, in a picture or in words. The artist has really captured the character of the place. Photos never quite capture her special charm. This poem tries to capture the feeling of joy on a spring morning.
verb If you capture data, you convert it into electronic form so that it can be stored and manipulated.
noun A car is a four-wheeled passenger vehicle driven by a motor. There are too many private cars on the roadswe must encourage greater use of public transport. I decided to go by car.

noun A car is one of the separate sections of a train that are joined together behind a locomotive. Cars can be either carriages for passengers or wagons for goods. The next will be a four-car train to Central Station.
noun A carafe is a glass container, usually with a wide body and a narrow neck, used to serve wine or other drinks. A carafe of the house red, please.
noun Caramel is burnt sugar. For dessert I served half oranges topped with caramel.
noun A caramel is a type of sweet made from sugar and butter.
noun Caramel is also a light brown colour. I'm looking for something in beige, or perhaps a sort of caramel.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective caramel ...ice-cream with caramel sauce. ...a caramel leather bag.

form.definition: noun A carat is a unit for measuring the weight of precious stones such as diamonds, rubies and sapphires. It is equal to 0.2 grams.
noun A carat is also a unit for measuring the purity of gold. My earrings are only 9-carat but my necklace is 18-carat. Pure 24-carat gold it too soft to be suitable for jewellery.

noun A caravan is a cabin with beds, a little kitchen, sometimes a living space, and other fixtures. You can live in it, especially when you are on holidays. Caravans can be towed by cars or remain stationary in caravan parks.
noun A carbohydrate is a chemical compound such as sugar and starch. Carbohydrates are found in foods such as potatoes, rice and bread. We need to eat them to provide our bodies with energy.
noun Carbon is a common element. Coal, graphite and diamonds are made ~of it, and all organic compounds contain it.
2 carbon copy (a) A carbon copy of a page of writing is a copy of it that you make using carbon paper. I'll make a carbon copy of my lecture notes for you.

(b) A carbon copy is also something that's exactly the same as something else, or only a little different from it. These new proposals are a carbon copy of what they tried to do three years ago. Rosalie's a carbon copy of her sister.
3 carbon dioxide Carbon dioxide is a colourless gas which forms a major part of the air we breathe. It is used in industry to refrigerate things and to make fizzy drinks.
4 carbon monoxide Carbon monoxide is a colourless poisonous gas. It is contained in car exhaust fumes.

5 carbon paper Carbon paper is paper coated on one side with fine carbon particles. You put it between two sheets of paper with the carbon side down, so that when you write or type on the top sheet the carbon comes off on the bottom sheet to make a copy.
noun A carburettor is the part of an engine where the air and petrol are mixed together to allow combustion to take place in the cylinders.
noun A carcass is the body of a dead animal. A special knife is used to strip the flesh from the carcass.
noun A carcinogen is a substance that causes cancer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective carcinogenic[qr

form.definition: noun A card is a piece of stiff paper or cardboard that you write information on and keep so that you can refer to it in the future. Sarah threw away her report card before her parents could see it. The medical record cards are filed over here. I keep all their addresses on index cards.

noun A card is a small piece of cardboard or plastic with information printed on it. These cards often show your identity, and are used for things such as bank transactions and club memberships. May I see your membership card? I've lost my library card. You have to show your Medicare card. Will you pay cash or charge it to a card? We exchanged business cards.

noun A card is a piece of cardboard folded in two with a picture on the front and a~~message inside. You send cards to people on special occasions. I got ten cards on my birthday. I'll have to post my overseas Christmas cards next week. I sent her a card to thank her for the meal.

A card is also a postcard. I want to buy some cards of the area to send to my friends. 5 Cards or playing cards are a set of 52 small pieces of cardboard labelled with 13 different values (from the ace to the king) and 4 different suits (clubs, diamonds, hearts and spades). You use them to play games such as bridge and poker.

6 on the cards In informal language, if you say that something is on the cards, you mean that it is likely to happen or may happen. After all the rows lately, it's on the cards that he'll resign. 'Do you think it'll rain?' 'It's on the cardslook at those black clouds.'

7 play your cards right If you say you play your cards right, you mean you are very clever in the way you handle a situation, with the result that you gain a benefit or reward. If I play my cards right I might get her to offer me a job!
noun Cardboard is a type of thick, stiff paper. The models were made from pieces of coloured cardboard. You need a special machine to print on cardboard.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cardboard ...a cardboard box.

form.definition: adjective Cardiac is a medical word that means 'relating to the heart'. They discovered, after my heart attack, that I had a blocked cardiac artery.
2 cardiac arrest A cardiac arrest is a medical emergency when someone's heart stops beating.
noun A cardigan is a knitted jacket with buttons down the front. Take a cardigan or a jumper with you in case it gets cold in the evening.
noun A cardinal number is a term used in maths for a number such as one (1), two (2), and three (3). It tells you how many things there are in a given set but not the order in which they appear.
form.note: ... NOTESee ordinal number.

form.definition: verb If you care about something, you are interested in it because you think it is important. We should all care more about the environment. I really care about youI want ~you to be happy. I don't care what you think. 'You'll be late.' 'I don't care if I am.'

noun If you do something with care, you pay thoughtful attention so as to do it as well as possible or so as not to damage something. You need to devote more care to your work. They lifted the wounded man with great care. GLASS: HANDLE WITH CARE

noun Care is looking after someone or something. I left our dogs in the care of a kind neighbour. Gina's expert care soon had him back on his feet. Mothers need reliable care for their children if they are to return to work.

noun In rather formal language, a care is a worry or responsibility. It was wonderful to go on holiday and leave all our cares behind. A lifetime of poverty and care had made her grey before her time.

5 care for (a) If you care for someone, you look after them. I cared for my mother for ten years before she died. It's exhausting caring for three children under five. (b) In rather formal language, if you care for someone or something, you like them. Sam really cares for FrancescaI hope they get married. I've never much cared for ice-cream. Would you care for another biscuit?
6 care of If you address a letter or a parcel to someone care of someone else, you send it to the second person's address. Tasha's away so much I'll send her card care of Nancy.
form.note: ... NOTEThis is often written c/o or c/-: Tasha Geistner, c/o Nancy Harris, 3/29 Bridge Street.7 take care (a) If you take care, you pay thoughtful attention so as to do something as well as possible or so as not to damage something. You need to take more care over your work. Take care not to spill your coffee.

form.definition: (b) If you take care of someone or something, you look after them and see that they don't come to harm. I've got to take care of my little sister this afternoon. If I lend you the book, I want you to promise to take good care of it. Take care of yourselfkeep well!

(c) If you take care of something, you deal with it. Marsha offered to take care of all the arrangements. I've already taken care of the bill. ... WORD FAMILYadjective See careful . adjective See careless.

noun Your career is the job or profession in which you earn your living. A science degree opens the door to many different careers. I had no idea which career to choose. I found out about the qualifications needed for various careers. b Your career is also your professional life. I've done several different jobs in the course of my career. My career's important to me, but so's my family. She's enjoyed a long and successful career in the movies.

verb If someone or something careers somewhere, they move fast and dangerously because they are not under proper control. The car careered down the hill and crashed into a tree. I careered round the corner and almost bumped into Jake. I gave it a little shove, and it went careering across the ice.

adjective If you are careful, you think about what you are doing and try hard not to make a mistake that could cause harm or damage. Be careful with the vaseit's very fragile. Be careful how you drivethe roads are wet. I was careful not to mention the divorce.

adjective If you are careful when you do something, you put a lot of time and effort into it to make sure it's all correct. Sophie's very careful about her homework. He drew up careful lists and tackled each job in turn. She sorted the papers with careful thought.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb carefully They carefully lifted the injured man. I carefully sorted through the rubbish.

dictionary.entry: careless`kE@l@s adjective If someone is careless, they don't pay enough attention to what they're doing. Marc's very careless, he's always losing his umbrella. There are too many careless mistakes in this piece of work. ... WORD FAMILYnoun carelessly I carelessly left my umbrella on the bus.noun carelessness It's sheer carelessnessyou know you could do better if you tried.

form.definition: verb If you caress a person or an animal, you stroke them lovingly.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun caress

form.definition: noun A caretaker is a person who is responsible for security and maintenance in a building such as a school, a block of ~flats or a set of offices. If I'm not there, get the caretaker to let you in.
noun Cargo is goods transported by plane or ship. The ship was carrying a live cargo of sheep.

noun A caricature is a drawing or description of someone that exaggerates their appearance or personality in order to make fun of it. Did you see the caricature of the Prime Minister in the paper? Her letters are full of caricatures of the people she's met. He's really good at drawing caricatures.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb caricature He caricatures famous faces. Her ideas have been caricatured as fantasy.

form.definition: noun Carnage is a situation where many people have been violently killed. TV news showed the carnage of the bomb blast in awful detail. Stop the carnage on our roadsdrive carefully this holiday.
noun A carnival is a festival with public celebrations. It usually marks a special occasion.

noun A carnival is also a sporting event when many different races or competitions are held on the same day. Joe's running in the relay at the athletics carnival. Are you going to the swimming carnival on Sunday?
noun A carol is a song or hymn that is about Christmas. On Christmas Eve, we all gathered around the piano and sang carols.
noun A car park is an area, usually outdoors, where people can park their cars.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this is carpark.

form.definition: noun A carpenter is someone whose job it is to make and repair wooden objects, particularly ones that are part of a house, such as window frames and doors.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with joiner. ... WORD FAMILYnoun carpentry

form.definition: noun A carpet is a floor covering made from tufts of fibre attached to a cloth backing. The house has fitted carpets throughout. There's a beautiful oriental carpet in the centre of the room. 2 carpet sweeper A carpet sweeper is a mechanical device with wheels which you push across the floor to pick up dust and bits of fluff from the carpet.~ ... COMPAREthis with vacuum cleaner. ... WORD FAMILYverb carpet The house is fully carpeted. It'll cost $1000 to carpet the room.
noun A carriage is one of the separate sections of a train in which passengers can sit.
noun A carriage is also an elegant old-fashioned vehicle pulled by horses. The bride came to the wedding in a horse-drawn carriage.

verb When you carry something, you take it with you from one place to another in your hands or attached to your body. Could you carry this chair over there? George is the tall one carrying a briefcase. She was carrying a bag in each hand, with another over her shoulder. Carry me, daddy, I'm tired!
verb When a vehicle carries people or cargo, they travel inside it and it takes them to their destination. This bus can carry sixty passengers. The train carried us swiftly through the night.
verb When something such as a river or wind carries something somewhere, it takes it along with it as it moves. The current carried us out to sea.
verb If a sound carries, it can be heard a long way away. The sound of the explosion carried for miles around.

3 carried away If you get carried away by something, you get so excited about it that you forget about practical matters. Before we get too carried away, let's look at how much it's going to cost. He got completely carried away and elaborated the story in great detail. 4 carry off In informal language, if you say you carry something off, you mean you succeed in doing it. I wasn't sure if we could win tonight, but we carried it off!

5 carry on (a) In informal language, if you say someone carries on about something, you mean they make a fuss about it. Don't take any notice of himhe's always carrying on about his problems. Don't carry on sowe'll soon sort it out.

(b) If you carry on doing something, you continue to do it. Carry ondon't mind me. He was devastated by his wife's death, but somehow he carried on. I want to carry on with my studies next year. The car carried on down the road.

6 carry out If you carry something out, you do it as you should. We need someone to carry out basic repairs and maintenance. Why have you not carried out my instructions?~ ... WORD FAMILYnoun carrier The carrier has arrived to pick up the furniture. ...a disease carrier.
noun A cart is a simple wooden vehicle pulled by horses.

verb In informal language, if you say you cart something somewhere, you mean you carry or transport it. By using this word you imply that it is difficult or inconvenient. Do you always cart so many books around with you? I seem to spend half my life carting the kids to friends and parties.
noun Cartilage is a firm elastic substance inside your body, particularly in the joints. I can't play football for a while because I've torn the cartilage in my knee.

noun A carton is a cardboard box used for storing and delivering packaged goods. We bought several cartons of beer for the party. I got some old cartons from the supermarket to pack up my possessions.
noun A carton is also a container made of cardboard that contains food or drink. I bought two cartons of milk. He packed a carton of orange juice. We've used a whole carton of eggs.

noun A cartoon is a funny or satirical drawing or strip of drawings in a newspaper or magazine. Did you see the cartoon about the Prime Minister in yesterday's paper? I like to read the cartoons on Sundays.
noun A cartoon is also an animated film.
noun A cartridge is a piece of ammunition for a rifle or machine gun. It is a small case containing both the bullet and the explosive powder.
noun A cartridge is a disposable container full of ink that you fit in some fountain pens and computer printers. When it is empty you throw it away and fit a new one.
noun A cartridge is also a light plastic case which can contain a camera film or a video tape.

verb If you carve something, you cut pieces away from a block of stone or wood to make a particular shape or design. Daria carves wooden animals as a hobby. He carved the rock into the shape of a bear. Rick carved his initials on the desk.

verb If you carve a piece of meat, you cut slices from it. It takes a bit of practice to carve a leg of lamb.~ ... WORD FAMILYnoun carving ...Aboriginal rock carvings.adjective carving ...a carving knife. ...a carving fork. ...a carving dish.
noun A case is a fairly large container or box. I bought a case of oranges at the fruit market today. A case of wine contains twelve bottles.
noun A case is also a suitcase. I've packed my case and I'm ready to go. How many cases will you be taking?

noun A case is a particular situation used as an example of others of the same type. This is a classic case of failure to do proper market research. If you ask me, it's a case of Ronan being jealous of Tom.

noun A case is a situation that someone such as a doctor or a social worker has to deal with. There have been a number of cases of typhoid recently. Rachel was one of my most rewarding cases. The lecturer presented a case to the class and asked them what they would do.
noun A case is also a criminal trial or a civil law action. The defendant lost the case but will lodge an appeal. When will the case come to trial?

noun The case for or against a proposal is the reasoning and argument that you use to support or oppose it. We've stated our case and await the minister's decision. He made a good case for increased spending.

noun The case of a noun or pronoun is the grammatical function it has in a particular sentence. This may be shown by a special form. In English, some pronouns have subject and object forms, and nouns have possessive forms.

verb If someone cases a place, they check it out carefully before committing a robbery or other crime there. The police said that the thieves had obviously cased the building as they went straight to the most valuable items and got away through a side exit.
6 in any case (a) In any case means 'besides'. You use it to give an additional reason for something. I don't want to go, and in any case I haven't got anything to wear.
(b) In any case also means 'at least'. You use it to show that if one thing is in doubt, then something else is certain. I'll probably come in June, or in any case before the end of July.

7 in case (a) You use in case to explain that you do something because of something that may happen. You want to be prepared if it does happen. I'll bring the car keys in case we want to go for a drive. Pack some ointment in case of insect bites. I'll ~take a sweater just in caseit may turn cooler. b In case also means 'for fear that'. You use it to explain that you act in a certain way to avoid bad consequences that may happen if you don't. I was nervous about using the computer in case I broke it. I didn't mention the party in case she hadn't been invited. I thought I'd better tell you in case you hadn't heard.
noun Cash is money in notes and coins. I've got my cheque book and credit card, but no cash.
verb If you cash a cheque, you exchange it for its value in cash. He cashes his pay cheque every Friday.
3 cash register A cash register is a machine which adds up the value of things people buy in a shop. It stores and keeps a record of the money paid by customers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See cashier.

form.definition: noun A cashier is someone who is responsible for taking money and giving change, for example in a restaurant or shop. Pay at the cashier's desk, please.
noun A casino is a place where gambling games are played.
noun A cask is a large barrel in which alcoholic drinks such as wine and brandy are stored.
noun A cask is also a cardboard container, usually with a capacity of between two and four litres, in which wine is sold. We'd better get a couple of casks for the party.
noun A casserole is a deep dish with a lid that is used for cooking food in an oven.
noun A casserole is also a mixture of food that is cooked for a long time in an oven. For dinner we had a chicken casserole.[qr
noun A cassette is a flat rectangular sealed case containing an audio or video tape.
2 cassette recorder A cassette recorder is a machine for recording and playing audio tapes.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is cassette player, especially if the machine only plays back tapes and can not record them.

form.definition: noun The cast of a play or film is all the people who act in it. After the first night there was a party ~for the cast. The film has a very distinguished cast. b verb If you are cast as a particular character in a play or film, you are chosen to act in that role. I was cast as Horatio in the school production of Hamlet.

verb If you cast something, you throw it or direct it somewhere. I cast my line into the water, but there was no sign of any fish. The moon cast a silver light over the trees. The pole cast a long shadow.
verb If you cast a vote, you vote in an election. She wouldn't reveal how she intended to cast her vote.
verb If you cast an object, you make it by pouring hot metal into a specially shaped mould and leaving it there until it sets hard. This statue was cast in bronze in the sixteenth century.

noun A cast or plaster cast is bandages and plaster wrapped around a broken limb and left to set hard. The cast prevents the bone from moving and allows it to mend. Josh broke his arm and had to wear a cast for six weeks.
noun Some societies are divided into castes or social groups, and have strict rules about what members of each caste can do and how they can live.
noun A castle is a large, strong, stone building that was used as a home by royal and noble families in past times.
noun A castor is a small wheel that can be attached to the legs of heavy pieces of furniture, such as tables, armchairs and beds, to make them easier to move.
verb When a male animal is castrated, its testicles are removed or crushed so that it becomes infertile.

adjective Something casual is informal and relaxed. We spent a casual evening with our neighbours. In casual speech contractions are used. Australian society is generally pretty casual. He's rather too casual about punctuality. b adjective Casual clothes are what you wear when you are relaxing. They are not suitable for formal occasions or many work situations. Shorts and a singlet are a bit too casual, but jeans and a T-shirt will be fine.

If you do casual work, you work only when the employer needs you. You may have to work irregular hours, or only a few hours a week. The rates of pay and other benefits are different from permanent rates.~ ... WORD FAMILYnoun casual Effie works as a casual in the bar.adverb casually Her jacket was slung casually over one shoulder. He casually sauntered over.

noun A casualty is someone who has been killed or injured in an accident or a war. The casualties from the bus crash were taken to Dubbo hospital. There has been bitter fighting in the civil war, with high casualties on both sides.
noun Casualty is a hospital department where patients are brought if they have an accident or are suddenly taken ill. Dad's had a heart attackhe's been rushed to casualty.
noun A cat is a small furry animal with whiskers and sharp claws. People keep cats as pets. Some wild species, both large and small, are also referred to as cats.
2 fight like cat and dog If two people fight like cat and dog, they quarrel all the time and dislike each other very much.
3 let the cat out of the bag If you let the cat out of the bag, you reveal a secret, often without meaning to.
If you say it's raining cats and dogs, you mean that it's raining very hard. It's pouring with rain.
noun A catalogue is a list and description of all the books in a library or all the items in a collection. Can you show me how to use the catalogue?

noun A catalogue is also a brochure that describes items for sale from a particular shop or manufacturer. I'd like to buy the ladder shown on the back page of your catalogue. Please send me a copy of your current catalogue.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb catalogue My job is to catalogue all our acquisitions.[xp\start\~Cantonese

form.definition: noun Cantonese is a Chinese language spoken in southern China and Hong Kong.
noun A casuarina is a type of tree or shrub found mostly in Australia.
noun A catapult is a Y-shaped stick with a length of elastic attached to the forks which children use for firing stones at things.
verb If something catapults or is catapulted somewhere, it moves there very suddenly and quickly, as if fired from a catapult.
noun A cataract is a medical condition in which the lens of a person's eye becomes cloudy so that they can't see clearly.
noun When you suffer from catarrh, your nose and throat are inflamed and you have a lot of thick mucus in them.
noun A catastrophe is a disaster. Thousands of lives were lost in the catastrophe. It'll be a catastrophe for Gemma if she doesn't get into university after all her hard work.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective catastrophic/ktstrfk/ The loss of all her computer files was catastrophic.

dictionary.entry:
catchkAtScatchescaughtcatching 1a verb If you catch an animal, you find and capture it. I went fishing, but I didn't catch anything. They set traps to catch rabbits. Once the budgie got out of its cage, it was a real job to catch it again.
verb When the police catch criminals, they arrest them. The police caught the car thieves last night.
verb If you catch a ball or something similar, you take hold of it as it moves through the air. Liam caught the ball expertly. I managed to catch the plate before it hit the ground.
verb If you catch a bus, train or plane, you get on it and travel from one place to another. I usually catch the eight o'clock train to get to the city by nine. I slept in this morning and I only just caught the bus.
verb If you catch someone doing something, you find them doing something that they shouldn't. The teacher caught Tom smoking. I'm sure he's cheating, but I can't catch him at it.
5 verb If you catch a disease, you become infected with it. I seem to have caught a cold. I don't want you to catch my bug.
6 catch on (a) If you catch on to something, you understand it. The teacher had to explain fractions several times before I caught on. She was winking frantically and eventually I caught on to the joke. Suddenly I caught on who he was.
(b) In informal language, if you say something catches on, it becomes popular. Many of the more extreme fashions never really catch on. 7 catch out If you catch someone out, you put them in an awkward situation. I'm sure half her stories are lies, but I've never been able to catch her out. He gets all the sports questions right, but the ~ones about history sometimes catch him out.
8 catch up (a) If you catch up with someone who's ahead of you, you reach them by going faster. I had to run to catch up with the others. I want to stop and buy a paper. You go onI'll catch you up. Rob's in second place, but he's catching up on the leader.
(b) If you catch up in your work, you spend extra time doing it because you did not have enough time to do it properly before. I was out a lot last week, so I must catch up on the cleaning. The bad thing about holidays is having to catch up when you get back. I still haven't caught up with the backlog.
(c) If you catch up with friends, you spend time with them after not seeing them for a while. Let's catch up properlycome around to our place and we'll spend an evening together. I'm dying to catch up on all the latest gossip.
... WORD FAMILY noun catch ...a nice catch.adjective catching She's pretty sick, but it's not catching.

form.definition: noun A category is a class of things that have some characteristic in common. We need to set up a separate category for Australian poetry. I began to sort the replies into various categories.

verb If something caters for someone, it is suitable for them. It provides them with what they need. This course caters for women who have been out of the workforce and who need to update their office skills.
verb If someone caters for a party or a dinner, they provide the food and drink that is needed, usually as a commercial service. She's catering for a big wedding next week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun caterer We decided to hire a caterer for the dinner party.noun catering It was a wonderful party. Who did the catering?

form.definition: noun A cathedral is the main church of a diocese and has a bishop as its minister or priest.
noun Cattle is the general name given to farm animals such as cows and bulls.

noun A caucus is a meeting of members of parliament belonging to the same political party to decide on tactics. This word is particularly associated with the Australian Labor ~Party. There was a meeting of the Labor caucus last night and policy on a variety of issues was discussed.
verb Caught is the past tense and past participle of catch.
noun A cauliflower is a vegetable. The part that is eaten is the white flower-like centre inside the green outer leaves. I bought half a cauliflower. Do you like cauliflower?

verb If something causes something else to happen, it makes it happen. It is the reason why it happens. The train strike caused him to be late for work. The leak in the roof caused extensive water damage. The drug is suspected of causing birth defects.
noun The cause of something is what makes it happen. What is the cause of all this anger? The situation has several causes.

noun A cause is an aim or principle that a group of people support because they believe in it strongly. She committed herself to the cause of political refugees. They collected half a million signatures in support of their cause.

A cause is also a charity to which you give money to help other people. We raise money for various causes, including homeless families and cancer research. I bought a ticket for the ball, as it was for a good cause.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective causal Is there a causal connection between use of the drug and birth defects?adverb causally

form.definition: noun A causeway is a raised road or path across low or wet ground.
adjective A caustic substance can cause chemical burns. Sugar soap is highly caustic.
adjective A caustic remark is very critical or sarcastic. She made a few caustic comments about her predecessor.
3 caustic soda Caustic soda is a chemical used in making soap and other cleaning products.
verb When a doctor cauterises a wart or a small growth, they burn it with heat or a chemical in order to destroy the tissue.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is cauterize.

form.definition: adjective If you are cautious, you're careful to avoid danger. In particular you don't act too quickly without assessing a situation properly. I advise you to be cautious about what you tell hershe's not very discreet.

adjective A cautious estimate is one that may be too low, ~but is certainly not exaggerated. At a cautious estimate, I'd say there were 3000 people there. The most cautious forecasts suggest revenue of some $3 000 000.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb cautiously He edged cautiously into the junction. I'm cautiously optimistic about it.

form.definition: noun Cavalry is soldiers on horses. In modern armies they have been replaced by armoured troops.
noun A cave is a large hollow in the side of a cliff or a natural chamber under the ground.
2 cave in (a) If something caves in, it collapses inwards. We just got out before the walls caved in on top of us. The roof caved in under the weight of the snow.
(b) If someone caves in, they give way to pressure that is being put on them to do something. He caved in and told her what she wanted to know.
noun A cavern is a large cave.
noun A cavity is a hollow space.
noun A cavity in a tooth is a hole caused by decay. The dentist told me I had two cavities.
noun A CD is a disc on which information is recorded which is read by laser and played back so that you can hear on sound equipment or see on a screen the information contained on the disc.
form.note: ... NOTEthat this word is the shortened form of compact disc.

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say you cease doing something, you mean you stop doing it. I ceased work at five and went home. At last the firing ceased. The machine ceased functioning. It's two years since I ceased smoking. I've ceased trying to please him.
noun A ceasefire is the order to stop firing guns at the end of a battle.
noun A ceasefire is also a period when guns are silent during a battle.
noun A ceiling is the top of a room. The hall was filled with crates from floor to ceiling. He lay on his bed staring at the ceiling. The house has some fine plaster ceilings.

noun If you put a ceiling on something, you set the maximum level that it can reach. The government ~wants to put a ceiling on wage increases. 3 hit the ceiling In informal language, if you say that someone hits the ceiling, you mean they are very angry about something. They completely lose their temper. When Roger finds out he'll hit the ceiling.

verb If you celebrate someone's birthday or some good news, you do something special and enjoyable, such as going out to dinner or having a party. I got the joblet's celebrate! We celebrated his birthday until 4 a.m.

verb If a country, organisation or business celebrates an event or occasion, they mark it by doing something special. This year we celebrate our fiftieth year in business. The Orthodox churches celebrate Easter on a different date.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun celebration The celebrations lasted into the early hours of the morning.

form.definition: adjective If someone is celebrated, they are famous and popular. Several celebrated authors will be speaking at the conference.
noun A celebrity is someone who is famous in some area of popular culture and appears in the media a lot. Last year he was unknown but now he's a celebrity.
noun Celery is a vegetable with long, pale green stalks. It is often used in salads.
noun Celibacy is not having sexual intercourse. Roman Catholic priests are bound by a vow of celibacy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective celibate

form.definition: noun A cell is a room in which prisoners are kept in a goal.
noun A cell is also the smallest functional unit of a living organism.
noun An electric cell is a device for creating a current, as for example in a battery.
noun A cellar is a room under the ground, often used for storage. Each time the heavy rains come, the cellar floods.
noun A cellar is also a place where wine is stored.
noun Celsius (C) is a metric scale for the measurement of temperature. It takes 0;dgC as the melting point of ice and l00;dgC as the boiling point of water. Put the cake in the oven at 200;dgC.
form.note: ... NOTEIn written language you will probably see a ;dg but in spoken language we say 'degrees'.

form.definition: noun Cement is a mixture of clay and ground limestone which is used in making mortar and concrete. Cement is also used to mean mortar or concrete. The cement's flaking away between the bricks. We surfaced the patio with cement.
noun Cement is also a type of strong glue.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb cement

form.definition: noun A cemetery is a burial ground or graveyard.

noun A censor is an official whose job it is to decide what books, films or news reports are to be made available to the public. The censors banned the movie because there was too much violence in it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun censorship Many people oppose all censorship for adults.

form.definition: verb If you censure someone, you express disapproval, often officially, of something that they have done. Workers who have not followed the rules have been censured by management.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun censure A motion of censure was brought against the government.

form.definition: noun A census is an official survey of the population to gather statistical data for planning. The results of the census will be published soon.
noun A cent is a hundredth of a dollar.
noun A centenary is a one hundredth anniversary. The year 2001 will be the centenary of Federation in Australia.
noun Centigrade is an older word for Celsius.
noun A centimetre is a unit of length in the metric system. It represents one hundredth of a metre.
form.note: ... THE SHORTENED FORMof this word is cm.

form.definition: adjective If something is central, it is at or near the centre of something. The dishes of food were arranged around a central floral display. Our offices are in the central business district of Sydney. I like living hereit's very central.

adjective If something is central to something, it is vitally important to it. It is not possible to do without it. Peter's involvement is ~central to our plans. The question of funding is absolutely central.

noun The centre of something is the middle. It is equally far from each side or corner of a shape or object. There was a vase of flowers in the centre of the table. I like chocolates with soft centres. He hit the very centre of the target. I've got a pain in the centre of my back.
noun The centre of a town or city is the busiest part where there are the most shops or business offices. It takes ages to get through the city centre by car.

noun A centre is a building or complex of buildings where people go for a particular reason. Usually several different services are provided at the same place. Try the 24-hour medical centre down the road. ...a child care centre. ...a shopping centre.

verb If something is centred on something, it is strongly directed towards it. All attention was now centred on the champion, to see if she could defend her title. Our efforts are centred on becoming the market leader.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See central. verb centre The caption should be centred under the picture.

form.definition: noun A century is a period of 100 years. In my opinion, he's the greatest writer this century has produced. ...the twenty-first century. Imagine, she's been alive for nearly a century!
noun In cricket, a century is one hundred runs made by a player batting in the one innings.
adjective Something ceramic is made of baked clay. I put ceramic tiles in my bathroom, but slate in the kitchen. She's a brilliant ceramic artist.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun ceramic ...a fine ceramic of an angel. I did a course in ceramics and glass.

form.definition: noun A cereal is a grain plant, such as rice, wheat or maize. Thousands of hectares are planted with cereals.

noun Cereal is edible grain. Many types of cereal can be ground into flour and they form a central part of the diet. Every year millions of tons of cereal are exported. 3 noun Cereal is also a processed food made from grain. Some people eat it for breakfast, usually with milk. Tommy ate two bowls of cereal this morning.
adjective Cerebral means relating to the brain. He suffered a cerebral haemorrhage.

noun A ceremony is a formal event held to mark a particular occasion. The opening ceremony went off without a hitch. At weddings there is usually a reception after the ceremony. The elaborate funeral ceremonies can last for several days.

2 without ceremony If you do something without ceremony, you do it very casually and abruptly. The new manager retrenched the workforce without ceremony. He announced without ceremony that he wanted a divorce.

adjective If you are certain about something, you are sure about it. I'm certain it's here somewhere. 'It's on the 20th.' 'Are you certain?' She seemed very certain about it. I'm not certain where he is. You need to be certain of your facts.

adjective If something is certain, it will definitely happen. His re-election seems certain now. She's certain to object. It's not certain that he'll be there. 3a adjective You can use certain to refer to something particular without specifying it precisely, because you don't know exactly, or it's not relevant to what you're saying. He only comes into the office on certain days each week. They made certain calculations and came up with the answer.

adjective You can use certain to hint at something particular. You assume that the person you are talking to will know what you mean. A certain person told me. The decision was unpopular in certain quarters. She gets very cranky at a certain time of the month.

4 for certain If you know something for certain, you have absolutely no doubt about it. I know for certain that's not true. I can't remember for certain, but I think it was Paul. When will you be able to say for certain?

5 make certain (a) If you make certain of something, you check it again to be absolutely sure. Let me just make certain of the timeyes, it's at two. Before you cross the road, make certain there's nothing coming.

(b) If you make certain that something happens, you take action to ensure that it does happen. He won't be late. I'll make certain of that. I'll put him on the bus myself. We must make certain that there's no delay.~ ... WORD FAMILYadverb See certainly. noun certainty (certainties) He'll be therethat's a certainty. I can state that with absolute certainty.
adverb You use certainly to emphasise that something is definitely true. He's certainly got a great future.

adverb You use certainly to admit that something is true, although there are also other things to be considered. She's certainly clever, but she lacks common sense. Certainly it's possible, but it'll be very expensive. You can certainly stay with me, but you'll have to sleep on the floor.
adverb You use certainly to agree to a request. 'Could you open the door for me?' 'Certainly.' 'May I leave this here?' 'Certainly.'
noun A certificate is an official document that confirms a certain fact. Did you remember to bring your birth certificate? ...a certificate of citizenship.
noun A certificate is also an official document you receive if you successfully complete a course of study or training. The students were presented with their certificates at a graduation ceremony.

noun A certificate is also a qualification you have if you've successfully completed certain courses of study or training. I completed the certificate, and went on to take the diploma. I hold a certificate in applied computer studies.

verb If you certify something, you declare officially that it is true. I asked my neighbour to certify the facts in my passport application. This is to certify that Sue Cook was employed at Acme Pty Ltd between 1985 and 1995.
verb If a psychiatrist certifies a patient, they officially declare that the patient is legally insane.
noun The cervix is the entrance or neck of the uterus.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY ...cervical cancer. ...a cervical smear.

form.definition: abbreviation for Commonwealth Employment Service, which is a government organisation that helps unemployed people to find jobs.
verb If something such as a piece of clothing chafes your skin, it rubs against it repeatedly so that your skin becomes sore. The handcuffs had chafed his wrists.
verb If you chafe ~at something such as a restriction or a delay, you are annoyed and impatient about it. You cannot accept it calmly. He chafed at the injustice of the decision.

noun A chain is a set of metal or plastic rings that are linked together to form one continuous length. She has a lovely gold chain which she wears round her neck. The dog was snarling and straining at its chain. The back gate is fastened with a chain and padlock.

verb If you chain something, you secure it with a chain. They chain their dog to the fence when they go out. I don't like to see monkeys chained up. The kidnap victim was found chained in a cellar. I chained my bicycle outside.
noun A chain of shops or hotels is a set of businesses with the same name and brand image and a central organisation behind them. She works for one of the leading supermarket chains.

3 chain reaction A chain reaction occurs when a series of related events happens, with each one being caused by the one before it. The panic set off a chain reaction in the crowd, and several people were badly trampled.
noun A chainsaw is a powered saw for cutting up wood. The cutting edge consists of a circular chain fitted with teeth and driven round by a motor.
noun A chair is a piece of furniture you sit on. It has a seat, legs, a back for support, and sometimes also arms.
verb If you chair a meeting or debate, you are in charge of it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See chairperson.

form.definition: noun Chairman is another word for chairperson, and is used especially when the person is male.
noun A chairperson is a person who is in charge of a meeting or debate, or is the main official of a society or committee.
noun Chalk is a soft white rock, a type of limestone.
noun A chalk is a small stick of chalk, sometimes coloured, that is used for writing or drawing on a blackboard.
3 chalk and cheese If you say that two things are like chalk and cheese, you mean that they are totally different.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective chalky The soil is very chalky. Her dress was a chalky blue.

form.definition: verb If you challenge someone, you invite them to compete against you in a test of skill or strength. She challenged me to a game of tennis. He challenged his opponent to a public debate. I challenge you to name the last five Australian prime ministers.
noun A challenge is an invitation to compete. I accepted her challenge to a game of tennis.
verb If something challenges you, you need your full interest and effort to deal with it. The advanced exercises challenge even the best students.

noun A challenge presents you with new and difficult problems to solve. My new job is a real challenge. An aging population is one of the challenges we face in the next decade. It's a tough assignment, but I enjoy a challenge.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun challenger The champion easily defeated the challenger.adjective challenging We seek an energetic manager to take on this challenging role.

form.definition: noun Chambers are rooms used by barristers and judges for their work. 2 chamber of commerce or chamber of trade A chamber of commerce or chamber of trade is an association of business people who work together to improve business in their town or city.
noun A chamois is a piece of soft leather, used as a cleaning and polishing cloth.

noun A champion is the winner of a competition or sporting event, especially one that consists of several rounds or stages. Last year's champion is in danger of losing in the first game. The defending champion has built up a commanding lead.
verb If you champion a cause or principle, you support and defend it. Despite the threat of jail, he championed free speech and democracy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective champion He's bred several champion bulls.noun championship There's still fierce contention for the swimming championship.

form.definition: noun Chance is luck or fortune, not the result of planning. I first met him by chance at a party. It was pure chance that she happened to be there.
verb If you chance to do something, you do it for no planned reason. I chanced to look up just as he was passing. If you should chance to pass the post office, could you get me some stamps?

noun A chance is an oppor~tunity. Now's your chance to really impress them. It was the chance of a lifetime. Please don't dismiss megive me another chance. You have three chances to guess the correct number.
noun A chance is a risk. I took a big chance in changing jobs, but it's worked out very well. He may not like it, but I'll just have to take that chance.

noun A chance is a possibility. It's not very likely, but there's still a chance. I clung to the remote chance of success. Is there any chance you could help me? Do you know where he is, by any chance?
6 chance it If you chance it, you take a risk. This may not work, but I'll chance it. Jane's really chancing it, being late for work so often.

7 stand a chance If you say that someone doesn't stand a chance, you mean that they have no possibility of success. We beat England, but against China we don't stand a chance. The whole house burnt down in secondsthey never stood a chance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective chance That chance meeting led to a close friendship.

form.definition: verb If something changes, it becomes different in some way. He's changed latelyhe's much nicer. The grub changes into a butterfly. Things are changing for the better. Nothing had changed between us.
verb If you change something, you make it different in some way. You alter it. You've changed your hairI like it like that. I changed the letter to make it more personal. I've had to change my plans.
noun A change is an alteration. Have you noticed the change in him lately? I've made a few changes to the letter. He had a change of heart. There's been a change of plan.
verb If you change something, you replace it with something else. I decided to change jobs. I changed seats with Ros. Where can I change my currency? We've had to change the date of the meeting.

verb If you change or get changed, you take off what you are wearing and put on different clothes. You'd better get changed quickly. I changed into a red dress. Do change out of those wet clothes. Are you going to change for the party?
noun Your change is the money you get back from a shop when the amount you give is greater than the price of the goods. PLEASE CHECK YOUR CHANGE BEFORE LEAVING.
noun Change or small ~change is money in coins, and sometimes also notes of low value.
verb If you change a banknote, you give someone notes or coins of smaller value to make up the same total value. I got the bank to change the $100 bills for me.

noun A change is something that is different from normal, and usually pleasant. I need a changelet's go camping next weekend. We're having fish tonight for a change. It made a change to study in the open air. The new job has been a big change for me.
6 change hands If something changes hands, it is transferred from one owner to another. This house has changed hands three times in one year. It was a straight swapno money changed hands.

7 change your mind If you change your mind about something, you think differently about it. You change your opinions or your plans. We've changed our mind about selling the car. You can't rely on Yurihe's always changing his mind.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective changeable The weather's been very changeable lately. He can be quite changeable.

form.definition: noun A channel is a passage for water to flow through.
noun A channel is a stretch of deep water able to be used by ships.

noun A channel is also a route for transmitting information or getting things done, for example in a large organisation. You'll have to submit your request through the usual channels or else they won't deal with it.
verb If you channel something somewhere, you guide it in a certain direction. We channelled the water into the drain. I've channelled my savings into real estate.
noun A channel is a frequency band for radio or television transmissions.
noun A channel is a TV station. I saw a good film on Channel 9 last night. What's your favourite channel? I always switch channels when the advertisements come on.
verb When you chant words, you say or sing them in a monotonous way. The crowd chanted 'C'mon Aussie, c'mon'. The worshippers chanted a prayer.
