form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun chant The air was filled with drums and chants.

form.definition: noun Chaos is complete disorder. When the alarm rang there was chaosnobody knew what to do. TRAFFIC CHAOS AS TUNNEL BLOCKED It's been chaos during the renovations. How can you find anything in this chaos?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective chaotic She leads a chaotic life. The painting is a chaotic riot of colour.

form.definition: noun Chap is an informal word for a man or boy. He's a nice chapalways happy to oblige.
noun A chapel is a small church or a special part of a large church building. They were married in the college chapel.
adjective If the skin on part of your body is chapped, it is rough, cracked and sore. I use a cream to stop my lips getting chapped in the cold wind.
noun A chapter is a fairly long section of a book, covering a particular topic or episode. Each chapter has a number and sometimes a title as well.

noun In fairly formal language, a chapter is a period of time in history or in someone's life. This is the start of a new chapter in Australia's history. Let's make the past a closed chapter, and start again as friends.
3 chapter and verse If you give someone chapter and verse, you tell them all the details of a happening or event. I don't want to hear chapter and versejust the broad outline will do.

noun The character of someone or something is their personality or nature. It is the combination of all the qualities that make them what they are. I don't really understand his character. The two sisters are very different in character. These changes threaten the whole character of our society.
noun A character in a novel, play or film is a person in the story. The main character is a retired librarian. Who is your favourite character in literature?
noun You can call a very interesting, unusual person a character. Old Liu is a real character, isn't he?
noun If a place is interesting or has something special about it, you can say it has character. I love Hobartthe historical buildings give it so much character.
noun If you say that a person is of good character, you mean that they possess high moral standards. My employer is prepared to ~say something about my good character in a reference.
noun A character is a letter or symbol used in writing and printing. The English alphabet has 26 characters. There is only room for 80 characters in the title field.

7 in character If you say that someone is behaving in character, you mean that they are behaving as you would expect. I'm not surprisedher rudeness is quite in character. He refused to come, but that's in character for him.

8 out of character If you say that someone is behaving out of character, you mean that they are not behaving as you would expect. It was quite out of character for Mina to come to the pub with us. Trent's been a bit out of character latelyI hope there's nothing wrong.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See characteristic. adjective See characteristic.

form.definition: noun Acharacteristic is a quality or special feature of something that marks it as being different. One characteristic of our college is the friendly staff. Dark hair and blue eyes are family characteristics. 2 adjective If something is characteristic of someone or something, it is typical and distinctive. I'd know his characteristic walk anywhere.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb characterise (<or> characterize) His attitude to the job is characterised by that selfish remark.adverb characteristically He was characteristically rude. Bats characteristically come out at night.

form.definition: noun A charade is a silly pretence which nobody believes. Why don't you stop this charade and admit the truth?
2 charades Charades is a game where one person has to act out a word or name, and the others have to guess what it is. We often play charades when the whole family gets together at Christmas.
noun Charcoal is partly burnt wood which can be used as a fuel. Sticks of charcoal are also used by artists to draw pictures with.

verb If you charge someone a certain amount of money, you make them pay that amount for a certain item or service. I'm not going back to that shopthey charge too much. How much do you charge for delivery?

noun A charge is the price you have to pay for something. ~ Postal charges will rise on 1 October. I pay a fortune in bank charges. What's this charge for? We will replace the item without charge. The repair will be free of charge.
verb If you have something charged to your account or to your credit card, its cost is added to the total that you will have to pay on that account later. Charge it to my account, please.
verb If the police charge someone with a crime, they formally accuse them of doing it. He was arrested and charged with assault.
noun A charge is a formal accusation of a criminal offence. He was arrested on a charge of assault.
verb If you charge somewhere, you rush there, often in an attack. The soldiers charged into the enemy camp. The bull lowered its head and charged. They all went charging off to the beach.
verb If you charge a battery, you pass an electric current through it to build up a store of electricity. My car battery needs charging.
noun An electric charge is an amount of stored electricity. This device lets you check the charge left in your batteries.
in charge If you are in charge of someone or something, you are responsible for them. I want to see the person in charge. Who's in charge of this child? I'm in charge of new product development.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun charger Leave the battery in the charger overnightthat should do it.

form.definition: noun If you have charisma, you have great popular appeal. He's a competent manager, but he lacks the charisma to inspire the employees.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective charismatic

form.definition: noun A charity is an organisation which raises money for people in need or for a socially desirable cause. He contributes to several charities.
noun Charity is giving help or money to people in need. They were forced to rely on the charity of their neighbours. He was too proud to accept charity. She gave away a lot of her money to charity.
noun Charity is kindness and understanding towards other people. Their attitude to the mentally ill lacks charity. You might try to show a bit more charity they are your parents, after all!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective charitable ...a charitable donation. ...a charitable attitude.

form.definition: noun Charm is an attractive and pleasing quality. I was won over by her charm and kindness. He has loads of charm, but don't trust him. The village has a quiet charm. One of the charms of working at home is not having to dress up.

verb If you charm someone, you delight them with your personality or behaviour. She was charmed by his old-world manners. I managed to charm the security guard into letting me through. 2 noun A charm is a small ornament worn on a chain. On each birthday she received a new charm to add to her bracelet.
3 charmed life If you say that someone leads a charmed life, you mean that they are always very lucky and get out of dangerous situations without harm.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun charmer The youngest child is a real charmer. He's a charmer, but don't trust him.adjective charming She's a charming little girl. They live in a charming cottage.

form.definition: noun A chart is a map, especially one used for navigating at sea or one that shows information about the weather.
verb If you chart an area of land or sea, you survey it and draw a map of it. Captain Cook charted the east coast of Australia. Some parts of the interior have still not been properly charted.
verb If you chart a route or a course, you work out where to go by looking at a map.
noun A chart is a table or graph that displays information. At the front of the book there's a chart of the basic food groups. The profits for each year are displayed on this chart.
3 the charts The charts are the weekly lists of the best selling recordings of popular music. One day we'll be number one in the charts! After all these years, they still regularly top the charts.
noun A charter is a legal document which gives rights and responsibilities to various people or groups.
verb If you charter a plane or a boat, you hire it to transport you somewhere.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective charter ...a charter flight.

form.definition: verb If you chase someone, you run after them in order to catch them. The guards chased the escaped prisoner.
verb In informal language, if you say you're chasing something, you mean you are trying to find or obtain it. I'm chasing that brand of car wash that's been ~advertiseddo you sell it?

3 chase away or chase off If you chase a person or animal away or off, you run after them and try to make them go away. I've chased the dog awayit's safe to come out now. She chased the intruders off her property.

chase up In informal language, if you say you chase someone or something up, you mean you try to make progress with a matter that hasn't been settled. He hasn't got back to me - I'll have to chase him up. The boss is chasing up that report that was supposed to be in yesterday.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun chase ...a long chase after the prisoner.

form.definition: noun The chassis of a vehicle is its metal framework. It supports the engine and other parts.

dictionary.entry:
chattSAtchatschattedchatting 1 verb If you chat, you speak with someone in a friendly way, usually about things which are not very important. I'd love to stay and chat but I must go now. We all sat around chatting. You can
2 chat up If you chat someone up, you talk to them and try to make them like you. Look at him over there chatting up that pretty girl. You have to chat up the customers and find out what they really want.
... WORD FAMILYnoun chat We had a pleasant chat. I haven't got time for idle chat.adjective chatty (chattier, chattiest) Send me a nice chatty letter. I'm not feeling very chatty today.

form.definition: verb If people chatter, they talk quickly and continuously about unimportant things. Children, stop chattering and pay attention. At first he was shy, but soon he was chattering away with the others.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun chatter I could hardly hear the music above all the chatter.

form.definition: noun A chauffeur is a person who is employed as someone's driver.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb chauffeur I'm always chauffeuring my children to parties.

dictionary.entry: chauvinism`S@Uv@nIz@m noun Chauvinism is a strong and unreasonable belief that your own country, race or sex is superior to others. ... WORD FAMILYnoun chauvinist. adjective chauvinistic

cheaptSi:pcheapercheapest 1 adjective If something is cheap, it doesn't cost very much. Apples are cheap at the moment. This jumper is cheapit's on special. I can get it for you cheap. I know a really good cheap dressmaker.
adjective Something cheap may be of poor quality. Don't buy itit looks a bit cheap to me. On holiday I wear old jeans and cheap T-shirts.
adjective In informal language, if you say that someone is cheap, you mean that they don't like spending money. Dad's so cheaphe didn't even buy Mum a Christmas present.
4 cheap and nasty If something is cheap and nasty, it is of very poor quality, and often in bad taste as well.
... WORD FAMILYadverb cheaply I bought it cheaply at the market.

form.definition: verb If someone cheats, they behave dishonestly. Ranier cheated in the examhe copied from my paper.

verb If someone cheats you, they take something from you in a dishonest, unfair way, usually by tricking you. She cheated meI worked for two weeks and she won't pay me. He was cheated out of his money.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cheat He's a cheathis answers are all copied from someone else.

form.definition: verb If you check something, you make sure that it is correct or in order. You can check your answers in the back of the book. Did you check the tyre pressures? The baby's fineI just checked. Let me check you're doing it right. Check how many are left.

noun A check is an examination to make sure that everything is in order. FREE SAFETY CHECK ON YOUR TYRES AND BRAKES I made one last check that I'd locked up properly. The fault was discovered during a routine check.
verb In rather formal language, if you say that you check something, you mean you control it and prevent it from getting worse. These drugs will check the spread of the disease.
noun A check is a pattern consisting of squares of different colours. I chose a suit in a red and black check.
4 check in If you check in to a hotel or airport, you arrive there and register. All passengers must check in two hours before their flight is due to depart.

5 check up on If you check up on someone, you find out as much information ~as you can about them, often secretly. Who is this Johnson? We'd better check up on him. Have you been checking up on me? Don't you trust me?
6 in check If you keep something in check, you manage to control it and prevent it from getting worse. They held the virus in check.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective checked ...a checked tablecloth. ...a checked skirt.

form.definition: noun A checkout is the place in a supermarket where you pay for the things that you have chosen. I really hate having to queue up at the checkout.
noun A check-up is an examination by a doctor or dentist. I'm going to the doctor for my annual check-up.
noun Your cheeks are the two soft parts of your face next to your nose. She kissed him on both cheeks.
noun Cheek is rudeness or insolence. If someone gives cheek, they do not show respect. Ari was always giving cheek to his teacher so she sent him out of the class.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cheeky (cheekier, cheekiest) Don't be so cheeky!

form.definition: verb If you cheer, you shout out in order to show your approval or to encourage someone. On sports day, I cheered and cheered for our team. The whole audience cheered when the band appeared on stage. The returning heroes were cheered by a huge crowd.
noun A cheer is a loud shout of approval or encouragement. A huge cheer went up as he crossed the finishing line. Three cheers for the organising committee! The announcement was greeted with cheers.

2 cheers People say cheers to each other when they are about to have an alcoholic drink together. Usually they also raise their glasses to each other, and often each person touches the others' glasses with their own.

3 cheer up If you cheer up or if something cheers you up, you stop feeling depressed. Cheer up! It's not all that bad! Salim's really homesick. What can we do to cheer him up? Seeing you has really cheered me up. She cheered up a bit at the prospect of food.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cheery (cheerier, cheeriest) Rosanna gave me a cheery wave as she passed.

form.definition: adjective Someone who is cheerful shows by their behaviour that they are happy. We need someone with a cheerful disposition for the reception desk.

adjective Something that is cheerful is pleasant and makes you feel happy. Leaving aside our funding problems let's turn to the more cheerful subject of the staff Christmas party. Some cheerful curtains would really improve the atmosphere of this room.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb cheerfully We smiled cheerfully for the cameras.noun cheerfulness

form.definition: noun Cheese is a solid food made from milk. There are very many different types of cheese.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cheesy The dip had a strong cheesy flavour.

form.definition: noun A chef is a cook in a restaurant or hotel.
adjective Chemical processes are those which have to do with chemistry. Chlorine gas is released as the result of a chemical reaction. I'm studying chemical engineering.

noun A chemical is a substance that is used in or obtained by a chemical process. You must be careful in handling these powerful chemicals. I don't like to eat processed food that's full of chemicals.

noun A chemist or a chemist's is a shop where you can buy medicines and other things such as toiletries and cosmetics. Another word for this is pharmacy. Is there a chemist near here? If you're going by the chemist, we need some shampoo.
noun A chemist is someone who is qualified to dispense drugs and sell medicines prescribed by a doctor. Another word for this is pharmacist. I need to get the script made up by a chemist.
noun A chemist is someone who is qualified in chemistry, or who does chemical research. My father's an industrial chemist. His research is in the area of non-polluting fuels.

noun Chemistry is the scientific study of substancesthe molecules and atoms they are made up of and the ways in which they react with each other. At TAFE I'm studying maths, English, physics and chemistry.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See chemical. noun See chemical. noun See chemist.

form.definition: noun Chemotherapy is the use of drugs to treat cancer.

noun A cheque is a piece of paper authorising your bank to pay an amount of money from your account to a particular person. Your name and account details are printed on it; you fill in the name of the person to be paid and the amount. Did you pay in cash or by cheque? I'll just write you out a cheque for that amount.
2 cheque account A cheque account is a bank account with funds available to pay cheques. Compare this with savings account.
A chequebook is a set of pre-printed cheques that are bound together. You tear off a cheque from it when you need one. I've left my chequebook at homecan I pay you tomorrow?
verb If you cherish something, it is important and dear to you. She cherished the memory of her happy childhood. Angela really cherishes that scruffy old doll.
noun In European art, a cherub is an angel drawn to look like a plump, naked child with wings.
noun You can call a sweet, innocent-looking child a cherub. And how are you today, my cherub? Their youngest child is an absolute cherub.

noun Chess is a board game for two players. Each starts with sixteen pieces which can be moved only to certain squares on the board according to fixed rules. The aim is to attack and trap your opponent's main piece, called the king.
noun Your chest is the top part of the front of your body, from your neck to your waist, excluding your arms.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: noun A chest is a large strong box used for storing things. All our old toys are in a chest in the attic.

3 get something off your chest If you say you get something off your chest, you mean you talk about something that's been worrying you. Come on, get it off your chestyou'll feel better if you tell us about it.
verb If you chew something, you bite it in your mouth several times to make it easier to swallow. This meat's a bit toughyou really have to chew it.
2 chew over If you chew ~over something, you think about it for a long time, particularly because you are trying to understand it. I chewed over what she had said.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective chewy (chewier, chewiest) I'm afraid the steak's rather chewy. I bought a bag of really chewy caramels.

form.definition: noun Chewing gum is a sweet, chewy substance that you chew until the sweetness has gone. Please don't leave your chewing gum on the furniture!
adjective If something is chic, it is stylish and attractive. That's a very chic hatwhere did you buy it? She always manages to look chic, although she hasn't got much money for clothes.
noun A chick is a baby bird, especially a baby hen or rooster. The mother bird gathers food for her chicks.
noun In informal language, a chick is a girl or woman. Many people find this word offensive.
noun A chicken is a young hen or rooster, or its meat, which you can cook and eat. The chickens were scratching in the back yard. We had chicken for dinner last night.
adjective In informal language, if you call someone chicken, you mean that they're a coward because they won't do something. I know why you won't do itit's because you're chicken.
3 chicken out In informal language, if you say someone chickens out of doing something, you mean they don't do it because they are afraid. I knew he'd chicken out at the last moment.
noun Chickenpox is a disease which causes a rash of itchy red spots. Most people get chickenpox when they're children, and after you've had it once, you usually don't get it again.

noun A chief is the head of an organisation. The local police chief is due to retire soon. She eventually became chief of a large engineering company. The division chiefs were summoned to a special meeting.
noun A chief is also a tribal elder. In Papua New Guinea, the highland chiefs are regarded with great respect.

adjective If something is the chief thing, it is the main or most important one. The chief cause of lung cancer is smoking. Our chief problem is finance. What have been the chief successes of your ~career? Wheat is still Australia's chief export.
noun A child is a person from the time they are born until they become a teenager and then an adult. When I was a child I loved birthday parties.
noun Your children are your sons and daughters. I have three children two sons and one daughter.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See childish. noun childhood Meredith had a happy childhood.

form.definition: adjective If someone is childish, they behave in a silly and immature way. Don't be so childish! She flew into a childish rage.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun childishness

form.definition: verb If you chill something, you cool it. I chilled the wine in the fridge before serving it. 2 verb If something chills you, it frightens you or makes you worried that something bad will happen. The screams chilled us to the bone. I was chilled by the revelations.
noun A chill is a mild sickness. He caught a bad chill and had to go to bed for a day.
noun If you say there is a chill in the air, you mean the weather is a bit cold.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun chill The scream sent a chill down my spine. adjective chilly (chillier, chilliest) Take a coatit's chilly out tonight.

form.definition: noun A chilli is a small red or green pod from a plant belonging to the capsicum family. Chillis are very spicy and are often used in crushed or powdered form as a flavouring in food.
verb When a bell or a clock chimes, it makes a musical ringing sound. I could hear the church bells chiming in the distance. The town hall clock has just chimed eight.
chimes Chimes are a set of metal tubes or bells which make musical ringing sounds when struck or when the wind moves them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun chime I love to hear the chime of church bells.

form.definition: noun A chimney is a pipe or tube which lets the smoke from a fireplace go up through the roof of a building.
noun A chimney is also a structure on the roof of a building out of which smoke and fumes from below are discharged.
noun Your chin is the lowest part of your face, below your mouth.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: keep your chin up If someone tells you to keep your chin up, they are telling you not to be discouraged. Keep your chin upthings will get better soon.
noun China is a type of fine clay used to make things such as cups, plates, bowls, vases and small ornaments.
noun Cups, saucers, plates and bowls can also be called china. Another word for this is crockery. We washed up the china and put it away.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective china ...a china doll. ...a china vase.

form.definition: noun Chinese is the language spoken in China. The standard form of it is called Mandarin; another form is Cantonese.
adjective If someone or something comes from China, you describe them as Chinese.

noun A chip is a small piece of something which has been broken off from a larger piece. Sweep up the chips of wood under the bench. b noun A chip in something is a place where it has been damaged and where a small piece of it has been broken off. This glass has a chip in the rimI wonder how that happened.
noun Potato chips are thin crisp slices of fried potato that you can buy in packets from shops and supermarkets. They are often flavoured, and you eat them as a snack.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor them is potato crisps.b noun Chips or hot chips are long, thin pieces of potato that have been freshly fried. They are usually eaten with a meal. Fast food shops often call them french fries.

form.definition: noun A computer chip is a tiny square of material which contains electronic circuits. The computer problems were caused by a faulty memory chip.

4 a chip off the old block If you say that someone's a chip off the old block, you mean that they are very much like their father or mother, in appearance or especially in character. Jim's a real chip off the old blockhis dad used to love fishing at the same age.

chip in (a) If someone chips in on a conversation, they join in, often without being invited. I was talking to Rosa, but Gail chipped in. He always has to chip in with his own problems. If you've got any questions, feel free to chip in.

(b) If you say that people chip in, you mean that everyone pays some money towards ~the cost of something. We want to get Sandra a presentwould you like to chip in? It'll only be a few dollars each if we all chip in.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb chip (chips, chipped, chipping) I've chipped all the wood ready for the fire. I chipped my tooth when I fell.

form.definition: noun Chipboard is a building material that's made of compressed wood chips or particles. It is sometimes also called particle board.
noun A chiropractor is someone who treats disease by manipulating the bones in people's necks and backs.
verb When a bird chirps, it makes short, high-pitched sounds.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun chirp

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say that someone is chirpy, you mean that they are happy and cheerful. You look very chirpy todayis it your birthday or something?[qr

dictionary.entry:
chisel`tSIz@lchiselschiselledchiselling
1 noun A chisel is a tool with a long, flat metal blade. You use it with a hammer to cut or shape wood or stone.
verb In informal language, if you say that someone chisels you out of something, you mean that they cheat you out of it. I was chiselled out of $500.
... WORD FAMILYnoun chisel He chiselled the stone into the shape of a bear.

form.definition: noun Chlorine is an element. On its own it is a greenish-yellow poisonous gas with a strong smell. It is also contained in compounds that are used to bleach clothes and as a disinfectant, especially in swimming pools.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb chlorinate The water in the pool is very highly chlorinated.

form.definition: noun Chocolate is a sweet food made from the seeds of a South American tree.
noun Chocolate is also a drink made with milk and a powder containing chocolate. I'll have two coffees and a hot chocolate, please.
noun A chocolate is a sweet, especially one covered in an outer layer of chocolate. Chocolates are an acceptable ~gift. ...a box of chocolates. My favourite chocolates are coffee creams.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective chocolate ...a chocolate egg.

form.definition: noun Choice is the act of choosing from a range of things. It's a difficult choice to make. If she wants to leave home, that's her choiceshe's an adult now.
noun A choice is a range of things from which you can choose. We offer a choice of ten different colours and two styles. There's a wide variety of choice.
noun A choice is also something that you choose from a range. Take your choice to the cashier's desk. My choice would be the blue one.

adjective Something choice is of very high quality. This word is used especially in promotional material. Enjoy a choice selection of vintage wines. The pie is filled with choice, juicy steak and sumptuous gravy.
noun A choir is a group of people who sing together. The school choir led the audience in singing 'Advance Australia Fair'.
verb If you choke, you struggle to breathe because you can't get enough air into your lungs. He choked on the fish bone and almost died. They emerged choking and gasping from the smoke-filled room.
verb If something chokes you, it makes it difficult for you to breathe. The smoke from the bushfire was choking me. This collar's too tightit's choking me.
verb If someone chokes you, they throttle or strangle you. He had his hands around my neck, choking me.
verb If something is choked with something, it's blocked so that it's difficult for things to get through. The drains are choked with leaves. The highway was choked with traffic.
noun The choke in a car is a control that reduces the amount of air coming into the carburettor and makes the engine easier to start. I pulled the choke right out. Try giving it a bit of choke.
choke back If you choke back an emotion, you force yourself not to show it. Andrea choked back tears. I tried to choke back my anger.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective choking ...clouds of choking black smoke.

form.definition: noun Cholera is a serious disease which causes diarrhoea and vomiting. It is spread by infected water and poor hygiene and is often ~fatal. You should have cholera injections before you go to India.
noun Cholesterol is a chemical that is found in your body and in foods such as eggs. It is thought that too much cholesterol can cause heart disease by blocking your arteries.
noun In informal language, chook is another word for chicken.

verb If you choose something, you pick out which one you want from a range. He chose a yellow shirt to wear with his grey trousers. I was chosen for the netball team! 'What shall we do tonight?' 'You choose.' Start thinking about choosing a career.
verb If you choose to do something, you decide to do it. I chose to stay on the farm, even though I knew it wouldn't be easy. Sometimes I think she chooses to be miserable.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See choice.

form.definition: verb If you chop something such as wood, you hit into it with quick, strong blows using an axe or other sharp tool. Tony, could you chop some wood for the fire, please? They chopped the tree down. We chopped off the lower branches. His arm was chopped off by the blade.
verb If you chop food, you cut it into smaller pieces. You'd better chop that meat a bit smaller. Add two finely chopped onions.
noun A chop is a thick slice of meat attached to a piece of bone. We had lamb chops, mashed potato and peas for dinner last night.
get the chop In informal language, if you say that someone gets the chop, you mean that they are dismissed or lose their job. Over two hundred workers got the chop when the factory closed down.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun chop She gave one last chop and the tree fell over.

form.definition: adjective If the sea is choppy, it has small, broken waves.
adjective If the wind is choppy, it keeps changing suddenly.
noun Chopsticks are a pair of thin sticks used in Asia for eating food. I always use chopsticks at Chinese restaurants.
noun A chord is several musical notes played together. She gave us the opening chord and we all started to sing.
noun A chore is a routine task that has to be done regularly. For some people, cooking a meal every night is a chore; for others, it's a pleasure. The children have to help with the household chores.
noun Achoreographer is someone who works out the dance steps for ballets and other dances.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun choreography

form.definition: noun A chorus is a large group of people who sing together.
noun A chorus is a part of a song which is repeated after each verse. We all joined in the chorus.
verb When a group of people chorus something, they all say it together. The students chorused 'Good morning, Miss Smith'.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective choral ...a delightful choral presentation.

form.definition: verb Chose is the past tense of choose.
verb Chosen is the past participle of choose.
verb If a minister of the church christens a baby, the baby is given a name during the Christian ceremony of baptism. She was christened Marianne Josephine, but she's always been called Mary Jo.
verb In informal language, if you say you christen a new possession, you mean you use it for the first time. Have you christened the new stereo system yet?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun christening We asked nearly thirty people to the christening.

dictionary.entry: ChristianitykrIsti:`An@ti: noun Christianity is a religion based on the teachings of Jesus Christ. ... WORD FAMILYnoun Christian adjective Christian

form.definition: noun Christmas is a Christian festival commemorating the birth of Jesus Christ, celebrated on December 25th. What are you doing over Christmas?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective Christmas ...Christmas tree. ...Christmas Eve. ...Christmas present.

form.definition: noun Christmas bush is a tree that has small red flowers at Christmas time in Australia and is used for decoration.
noun Chrome is a hard, shiny, silver-coloured metal used to cover metal objects to prevent them from rusting.
adjective If something is chronic, it lasts for a long time and is difficult to get rid of. She suffers from chronic heart disease. There are chronic food shortages in the areas near the fighting.
adjective If things are arranged in chronological order, they are arranged in sequence according to the date when they happened.
adjective If someone is chubby, they are plump. The word is especially used of babies and toddlers. He's getting a bit chubbyhe needs to do some exercise.

verb In informal language, if you say you chuck something somewhere, you mean you throw it, or put it there in a rather careless way. Chuck that cushion over here, will you? I chucked some more garlic into the sauce. Just chuck your cases in the boot and we'll be off.
verb In very informal language, if you say that someone chucks, you mean that they vomit. She chucked all over my car. He looked as if he was about to chuck.
chuck in In informal language, if you say you chuck something in, you mean you give it up. He chucked in his job last week. Don't chuck it all inyou'll do well if you just keep trying.
chuck out verb In informal language, if you say someone chucks you out of somewhere, you mean they force you to leave. We were chucked out of our flat.
verb If you chuckle, you laugh quietly. He just sat there chuckling to himself.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun chuckle He let out a delighted chuckle.

form.definition: verb In informal language, if you say that someone chunders, you mean that they vomit.

noun A chunk of something is a fairly large piece cut off or broken off from a whole. We were eating chunks of fresh bread spread with butter. Cut the meat into chunks. The rent takes a big chunk out of my income. ~ ... WORD FAMILYadjective chunky ...a chunky sculpture.
noun A church is a building in which Christians worship. There's a beautiful old church in the village. We used to go to the same church.
noun Church also refers to the service held in a church. Rada goes to church every Sunday. We see each other at church most weeks.
noun A church is one of the organisations of people who belong to the Christian religion, such as the Anglican Church, the Roman Catholic Church and the Uniting Church.
verb If you churn milk into butter, you stir it until it becomes butter.
noun A churn is a container in which milk is stored or butter or ice-cream is made.

churn out In informal language, if you say someone churns something out, you mean they produce a lot of it, often without much thought or inspiration. She is a very fast knitter and churns out jumper after jumper. He still churns out a novel every year. Answer the questiondon't just churn out everything you know.
churn up If something churns someone up, it upsets them or worries them very much. Gonzalo won't eat dinnerhe's all churned up about the big soccer game tomorrow.
noun A chute is a steep, narrow passage down which you can slide or drop things to a lower level. Put the garbage down this chute.
noun Chutney is a cooked mixture of fruit or vegetables, vinegar and sugar. It is eaten as a cold sauce with some meat and salads.
noun Cider is a drink made from apples. You can buy alcoholic and non-alcoholic cider.
noun A cigar is a roll of dried tobacco leaves which you can smoke.
noun A cigarette is a small tube of paper containing flakes of tobacco, and often a filter, which you can smoke.
noun A cinema is a place where people go to watch films.[qr
noun A circle is a flat, round shape. She wore a red dress with a pattern of blue and black circles. Put the dishes in a circle around the vase. The ship moved ~in a circle.
noun A circle is also a group of people or things arranged in the shape of a circle. The teacher was surrounded by a circle of children.
verb If something circles, it moves in the shape of a circle. The plane had to circle for twenty minutes before landing. The vultures were circling overhead.
verb If something circles something else, it moves around it in the shape of a circle. The earth circles the sun once every year.
verb If you circle something on a piece of paper, you draw a ring around it. I circled the time and place in red ink.
6 noun The circle in a theatre or cinema is an area of seats on an upper floor. Would you like tickets in the circle or the stalls?
go round in circles If you say that someone is going round in circles, you mean that they are lost. When we visited Canberra for the first time, we just went round and round in circles.

run around in circles If you say that someone is running around in circles, you mean that they are very busy but not achieving very much. I've been running around in circles all dayI'm absolutely exhausted. Stop running around in circles and think calmly what you need to do.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective circular There's a circular mark on the back.

form.definition: noun A circuit is a path around which an electric current flows.
noun A circuit is a trip all the way around something. Have you done a circuit of the grounds?
noun A circuit is also a prepared circular track on which races take place.

noun A circuit is a set of places or events that people attend regularly for a particular reason. It's a gruelling slog on the professional tennis circuit. The same old faces keep turning up on the conference circuit.
verb If you circulate something such as a report or journal, you send it from person to person so that everyone can have a look at it. Please circulate this memo in your department.

verb If something circulates, it moves around so that eventually it comes back to where it started from. William Harvey proved that blood circulates in the body. The host should circulate among the guests.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See circulation.

form.definition: noun The circulation of a newspaper or magazine is the number of copies sold each time it is printed.
noun Your circulation is the movement or flow of blood through your body. I have poor circulationmy fingers and toes are always cold and stiff.
verb If a male child is circumcised, the loose skin from the tip of his penis is cut off. It is done either for religious or health reasons.
verb If a female child is circumcised, an operation is performed on her genitals. There is strong support for making this illegal in Australia.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun circumcision

form.definition: noun Thecircumference of something circular is the distance around its edge.

noun Acircumstance is something which has an influence on what happens. I don't want to express an opinion without knowing all the circumstances. There was one unusual circumstance to the case. It was the best we could do in the circumstances.
2circumstances Someone's circumstances are the conditions they're experiencing. His home circumstances make it difficult for him to study. I'm in difficult financial circumstances at the moment.

under no circumstances If you say that something should happen under no circumstances, you are emphasising that it absolutely must not happen. Under no circumstances are you to leave this house until I get back.

noun A circus is a group of performers such as clowns, jugglers and acrobats who put on live shows for large audiences. Some circuses also have trained animals such as elephants and monkeys. She ran away to join a travelling circus.
noun A circus is also the show that these performers put on. Children love to go to the circus.
If any situation becomes rough and noisy or out of control, you can call it a circus. The business meeting degenerated into a circus.
noun A citizen is a person who has a certain nationality.

noun A citizen is a person who lives in a particular country, state or city. As a citizen of Sydney, I am concerned about the pollution of our beaches. ~ ... WORD FAMILYnoun citizenship Luke-Yan and I have just received our Australian citizenship.
adjective Citrus fruits include oranges, lemons, limes and mandarins, which grow on small evergreen trees.
noun A city is a large and important town. Most major cities have traffic problems. In Australia, more than two-thirds of the population live in the coastal cities.

adjective In formal language, civic refers to anything that has to do with your role as a member of society. Voting in elections is a civic responsibility. It's your civic duty to report any vandalism.
civic centre A civic centre is a building or group of buildings belonging to the local council. It often includes a large hall for public use.
adjective If someone is civil, they are formally polite although not very friendly. She's always been perfectly civil to me. I tried to maintain civil relations with the neighbour.
civil war A civil war is an armed conflict between groups within the same nation. The country is on the brink of civil war.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun civility (civilities) We maintained a facade of civility. They exchanged icy civilities.

form.definition: noun A civilian is someone who is not a member of the armed forces.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective civilian He found it hard to adjust to civilian life. ...the new civilian government.

form.definition: noun A civilisation is a society of people which has its own highly developed social organisation, culture and distinctive way of life.
noun Civilisation is also all the different societies in the world. The survival of civilisation depends on world peace. We studied the history of civilisation.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is civilization. ... WORD FAMILYadjective civilised

form.definition: adjective A civilised society has highly developed social organisation and control. Who would believe that such atrocities could occur in a civilised country?

adjective If you say someone is civilised, you mean that they are cultured, polite and controlled in their dealings ~with others. I expect you to behave in a civilised manner when we visitno putting your feet on the chairs.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is civilized.

form.definition: abbreviation for close. You use it when you write an address for someone who lives in a close. ...21 Banksia Cl., Emu Plains.

verb If you claim that something is true, you say that it is, although other people may not believe you. He claims he caught a three-kilo fish last weekend. He claims he's sick, but I have my doubts. An old woman came forward claiming to be his mother.
noun A claim is a statement that something is true. It does not necessarily have any proof to support it. I don't believe her claim to be his sister.

verb If you claim something, you ask for it on the grounds that it legally belongs to you. Any lost property not claimed after six months is auctioned for charity. She claimed a half share in the proceeds.
noun A claim is an assertion of your right to something. His former wife made a claim on the estate.

noun A claim is a demand that someone makes on you. They want you to do something for them. Everyone makes claims on my timethere's nothing left for me. It's not easy to reconcile the conflicting claims of work and family.
noun A clairvoyant is a person who claims to be able to see things beyond the powers of normal people.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clairvoyance

form.definition: noun A clam is a large shellfish with two hinged shells that it can close together very tightly.

2 clam up In informal language, if you say someone clams up, you mean they won't say any more. Perhaps they are nervous, or they are worried about revealing something. After answering the first couple of questions, Vishal just clammed uphe wouldn't say another word.
verb If you clamber somewhere, you climb there with difficulty. He clambered up onto the roof, dragging himself up with his hands.
adjective Something clammy is damp and sticky. Her hands and feet are clammy and she has a temperature.

verb If you clamour for something, you demand it noisily or without stopping. The crowd was clamouring for the pop stars to appear. More and more teachers are clamouring for reform of the education system.
noun If you hear a clamour of voices you hear a lot of people talking and shouting together. We could hear the angry clamour in the street below.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is clamor. ... WORD FAMILYnoun clamour There is a growing clamour for democratic reform.

form.definition: noun A clamp is a device which holds two things tightly together. Leave the clamps in place until the glue is dry.
verb If you clamp two things together, you hold them together with a clamp.
verb If you clamp your teeth together, you press them together very tightly. He clamped his teeth together in anger. 3
clamp down If authorities clamp down on an activity, they take steps to stop it from happening. The boss has been clamping down on long lunches this month.
noun A clan is a group of related families who believe that they share a common ancestor.

noun You can also use clan as in informal word for a group of people who have something in common and who seem to help and support each other all the time. It's difficult to break into that clan because they all went to school together.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective clannish The community's very clannish and it's hard for an outsider to be accepted.

form.definition: adjective If something is clandestine, it is secret, often because it is illegal. He had been making clandestine payments to various individuals.
verb If something clangs, it makes a loud, deep ringing noise. I could hear the bells clanging as I approached.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clang The clang of the fire alarm interrupted our discussion.

form.definition: noun In informal language, a clanger is an embarrassing mistake. She really dropped a clanger when she asked after his wife. What a clanger! I should have kept my mouth shut.
verb When you clap, you make a noise by ~hitting your hands together repeatedly to show your appreciation for a performance. The audience clapped loudly. We all clapped at the end of her speech.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is applaud.

form.definition: verb When you clap your hands, you make a noise by hitting your hands together, often as a signal. Stop when I clap my hands. He clapped his hands three times and they began singing. She clapped her hands in delight.
verb If you clap someone on the back, you give them a friendly hit with your open hand. He clapped me on the back on his way past.
verb In informal language, if you say that someone is clapped in prison, you mean that they are put into prison.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clap Let's give Damian a clap for his hard work. He gave me a clap on the back.noun clapping At last the clapping died down.

form.definition: verb If you clarify something, you explain it in more detail. You make it clear and easy to understand. Could you clarify what you mean by additional funding? Now that that point has been clarified, we can proceed with the meeting.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clarification There are still one or two points that need clarification.

form.definition: noun Clarity is the quality of being clear and easy to understand. She explained the point with great clarity. I'll repeat that once more for the sake of clarity. Your last paragraph lacks clarity.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See clear.

form.definition: verb If objects clash together, they strike each other with force.
verb If you clash with someone, you argue heatedly with them. The Prime Minister and the leader of the Opposition clashed over the issue again in Parliament today.
verb If two colours or patterns clash, they go together badly and create an unpleasant visual effect. Don't you thing the pink carpet will clash with the green wallpaper?
verb If two appointments or events clash, they both happen at the same time so that people can't go to both of them. I couldn't go to the party because it clashed with my exams.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clash

form.definition: verb If you clasp something, you hold it tightly. I clasped the rope and swung myself up. She clasped him to her and wept. The students lined up, clasping their enrolment papers. Clasp this handle and squeeze it.
noun A clasp is a small fastening device that holds things together. The clasp on my necklace is broken. They had to force the clasp on his suitcase. Her hair was gathered back with a clasp.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clasp The glass slipped from my clasp and fell.

form.definition: noun A class is a group of things with similar characteristics. There are three main classes of error. I divided the shells into three broad classes: small, medium and large.

noun A class is also a set of people with a particular status in society because of their family background or level of income and education. He was born into the working class. She married into the upper middle class. Distinctions of class are fairly fluid in Australian society.
noun A class is also a category of something, graded according to its quality. Did you fly first class, business class or economy class? We use only ingredients of the highest class.
noun A class is a group of students who are taught together. We never have more than 18 students in a class. I was moved up to a more advanced class. The whole class went on a field trip.
noun A class is also a course of instruction in a particular subject. I decided to take a class in woodwork. My Vietnamese class is on Friday evenings.

noun A class is also a short period of teaching in a particular subject. For this course, there are three two-hour classes per week. I missed a couple of classes and fell behind. Li waited to talk to the teacher after class. Please don't eat in class.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb class I'd class that as a trivial mistake.verb See classify.

form.definition: adjective If something is a classic example of something, it's typical of it. The patient had a classic case of measles.
adjective If something is classic, it is simple and elegant, without decoration. She was wearing a plain black dress of classic design.
noun A classic is something such as a book or film which is famous and popular for a long time. It doesn't go out of fashion. Robert Louis Stevenson wrote a number of ~adventure classics.
4 classics If you study classics, you study Latin and Ancient Greek.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective classical I prefer classical music to rock.

form.definition: verb If you classify things, you put them into groups or classes which have similar characteristics. This library classifies books according to a decimal system. Would you classify ment Classified advertisements are short advertisements in a newspaper. They are grouped together under headings such as 'articles for sale' and 'positions vacant'.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun classification What classification would you put this under? ...a system of classification.

form.definition: noun A classroom is a room in a school where pupils or students have lessons.
noun If something clatters, it makes a series of short knocking or banging sounds. The stones clattered down the slope. The kids came clattering down the stairs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clatter The familiar office clatter greeted me as I entered.

form.definition: noun In grammar, a clause is a group of words containing at least a subject and a verb.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with phrase.

form.definition: noun A clause in a contract or agreement is a part of it dealing with a particular issue. Usually the clauses are numbered to make it easy to refer to them. There's a clause in the lease that forbids us to keep pets.
noun Claustrophobia is the fear of being shut up in a small place.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective claustrophobic

form.definition: noun An animal's claws are the sharp nails on its feet.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb claw

form.definition: noun Clay is a type of soil which is heavy and sticky when wet. You can use clay to make pots and sculptures by shaping it when it is wet and then baking it at very high temperatures to make it hard.

dictionary.entry:
cleankli:ncleanercleanest 1a adjective If something is clean, it is free from dirt and stains. The house was clean but a bit untidy. I put clean sheets on the bed for the visitors. Is this shirt clean, or is it for the wash? It's hard to get
verb If you clean something, you make it free from dirt and stains. I cleaned the whole house. Have you cleaned your teeth? He cleaned the wound and dressed it. It's important to clean right into the corners. On Saturdays I clean and shop.
adjective If a piece of paper is clean, it has no marks or writing on it. I put a clean sheet of paper in the printer. You should start each section on a clean sheet of paper.
adjective If a game or fight is clean, it's fair. The contestants obey the rules and don't try to cheat. It was a good, clean fight.
adjective If a shape or design is clean, it's smooth and simple. The boat has a good clean line to it. I prefer classic clothes in bold, clean colours.
5 clean up If you clean up, you tidy up any mess and clean anything that's dirty. We need to clean up before my parents come to stay. Cooking is easier if you clean up as you go along. My mother's always nagging me to clean up my room.
6 come clean In informal language, if you say that someone comes clean about something, you mean that they reveal the truth after denying or concealing it before. At last he came clean and we heard the real story.
... WORD FAMILYnoun clean I gave the tiles a clean with a damp cloth.noun cleaner My father's a cleaner at the hospital.noun cleanliness Cleanliness is very important to prevent infection.noun clean-up Community groups got together for the clean-up after the bushfires.noun cleaner ...household cleaners. ...vacuum cleaner.

form.definition: adjective If something is clear, you can understand it easily. Her lectures are always very clear. The book is illustrated with clear diagrams. Let me try again to make myself clear.
adjective If you are clear about something, you understand it. I'm still not clear about fractions. Are you clear what you have to do? I want you to be quite clear that this mustn't happen again.

adjective If something is clear, it's definite and certain, with no doubt about its meaning. His message contained a clear ~promise of support. My instructions on this point were quite clear. They refused to give a clear guarantee not to raise prices.
adjective If writing is clear, it's easy to read. She writes in a clear, bold hand.
adjective If a substance is clear, you can see through it. He poured the liquid into a clear glass bottle. The water is beautifully clear.
adjective A clear day is a bright and sunny day. We woke up to a lovely clear spring day.
verb If the weather clears, it becomes bright and sunny. After a rainy morning, the weather cleared in the afternoon. The weather forecast says it'll clear tomorrow.
adjective If a view or a road is clear, it's not blocked or obstructed. We have a clear view of the Blue Mountains from our balcony.

verb If you clear something, you move things away from it so that it's empty. I cleared the table after the meal. We cleared most of the land to build our new house. You can press this button to clear the memory.
verb If you clear something, you remove it or get rid of it. Can you clear your things off the table, please. We reduced the price to clear the last few jumpers.
verb If you clear something with someone, you get their permission. I'll have to clear your request with the manager.
verb If someone in authority clears something, they give their permission. The office manager has to clear all claims for petty cash.
verb If someone is cleared after an official investigation, they're freed from blame or suspicion. He was cleared of all the charges against him.

verb When a bank clears a cheque that you have made out to someone, they transfer the funds from your account to that of the other person who can then withdraw the money. You can pay an extra fee to have the cheque cleared more quickly than normal. Cheques usually take four or five working days to clear.
verb If you clear something as you are moving, you don't hit it. There's a gap between you and the object. Look out! You only just cleared that parked car.
verb If you clear a certain amount of money, that's the amount you receive after the deduction of tax or expenses. I clear about $500 a week with overtime. I cleared $500 on the deal.
14 clear off If someone tells you to clear off, they want you to go away. There's nothing for you here, clear off!
15 clear out (a) If you clear out of somewhere, you leave, taking all your possessions ~with you. We were forced to clear out when Sam's parents came back.
(b) If you clear something out, you remove rubbish or unwanted items, and tidy what's left. It's time we cleared out the attic.
16 clear up (a) If you clear up a problem or a disagreement, you resolve it so that it doesn't cause difficulties any more. I'm glad we've cleared up that misunderstanding.
(b) If you clear up, you tidy things away. You put everything back in its correct place. We were too tired to clear up after dinner. Clearing up after the floods will take months.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See clarity. adverb clearly This one is clearly superior. Clearly, you can't go back there.noun See clearance.

form.definition: noun If you get clearance to do something, you get official permission. Have you got clearance from the council to put up that fence? The pilot received clearance from the control tower and took off.
noun Clearance of a cheque is when the bank clears it. You can pay extra for special clearancethat way you'll be able to withdraw the money sooner.
noun Clearance is the distance between one object and another that passes underneath or beside it. There was a clearance of only a few millimetres between the vehicles. MAXIMUM CLEARANCE 4 METRES
noun A clearing is a piece of bare ground in the middle of bush or forest. They set up camp in the clearing.
noun A clearway is a stretch of road where cars are not allowed to stop except in an emergency.
verb If you clench your teeth, you press your jaws tightly together. It was a pretty bad injuryyou could see him clenching his teeth in pain.
verb If you clench your fist, you make your hand into a fist very tightly. He clenched his fist in rage.
noun The clergy is all the priests and ministers of the Christian church. He was keen to enter the clergy.
noun A clerk is someone who works in an office and keeps records and accounts.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective clerical

form.definition: adjective If someone is clever, they're intelligent and able to learn things quickly and easily. My brother's the clever one in our family.
adjective If someone is clever at doing something, they're skilled at it. They do it well.

adjective If something is clever, it's sensible and practical. That's a clever idea! It wasn't very clever to wash your jeans without emptying the pockets. They sell a clever device for taking the fluff off jumpers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb cleverly noun cleverness

form.definition: noun A clich;aae is a common expression or saying that has lost a lot of its impact through being used too often.
verb When something clicks, it makes a short, sharp sound. The door clicked shut. Can you click your fingers?
verb In informal language, if you say that two people click when they meet for the first time, you mean that they like each other and get on well together. We clicked right from the start.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun click Did you hear the click of the door?

form.definition: noun A client is someone who uses the services that someone else provides professionally.
noun A cliff is a very steep slope which often leads down to the sea.
noun The climate of a place is the weather conditions that are normal there. Sydney has a mild climate. Don't go and live thereit has a dreadful climate. It never stops raining.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective climatic

form.definition: noun A climax is the most important or most exciting point in a series of events. The climax of the film comes when the hero overcomes his fear, and faces his enemy. Their disagreement reached a climax when Tara took over Simon's project.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective climactic ...the climactic moment.

form.definition: verb If you climb, you move or rise upwards. The plane climbed steadily. I climbed onto the roof. We climbed up the hill. You have to climb a steep staircase. She climbed to the top of her profession through hard work.
verb If ~something climbs, it increases in value or amount. My shares climbed twenty cents on the stock exchange today. House prices have climbed sharply in the past quarter. 3 climb down

(a) If you climb down something steep, you move down it cautiously or with difficulty. We climbed down the gorge. Bev climbed down to rescue the dog trapped on a ledge. (b) In informal language, if you say someone climbs down in an argument or dispute, you mean they make a concession or admit they were wrong. He's climbed down from his original position and is being much more reasonable now.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun climb I was exhausted after the climb. What has caused the climb in interest rates?noun climber A party of climbers was rescued from the summit.

form.definition: verb If you clinch something, you settle it. It was not certain before, and now you make it definite. I clinched that deal todaylet's celebrate! That clinches it! If you can't be polite, I'm leaving.
noun In boxing, a clinch is the position of the two fighters when they hold each other tightly. They had each other in a clinch.
verb If you cling to someone or something, you hold on to them tightly. The baby clung to its mother's back. I clung to the railings, too frightened to move.

verb If someone or something clings to you, they stay with you and won't go away. The smell of the bushfire clung to the house for days. Adam clung to me for the whole weekendI hardly got a chance to talk to anyone else.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective clinging ...a clinging smell. Sophie's hard workshe's so clinging.

form.definition: noun A clinic is a building where people go for medical or dental advice or treatment.
verb If you clip something to something else, you fasten it in place. He clipped his cheque to the application form. You should clip the pages together.
verb If you clip something, you trim it or cut small pieces from it. The man next door was out clipping his garden hedge.
verb If you clip something out of a magazine or the newspaper, you cut it out. He always clips the coupons from magazines. I clipped out an article you might like to see.
verb When a ticket inspector clips your ~ticket on a bus or train, they cut a small piece out of it to show that it's been used.
verb If you clip someone or something, you give them a fairly light knock. His father threatened to clip him round the ear. My car wasn't badly damagedthe truck just clipped the rear bumper.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clip ...a paper clip. ...a hair clip.noun clippers Have you seen my nail clippers? The hairdresser finished off with clippers.noun clipping She has a box full of old newspaper clippings.

form.definition: noun A cloak is a wide, loose coat that's fastened at the neck and doesn't have sleeves.
noun A clock is an instrument that measures time and displays what time it is.

2 around the clock If something happens around the clock, it happens all day and all night, or at least for very long hours. Security guards patrol the factory around the clock. We've been working around the clock to fill that rush order.
adverb If something moves clockwise, it moves round in the same direction as the hands of a clock face, from left to right. Turn the knob clockwise and the door will open.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is anticlockwise.

form.definition: noun Clockwork is the machinery in clocks and some types of mechanical toys that you wind up with a key to make them move.
2 like clockwork If something happens like clockwork, it happens without any problems or anything going wrong. After all my worries, the wedding ran like clockwork.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective clockwork When I was young I had a clockwork monkey.

form.definition: verb If something is clogged or clogged up, it's blocked. There are things in the way so that it's hard to get through. The gutter was completely clogged with leaves. My nose is all clogged up with this cold.
noun Clogs are heavy shoes made of wood.
noun A clone is an organism that comes from a single parent rather than two parents, so that it's exactly the same as the parent it came from rather than a mixture of two parents.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb clone

dictionary.entry:
closekl@Uz for the verb; for the adjective, /\times,0\klos/closerclosest
verb If you close something, you shut it. Close the door, pleaseit's cold in here. Katrina, it's very lateclose that book and go to sleep! The door closed behind her and I was alone again.
verb If you close something such as a meeting, a discussion or a bank account, you end it. The subject is closedI don't wish to discuss it any more. He closed by reminding us how important it was to work together.
verb If a road is closed, it's blocked off so it can't be used. Heavy snow closed the road.
verb If something such as a shop closes, it stops trading or operating, either for a while, often until the next business day, or else permanently. We close at 5 p.m. They're closed for their annual holidays. The airport was closed for two hours due to bad weather. Bad debts forced us to close. Head office closed the factory.
adjective If someone or something is close, they are nearby. The park's very closejust at the bottom of the street. I live close to the local shops. The photographer got us to stand closer together.
adjective If you are close to someone, you are very fond of them and talk to them about intimate things. I've never been very close to my sister. We were close friends for years.
adjective If two things are close, they are similar. There isn't much difference between them. We're very close in age. The paint isn't an exact match for the carpet, but it's close. It was a close finishTess was only a few centimetres ahead.
If you are close to doing something, you are about to do it or you almost do it. Scientists are close to unlocking the mysteries of our genes. I was close to losing my temper.
adjective Your close relatives are the ones nearest to you on your family tree. Your closest relatives are your parents, brothers and sisters, and children; next come your uncles, aunts, nephews, nieces, first cousins, grandparents and grandchildren.
adjective If you take a close look at something, you look at it carefully. The official took a close look at my passport before letting me through. That seems an attractive villagelet's take a closer look.
adjective If something is close, it fits tightly. Make sure you get a close seal on the tube.
noun A close is a street, especially one that's a cul-de-sac. This word is used mainly in the ~names of streets. I live at 12 Banksia Close.
13 close shave In informal language, if you say you have a close shave, you mean you nearly have an accident or a bad experience, or you only just manage to achieve something. I've had some close shaves, but always survived. I caught my flight to Perth, but it was a close shaveI got there with only 5 minutes to spare.
... WORD FAMILYadjective closed I prefer to work with my door closed. I'm sorry, we're closed.adverb closely The two things are closely related. If you look closely, you can see tiny dots.noun closeness I've always felt a special closeness to Julian.noun closure The proposed closure of the hospital has angered local residents.

form.definition: noun A close-up is a photograph or film shot that is taken very near to the subject. You can see so much detail because it's a close-up.
noun A clot of something such as blood or cream is a solid lump of it. Blood clots can be extremely dangerous if not treated.
noun In informal language, if you call someone a clot, you mean that they are stupid or foolish. What a clot, he forgot our dinner.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb clot Haemophilia is a disease where the blood won't clot.

form.definition: noun Cloth is fabric, used for making garments and other things such as curtains. What sort of cloth is that dress made of? They sell some wonderful silk cloths.
noun A cloth is also a piece of fabric or a flat sponge used for cleaning. He wiped the milk up with a cloth. I wash the windows by hand, with a bucket and cloth.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you clothe someone, you mean you provide them with clothes. Our models are clothed by Australiawide Fashions. We rely on charitable donations to feed and clothe the homeless.
verb In rather formal language, if you say someone is clothed in something, you mean that they're wearing it. He was clothed from head to foot in green.
noun Clothes are garments, the things that people wear to cover themselves and ~keep warm. He had so many clothes that he couldn't fit them all into the wardrobe.
form.note: ... NOTEClothes is always plural.

form.definition: noun Clothing is a formal word for clothes. You may import your personal clothing without duty. ...an item of clothing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective clothing I get a clothing allowance to cover the cost of maintaining the uniform.

form.definition: noun A cloud is a mass of water vapour that floats in the sky. It's a beautiful spring day with not a cloud in the sky. We were flying up above the clouds. There's a large grey cloud on the horizon.
noun A cloud of smoke or dust is a large amount of it in the air in a particular place. The car in front threw up a cloud of dust.
3 cloud over
(a) If the weather clouds over, it becomes cloudy.
(b) If something clouds over, it becomes less easy to see through or into. The mirror clouded over with steam.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See cloudy.

form.definition: adjective If the sky is cloudy, there are a lot of clouds in it. We've had several cloudy days this week. It's cloudy again today.
adjective If a liquid is cloudy, you can't see through it clearly, often because it contains particles of dirt or other substances.

noun In informal language, if you say that you give someone or something a clout, you mean that you hit them quite hard. I gave my head a dreadful clout as I came through the door. If the filing cabinet won't open, give it a clout on the side.

noun In informal language, if you say that someone has clout, you mean they have influence. People take a lot of notice of what they say. We're lucky to have Bill as our union representativehe's got a lot of clout with the boss. A fancy title won't necessarily give you any more clout.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb clout Dad used to clout me for being cheeky.

form.definition: noun Clover is a small plant with leaves that are divided into three parts and with white or pink flowers. It is used as a foodstuff for cattle.

2 in clover In informal language, if you say you're in clover, you mean that you're ~leading a comfortable, luxurious life. Now we've both got good jobs and the kids have settled into school, we're really in clover.
noun A clown is a circus performer who performs acts that are meant to make people laugh.
verb If someone clowns or clowns around, they behave foolishly, usually to make people laugh. Stop clowning and pay attention to me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective clownish

form.definition: noun A club is an organisation of people who share a particular interest or hobby. She's a member of the school debating club. I decided to join a singles club. I go to the sports club twice a week.
noun A club is also a weapon. It is a heavy stick, usually weighted at one end. The riot police were armed with clubs.
noun A club is also a stick used to hit the ball in games such as golf.

4 clubs Clubs is one of the four suits in a pack of playing cards. The cards in this suit are marked with black clover-shaped signs. 5 club together If people club together, they join together to pay for something. Each person contributes some money. We're all going to club together to get Margaret something really nice.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb club (clubs, clubbed, clubbing) They showed a distressing film of seals being clubbed on the ice.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say that a woman is clucky, you mean she wants to have a baby. As she passed thirty, Claudia began to get clucky.

noun A clue is something which helps to solve a puzzle or mystery. The police discovered several clues at the scene of the crime. I'll give you a clueit's got five letters. You have to follow a series of clues to find the hidden treasure.

2 not have a clue In informal language, if you say someone hasn't got a clue about something, you mean that they don't know anything about it. Andrea's been out all day I haven't got a clue where she is. He's hopelesshe hasn't got a clue.
noun A clump is a solid mass of something. The soil tends to pack together in clumps.
noun A clump of plants is a group of them growing close together. Our lawn's in a dreadful statethere are clumps of weeds every~where. I took shelter under a clump of trees.
adjective If someone is clumsy, they move in an awkward way and tend to bump into things and drop things. I can't dance at allI'm very clumsy on my feet. Now look what you've done, you clumsy oaf!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clumsiness

form.definition: verb Clung is the past tense form of cling.

noun A cluster is a small group of things in the same place. They stood around the room in clusters, drinking and chatting. These incidents tend to occur in clusters, then nothing happens for a long while.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb cluster The children clustered around their teacher.

form.definition: verb If you clutch something, you hold it tightly. The little boy clutched his mother's skirt. I was stuck behind a party of tourists clutching maps and guide books.

noun The clutch in a car is the mechanism that transmits the power from the engine to the wheels. The clutch is slipping. b noun The clutch can also be the pedal you use to engage and disengage this mechanism. You must press the clutch right down while you change gear. 3 clutch at If you clutch at something, you reach out for it with your hands. He felt himself falling and clutched at the rope.
4 have someone in your clutches If you have someone in your clutches, you have total power over them.

verb If you clutter something or clutter it up, you make it untidy because there are too many things. I hate it when you clutter up the yard with junk. You've cluttered the argument with unnecessary detail.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun clutter Would you move your clutter off the table, please.

form.definition: abbreviation for centimetre.
abbreviation for Company.
form.note: ... NOTEIn informal language, especially when you're talking about a group of friends instead of .

form.definition: abbreviation for care of. See the explanation at care.
noun A coach is a tourist bus. Did you go by train or coach?
noun A coach is ~a railway carriage. We got into the last coach on the train.
noun A coach is someone who trains people or a team of people in a particular sport or subject.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb coach I'm coaching Isaac at swimming. He coaches maths in his spare time.

form.definition: verb If a liquid such as blood or paint coagulates, it becomes very thick.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun coagulation

form.definition: noun Coal is a hard black substance that is mined from under the earth and burned as a fuel.

noun A coalition is an arrangement where two or more political parties join together in the hope of forming a majority to govern the country. In Australia, this arrangement exists between the Liberal and National parties.

coarse If something is coarse, the parts of which it is made up are relatively large. The opposite of this is fine. The path was covered with coarse gravel. The smaller fish can escape through the coarse netting.
adjective If something is coarse, it is simple and basic. It is not elaborate. He was dressed in a coarse woollen coat. They live on a coarse diet of rice and vegetables.
adjective If someone is coarse, they are uncultured and rude.
adjective We say language is coarse if it is about sexual matters or things like going to the toilet and if we are offended by it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb coarsely ...coarsely chopped vegetables.

form.definition: noun The coast is the part of an area of land that's near to the sea. He's got a holiday home on the south coast of New South Wales. We sailed along the coast, looking for a place to land.
verb If a car coasts, it continues to move without being driven by its motor. My driving instructor told me off for coasting up to the traffic lights.
verb If somebody coasts along, they get by without making much effort. Russell coasted through his first year at college. I had to work hard at first, but now I'm just coasting.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYcoastal adjective ...coastal showers.

form.definition: noun Coastline is another word for coast, especially for the very edge of the land by the sea.
noun A coat is a piece of clothing, usually with long sleeves, that you wear over other clothes. You'll need a coatit's cold outside.
noun An animal's coat is the layer of fur on its body.
verb If you coat something with something else, you cover it with a thin layer of it. Coat each biscuit with chocolate, then place in the fridge for an hour.

noun A coat of something is a thin layer of it. This house could do with a coat of paint. The coat of silver's beginning to flake off. 4 coat of arms A coat of arms is an emblem or symbol that's used by a country, family, university, and so on.
noun A coathanger is a curved piece of wood or plastic which you can hook over a rail in your wardrobe, and on which you hang an item of clothing like a coat or shirt.
A coating is a thin layer of something spread over a surface. The saucepans have a non-stick coating.
verb If you coax someone to do something, you gently try to persuade them to do it. She coaxed the baby to drink his milk.
noun A cobweb is the pattern of fine, sticky threads spun by a spider to trap insects.
noun Cocaine is an addictive drug that acts as a stimulant.
noun A cock is an adult male chicken.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is rooster.

form.definition: noun Cock is an informal word for penis.
