noun A cockatoo is a large Australian parrot which has a crest of feathers on its head. White cockatoos are common but black ones are quite rare.
form.note: ... A SHORTENED FORMof this is cocky.

form.definition: noun The cockpit is the area at the front of a plane where the pilot sits.
noun A cockpit is also the compartment where the driver sits in a racing car.
noun A cocktail is a drink made by mixing various drinks together. There are alcoholic and non-alcoholic cocktails. Why don't you come over for a cocktail before the show?
noun In informal language, a cock-up is a situation where someone has made ~a bad mistake. Who's responsible for this cock-up? The whole thing was a complete cock-up.

dictionary.entry:
cocky`kOki:cockiercockiest 1 adjective In informal language, if you say someone is cocky, you mean that they're too confident of themselves. It's her cocky attitude that annoys me.
noun In informal language, cocky is short for cockatoo.~[xp\start\~[ap--cocoa
`k@Uk@U
noun Cocoa is a hot sweet drink that you make from milk and a powder that comes from the crushed seeds of a tropical plant. Would you like a cup of cocoa? We've nearly finished this tin of cocoa.

form.definition: noun A coconut is the large, hard fruit of a type of palm. Inside, it has hard white flesh that you can eat and juice that you can drink.
abbreviation for cash on delivery. If you buy something COD, you have to pay for it when it is delivered.

noun A code is a set of rules about how people should behave in a particular situation. That advertisement doesn't follow the trade's code of practice. Anna is learning the traffic code so she can get her driver's licence.

noun A code is also a system for giving a secret message. Only the person for whom the message is intended can understand the code. Most of the signals were transmitted in code. We worked out a code for warning each other when we were not to be disturbed.
noun A code of football is a particular variety of it, such as rugby league.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb decode ...to decode a secret message.verb encode Commercially sensitive information should be encoded before it is sent.

form.definition: noun Codeine is a pain-killing medicine. It is often used to relieve the pain of headaches.

verb In rather formal language, if you say that someone coerces you to do something, you mean they force you to do it even though you don't want to, perhaps by threatening that something bad will happen if you don't agree. Janos felt that he'd been unfairly coerced into transferring to a remote area of the state.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun coercion

form.definition: noun Coffee is a rather bitter hot drink that you make from water and a powder that comes from the roasted and ground seeds of a tropical plant. Sometimes you also add milk and sugar. Would you like a cup of coffee? I bought a jar of coffee and a packet of tea bags.
noun A coffin is the box in which a dead person is buried or cremated.[qr

dictionary.entry:
cogkOg
noun A cog is a wheel with teeth around its edge which link into the teeth of another wheel and make it turn around.
noun A cog is also one of the teeth around the edge of the wheel.
noun If you say someone is a cog in an organisation, you mean that they are just one of many people working there and they do not have very much influence on what happens. It's no use blaming Johnhe's just a cog in the system.

form.definition: adjective If something such as an account or an essay is coherent, the different parts of it fit together well so that it is easy to understand. The book gives a coherent account of Europe between the wars.

adjective If someone speaks in a coherent way, what they say makes sense and is clear to anyone listening. When I spoke to Kaled after his accident he was perfectly coherent. She was so shocked that she wasn't very coherent, but I gather she was attacked by two men.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun coherence adverb coherently

form.definition: noun Cohesion is a state or situation where everything fits together well. After so many years together, there's a strong feeling of cohesion in the group.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cohesive They form a tightly knit and cohesive group.

form.definition: noun A coil of something such as wire or rope is formed when you wind the full length so that a number of circles or loops lie one on top of the other. There's a coil of rope lying on the ground.

verb If you coil something, or it coils, it is wound around so that its whole length is in the shape of rings, usually one on top of or beside the other. The snake had coiled itself around the branch of the tree. Coil the rope and store it ~in the garage.
noun In informal language, a coil is a contraceptive called an IUD, short for intra-uterine device.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb coil I coiled up the hose and put it in the garage.

form.definition: noun A coin is a small, round, flat piece of metal which is used as money.
verb If someone coins a word or a phrase, they invent it. The saying was coined by a radio announcer and now everyone's using it.

3 to coin a phrase If you include the words to coin a phrase with something you say, you are describing a situation with a well-known phrase that everybody will understand. You are not inventing a new phrase at all. Omar was at the races and he was, to coin a phrase, as sober as a judge.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun coinage Australia adopted decimal coinage in 1966.

form.definition: verb If two or more things coincide, they happen at the same time as each other. Unfortunately our holidays don't coincide this year. Luis's visit here coincided with our trip overseas, so we missed him. Our party coincided with the wettest day of the year.
verb If people's opinions coincide, they are the same. Our beliefs have never coincidedwe're always arguing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See coincidence.

form.definition: noun A coincidence is two or more events happening at the same time by chance, something you wouldn't expect. Are you trying to tell me it's just a coincidence that you two arrived at the party together? By an amazing coincidence I found myself sitting next to an old friend from school.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective coincidental

form.definition: noun Coke is a type of coal which is used as a fuel in making steel.
noun Coke is an informal word for cocaine.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with Coke, which is a short form for the soft drink Coca Cola. Both of these words are registered trade names.

form.definition: noun A colander is a plastic or metal bowl with many small holes in the bottom. You used it in the kitchen for draining liquids away from foods such as salad leaves that you've rinsed or pasta that you've boiled in water.

adjective If something is cold, it has a very low temperature. It's cold in here. The weather turned colder. Put the heater on if you feel cold. You can eat this quiche hot or cold. I'd love a cold beer. Which is the cold water tap?
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is hot.

form.definition: adjective If someone acts in a cold way, they are unfriendly and don't display any emotion or warmth of feeling. Inda has a cold manner and doesn't make friends easily. We met with a very cold reception.

noun The cold is a state in which the temperature is very low. Come in out of the cold. Because of the unexpected cold, we decided to hold the party indoors. These vaccines have to be stored in the cold.
noun A cold is also a very common, mild, viral illness which affects your nose and throat. It causes symptoms such as sneezing, coughing and a fever. I spent the day in bed because I had a bad cold.

5 catch cold If you catch cold or catch a cold, you become sick with a cold. Don't sit around with wet hairyou'll catch cold. I didn't go to the party because I didn't want the others to catch my cold.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb coldly She looked at him coldly as he fumbled in his pocket.noun coldness

form.definition: adjective If someone acts in a cold-blooded way, they show no pity or sympathy towards the people they deal with. The judge said the accused was a cold-blooded murderer. She was quite cold-blooded about retrenching a third of the staff.
adjective Animals such as reptiles and fish are said to be cold-blooded, which means that their temperature depends on the environment they are in.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb cold-bloodedly noun cold-bloodedness

form.definition: noun Coleslaw is a salad made from shredded raw cabbage mixed with dressing and other vegetable ingredients such as onion.
noun Colic is a painful condition, especially in babies, which causes cramps in the stomach and bowel.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective colicky

form.definition: verb If people collaborate, they work together in order to achieve something. The writer and photographer collaborated to produce a marvellous documentary.
verb If someone collaborates with the enemy during a war, they help them and betray their own country. Many of those who had collaborated with the invaders received rough justice at the war's end.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun collaboration noun collaborator ...a known collaborator.

form.definition: verb If something collapses, it falls down suddenly. Five minutes after the earthquake, the bridge collapsed. The picnic table collapsed under the weight of the heavy pot.

verb If someone collapses, they fall down suddenly because they are ill or very tired. He collapsed at the supermarket and died on the way to hospital. After studying late into the night for so many weeks, she collapsed with exhaustion.

verb If something such as a marriage, plan or project collapses, it suddenly fails or breaks down. Their relationship collapsed and they got a divorce. Talks between the government and the teachers' union have collapsed.
verb If you collapse something, you fold it into a shape that takes up less space. You can collapse this table and put it away when you don't need it. We need a tent that collapses easily.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun collapse I could see he was close to collapse. The collapse of her business was a blow.adjective collapsible I bought some collapsible chairs to take in the car for picnics.[qr

dictionary.entry:
collar`kOl@
noun The collar of a garment is the part around the neck which is usually sewn on separately and is often folded over. You'll need to scrub the collars and cuffs to get them clean. 2 noun A collar is a band made of something such as leather or twine which is put around the neck of a dog or a cat. Our cat has stopped scratching since we gave her a flea collar.
verb In informal language, if you say someone collars you, you mean that they catch you when you are trying to avoid them. He was collared by the police and put into jail. Why do I always get collared by the most boring person at the party? The boss collared me about the slow progress of the project.

form.definition: noun Your collarbone is one of two long bones that go from the base of your neck to your shoulder. He broke his collarbone playing rugby.
noun Collateral is money or property which is used as a guarantee for a loan. He borrowed $45|000 from the bank using his house as collateral.
noun Your colleague is someone you work with. I often go for a drink after work on Friday with some of my colleagues. Meet my colleague, Menghe's responsible for the financial side.
verb If you collect things, you acquire as many of them as possible as a hobby. She collects coins from all around the world.
verb If you collect money for a charity or a special purpose, you ask people to give towards it. I'm collecting money for the Smith Family. Bob is collecting for June's farewell.

verb If you collect something from a place, you pick it up from there. You go there and take it away with you. I collected my clothes from the dry cleaner. I have to collect the children from school at 3 p.m.

verb If something collects somewhere, it accumulates or builds up there over a period of time. Did you see how much dust had collected on the shelves? The rubbish that collects in my daughter's room has to be seen to be believed!
adjective A collect call is a phone call that is paid for by the person you are ringing. This kind of call is often called a reverse charges call. There is a collect call for you, will you accept it?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See collector. noun collection

form.definition: adjective If something is described as collective, it belongs to or is shared by a number of people. We each paid $5 to buy Ralph a collective present. It was the collective opinion of the committee that he should resign immediately. Collective bargaining is a key union right.
noun A collective is a group of people who share the running and the ownership of a property, business or any similar enterprise. The newsletter is produced by an editorial collective.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb collectively We decided collectively to protest.

form.definition: noun A collector is someone who acquires things of a particular type because they like them or are interested in them. He's a stamp collector. The painting is now in the hands of a private collector.
noun A collector is someone whose job is to gather something such as money or tickets from different people. There won't be any a ticket collector there after 7 o'clock. ...a rent collector.
noun A college is an institution where you study after you finish high school, such as a teachers' college or an agricultural college. Her youngest daughter's at college now.
noun A college is also a place within a university where students live. Are you still living at home or are you in college? The conference will be held at Wesley College.
noun Some private secondary schools are called colleges.
verb If you collide with someone, you bump into them, usually with some force. As I ran out to the street I collided with my brother running the other way.
verb If two or more vehicles collide, they crash into each other. The two cars collided at the intersection.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun collision There was a nasty collision on the bridge last night.

dictionary.entry: colognek@`l@Un Cologne is a weak type of perfume.

form.definition: noun A colon is the punctuation mark :. It is used to separate the main part of the sentence from another part which is often a list of thingsfor example, She bought several gar-ments at the sale: a dress, a skirt, blouses and a jumper.
noun Your colon is a part of your intestine. She was diagnosed with cancer of the colon.
noun A colonel is a senior officer in the army or air force.
noun A colony is a territory that has been taken over and is controlled by a more powerful country. People from the ruling country leave their homeland to form a settlement there.

noun A colony is also a group of animals or plants of the same kind who live closely together. The pest control company found a colony of termites under the house.~ ... WORD FAMILYadjective colonial verb colonise (or colonize) noun colonist
adjective If something is colossal, it is very large. The building is colossalit's a magnificent feat of engineering. They served us a colossal banquet of about ten courses.
adjective In informal language, if you say something is colossal, you mean that it is very impressive and amazing. You should see the movieit's colossal.

noun The colour of something is how it looks when reflecting light. It is the quality something has which we label with words such as red, yellow, blue, green, orange or purple. What's your favourite colour? What colour dress was she wearing? I decided to paint the bathroom a different colour. The book is a reddish colour.

noun A colour is a substance such as a dye or paint that you apply to something to give it a different appearance. The colour is added to the paste through this nozzle. I'm very pleased with this new hair colourthe effect is really natural. 3 noun Someone's colour is the colour of their skin, used as a label for their racial or ethnic status. He suspected that he had been discriminated against because of his colour.

noun Colour is the extra detail that you add to a story which makes it more interesting or dramatic. He should have told us about people who travelled with himthat would have given a bit more colour to his story.

verb If you colour something, you use dye or paint to make it a different colour. Do you think she colours her hair? Why don't you colour in the picture with your crayons? The icing is coloured with natural dyes. We decided to colour the bathroom pink.
verb When someone colours, they go red in the face, for example because they are embarrassed, shy or angry. Mia's face coloured with anger and she turned and left the room.
verb If something colours your judgment or opinion, it has an effect on it even though it is not strictly relevant. Knowing that he has been cruel to his animals colours my feelings about him.

8 in colour If something is in colour, it is several different colours, not just black and white. Her photo was in yesterday's paper, in full colour. If you buy this ribbon for your printer, you'll be able to print in colour.~ ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this word is color. ... WORD FAMILYtograph. ...a colour television. ...a colour photocopier.adjective coloured The white envelopes are $2 a packet and the coloured ones are $3.adjective colourful I like this patternit's very bright and colourful.adjective colourless The glass contained a colourless liquid.[qr
noun A column is a tall, thin, cylindrical pillar which is used to support part of a building. The entrance was flanked by two large white columns.
noun A column is anything which has a tall, thin shape. Columns of smoke were rising into the air.
noun A column of people or animals is a group of them forming a long line one behind the other. Children, form two columns, please!

noun A column of print in a newspaper or magazine is a vertical section on a page. It is separated from other vertical sections on either side by narrow strips of blank space. The story got three columns in today's paper. The price is given in the last column of the table.

noun A column is also a piece of writing by a particular person which appears regularly in a newspaper or magazine. Did you read Jim Morris's column in today's paper? I like to read the fashion columns.
noun If someone is in a coma, they are unconscious for a long while, usually because of a severe accident or illness. Mary was in a coma for three weeks after the accident.
noun A comb is made out of plastic or metal and has narrow, pointed teeth along one edge of it which you draw through your hair to make it tidy.
verb If you comb your hair, you tidy it using a comb.

verb If you comb a place, you search it thoroughly because you are looking for something or someone. The rescue services combed the area for three days in search of the lost hikers. I've combed my files but I can't find any record of the transaction.

dictionary.entry:
combat`kOmbAt for the noun; for the verb,
noun Combat is the fighting that takes place between opposing armies. The soldiers were locked in combat.
noun Combat is also a struggle or competition between two people which is not necessarily violent. The Russian and American chess players were in combat for days.
verb If you combat something, you fight against it and try to resist it. He is always trying to combat his craving for sweet things. Both candidates vowed to combat rising crime. Tough new regulations are being introduced to combat pollution.
... WORD FAMILY Two hundred combatants perished in the battle. She was unnecessarily combative in her response to the proposal.
`kOmb@t@nt`kOmb@tIv

form.definition: noun A combination is a number of things that are joined or mixed together. Pink and yellow is a horrible combination.
noun A combination is also a sequence of letters or numbers that is used to open a combination lock. He couldn't open the safe because he forgot the combination.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See combine.

form.definition: noun A combination lock is a special lock that you can only open by turning its control according to a particular sequence of letters or numbers.

verb If you combine two or more things or if they combine, they become joined together to form a single thing. If you combine yellow and blue, you get green. The two parties combined to increase their share of the vote. This dish combines sweet and spicy ingredients.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See combination.

form.definition: verb If someone comes somewhere, they move towards where you are. Come over here, please. Marius hasn't come into work today. When did you come to Australia?

verb You can say someone or something comes to a particular place if they arrive there. I hope the bus comes soon. The waiter finally came to our table to take our order. Are you leaving already? You've only just come!
verb If someone comes to an event, they attend it. Will you come to dinner with me? I'm afraid I won't be able to come to your party. People came from all over the country to see the exhibition.
verb If something comes to a certain point, it reaches or extends that far. Her hair comes to just below her shoulders. The water came half way up the wall.
verb If a date or event comes, it happens in the course of time. At last my birthday came. The time has come to make a decision. Christmas is coming soon.
verb If someone or something comes into view or into sight, they appear. At last she came into sight at the top of the hill.
7 come about If something comes about, it happens as a result of something else. How did the misunderstanding come about?
come across If you come across something, you find it by chance. I came across an old photo of you last week. In all my long experience I've never come across a similar case.
9 come forward If someone comes forward to do something, they offer to do it. If the committee can't persuade anyone to come forward with financial support, they may have to drop the idea.

10 come from If you come from a certain place, you live there or were born there. Most of our pupils come from the inner city. My mother comes from Sicily and my father comes from Crete. 11 come over If something comes over you, it affects you suddenly. Why are you acting so strangely? What has come over you? A great wave of tiredness came over me.
12 come to If a bill or account comes to a certain amount, it adds up to that amount. The bill came to over $500. So we've examined the various options, but what does it all come to?
13 come up with (a) If you come up with an idea or a plan, you think of it as the solution to a problem. Melinda came up with a plan to persuade Martin to stay on at school.

(b) If you come up with something that is needed, you provide it unexpectedly. There was nothing to eat until Maria came up with some bread and cheese that she'd picked up at the shops. If they don't come up with a payment soon we'll have to stop their account.
noun A comedy is a funny movie, TV show or play.
noun A comedy can be any funny event that makes people laugh. The way she told it, her camping trip was a real comedy.~ ... WORD FAMILYadjective See comic. noun comedian
noun A comet is a body in space which travels around the sun leaving a misty trail behind it. Halley's comet appears every 76 years. They believed that the comet was a sign from the gods.
noun Comfort is the state of being physically relaxed and at ease. I was able to stretch out in the chair in comfort.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is discomfort.

form.definition: noun If you live in comfort, you have enough money to live well without worry. They wanted their children to lead lives of comfort.
noun Comfort is kindness or sympathy which you give to someone who is sad, sick or worried. The nurse spoke a few words of comfort to the patient.
noun Comfort is the feeling of support and reassurance that they get from this. The kindness of my friends was a great comfort to me when my wife died.

verb If you comfort someone, you try to make them less sad or worried, for example by talking to them in a kind and sympathetic way or by hugging them. Jill tried to comfort the boy after his dog was run over.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See comfortable.adjective comforting His sympathy was very comforting.

form.definition: adjective If you are comfortable in your physical circumstances, you are able to relax and be at ease. You are not bothered because of being cramped or awkward, or too hot or cold. Are you comfortable in that chair, or would you like a cushion? The table is too low to be comfortable to work at. It's not very comfortable in the office without air conditioning.

adjective If you are comfortable about something, you feel at ease about it in your mind. You do not feel worried, embarrassed or guilty. I'm quite comfortable with my decision to leave my job. I'm not very comfortable to keep asking him for favours.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this sense is uncomfortable.

form.definition: adjective If someone who has been seriously ill or injured is described as being comfortable, their condition is improving.
adjective If you are comfortable or comfortably off, you have enough ~money to live well without worry. I don't want to be rich, just comfortable.
adjective If you find something comic, it amuses you and makes you laugh. The film is full of comic situations. If the issue were not so vital their blundering would be comic.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is comical.

form.definition: noun A comic is an entertainer who makes people laugh. He works in a nightclub as a comic.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is comedian.

form.definition: noun A comic is a magazine in which cartoon drawings are used to tell stories. Sid's not much of a readerhe sticks to comics most of the time.
noun A comma is the punctuation mark ,. It is used in some sentences to separate clauses and phrases. It is also used between items in a list.
verb If you command someone to do something, you order them to do it. The sergeant commanded his troops to attack.
noun A command is an order. He gave the command to commence firing.
verb If you command something, you control it totally and you are responsible for it. He commanded the entire western sector.
noun Command is the ability to have control over a situation. Her command never faltered, even in the most stressful situations.
noun A commando is one of a small group of highly trained soldiers often used for dangerous and difficult missions into enemy territory.
verb If you commemorate a person or an event, you do something special to show that you remember them. A statue was built to commemorate the life of Governor Macquarie.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun commemoration adjective commemorative

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you say you commence something, you mean that you begin or start it. You are required to commence work at 8 a.m. daily.

verb In formal language, if you say something commences, you mean that it begins or starts. Please take your seatsthe performance will commence in five ~minutes. It commenced raining as soon as we left the house.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun commencement At the commencement of term, most new students are enthusiastic.

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say you commend someone, you mean that you praise them officially. Nicholas has had a good year at school and I commend him for his efforts.

verb In formal language, if you say you commend something to someone, you mean that you tell them about it and say that it is good or important. You recommend it. It is a good scheme and I commend it to you.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective commendable She showed commendable discretion.noun commendation The boys received a commendation for their bravery.

form.definition: noun A comment is a short remark that expresses an opinion about something. Whenever I sing my brother makes rude comments. The premier refused to make any comment on the situation.

verb If you comment on something, you notice it and say something that expresses your opinion about it. I couldn't help commenting on Belinda's new hairstyle. He commented that he'd had to wait a long time for a reply.
noun A commentary is a narrative that explains what is happening. He was listening to the racing commentary on the radio. The documentary program let the events unfold with the minimum of commentary.
noun A commentary is also a discussion or analysis that gives someone's opinion about events. Did you read the political commentary in the paper yesterday?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb commentate noun commentator

form.definition: noun Commerce is the buying and selling of goods and services.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See commercial.

form.definition: adjective Commercial means relating to commerce. She got a job as a commercial traveller. He specialises in commercial law.
adjective If something is commercial, it is intended to make a profit. She only began producing her invention as a commercial venture last year.
~adjective If something is too commercial, the aim to make a profit has resulted in a lowering of standards. His early work was very fine, but lately his paintings have become very commercial.
adjective Commercial radio and television are paid for by advertisements.
noun A commercial is an advertisement that is broadcast in intervals between and during programs on television and radio. Commercials can take up to a quarter of the advertised time of a program.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective commercially

form.definition: verb If you commiserate with someone, you express sympathy to them because they are upset or disappointed about something. We commiserated with each other when we both failed our exams. I commiserated with David about his family problems.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun commiseration

form.definition: verb If you commission a piece of work, you arrange for it to be done according to your instructions in return for payment. His friends commissioned a portrait to mark his 80th birthday. I commissioned Jenny to write a text to accompany the photos.
noun A commission is an order for a particular piece of creative work. Does the artist accept commissions?
noun A commission is a sum of money paid to a sales person for every sale they make. The salary is low but Ena makes quite a bit on commissions.
noun A commission is a group of people who are appointed officially to do a particular job. The premier ordered a commission of inquiry into police corruption.

5 out of commission If something is out of commission, it is not able to be used because it is damaged or broken. My car will be out of commission for several days while they carry out the repairs. A heavy cold put him out of commission for the rest of the week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See commissioner.

form.definition: noun A commissioner is someone who is a member of an official commission.
noun A commissioner is also the highest ranking official in a government department. The Police Commissioner retired after eight years in the job.
3 high commissioner A high commissioner is the highest ranking diplo~matic representative of one country to another, within the Commonwealth of Nations. The rank is the same as that of an ambassador.
verb If someone commits a crime, they do it. The same gang is believed to have committed all these burglaries.
verb If someone commits suicide, they kill themselves.

verb If you commit something such as money or time to a purpose, you devote it or set it aside for that purpose. The bank has committed $50|000 to the project. I'm not willing to commit more than a day a month to the society.
verb If someone is committed to prison or to a mental hospital, they are sent there.

4 commit yourself If you commit yourself to a course of action, you decide or promise to do it with the firm intention that you won't change your mind. I had no hesitation in committing myself to the project. We ask that you commit yourself for a minimum of three months. He was frustrated by her reluctance to commit herself. 5 not commit yourself If you do not commit yourself, you avoid saying or doing anything decisive because you want to keep your options open. I wouldn't like to commit myself on that subject.

noun If you show commitment, you show dedication and determination in trying to achieve something. It takes a lot of commitment to put in the hours of training needed. I admired her commitment to her ideals.

noun A commitment is a responsibility or something you have taken on that may make it difficult for you to do what you would like. Regular travel interstate is hard to fit in with family commitments. I'm afraid I already have a commitment for that evening.

noun A committee is a group of people who represent a larger group or organisation. They discuss or make decisons about particular matters which affect everybody. A special committee has been set up to investigate the alternatives. She was elected to the P&C committee.

noun A commodity is something that is useful for a particular purpose. This is a rather formal word, used especially in shops and stores. This area is devoted to household ~commodities, mainly for the kitchen and laundry.
noun A commodity can also be anything that is of use or advantage. Common sense is a more important commodity than great intelligence in most situations.
noun A commodity is also a basic raw material that is traded, such as minerals or farm products.
adjective If something is common, it occurs frequently or in large numbers. Zhang is a very common family name in China. It's not common for the weather to be so cold in November.

adjective If something is described as common, it belongs to or is shared by several people. We have a common interest in chess. They were united by a common dislike of Martin. I spoke no Vietnamese and Minh no English, so our only common language was French.
3 common knowledge If you say some fact is common knowledge, you mean that it is generally known. It is not secret or concealed. It's now common knowledge that they don't live together.
4 common sense If someone has common sense, they are not too concerned with theory but have a practical and effective approach to solving problems.
5 in common (a) If two or more people own something in common, they own it between them.

(b) If you have something in common with someone else, that is a point of similarity between you. As we chatted it became clear that we had many interests in common. The only feature the sisters have in common is their straight dark hair.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb commonly I commonly go for a walk before dinner.

form.definition: noun The Commonwealth of Australia is the group of states and territories which have joined together to form the nation of Australia.
noun The Commonwealth of Nations is an association made up of countries that were formerly colonies of the United Kingdom.
noun A commotion is a lot of noise, excitement or confusion. We heard the commotion in the street and went to see what was happening.
adjective If something is communal, it is shared or used by several people. We have our own kitchen but there's ~a communal laundry. We each pay $1 a week for a communal supply of biscuits.

dictionary.entry:
commune`kOmju:n for the noun; for the verb,k@`mju:n
noun A commune is a group of people who live together and share their lives and property. The last I heard of her she was living in a commune.
verb If you commune with someone, you spend time together in sharing thoughts or just silently enjoying each other's company.

form.definition: verb If you communicate with someone, you get in touch with them, either by writing, telephoning or speaking to them directly. Don hadn't communicated with his accountants and wasn't aware of the problem. I try to communicate with my parents once a week.
verb If you manage to communicate with someone, you understand each other. Somehow I feel we're just not communicating. As a public speaker you have to know how to communicate with your audience.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you communicate information to someone, you mean that you pass it on to them. The result of your application will be communicated within three weeks. He's very clever, but he's a hopeless teacher because he just can't communicate simple facts.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See communication.

form.definition: noun Communication is the process of giving information to other people. Communication from the hut suggests that the walkers have been found. Even when there are tensions in the family, it is important to keep up communication.

noun A communication is a letter or telephone call from someone. Jeanne had a number of communications from her son and then nothing for about six months. 3 communications Communications are the systems and processes used to transmit information, especially electronically.

dictionary.entry: communism`kOmj@nIz@m noun Communism is a social and political system in which the state controls all economic activity. ... WORD FAMILYadjective communist noun communist

form.definition: noun A community is a group of people who live in a particular area and share a ~common language and culture. In country towns the teacher is an important figure in the community. He is a leading member of the local Greek community.
verb If you commute, you travel a fairly long distance to work from your home and back again each day. I don't mind commuting because it gives me time to think.
verb If a sentence passed on a prisoner is commuted, the punishment is changed to one that is less severe. The death sentence was commuted to life imprisonment.
adjective If something is compact, it doesn't take up much space. It fits into a small area. The kitchen is compact but it's got everything you could need.
adjective If things are arranged in a compact way, they are packed closely and tightly beside each other.
verb If things are compacted, they are crushed or pressed tightly together so that they take up less space. The garbage truck compacts all of the rubbish with a huge metal press.
noun A compact is a small flat container which holds face powder and a powder puff. She got out her compact and powdered her nose.
noun A compact disc is a disc which has recorded information on it. The information is read by laser and played back so that you can hear or see it.
form.note: ... A SHORTENED FORMof this is CD.

dictionary.entry: companionk@m`pAnj@n noun Your companion is a person you are with. She turned up at the party with a new companion. The man sitting opposite me proved an entertaining companion. ... WORD FAMILYadjective companionable We sat in companionable silence.noun companionship I valued their companionship on the long journey.

company`kV mp@ni:companies 1 noun A company is a firm that is set up to do business and make a profit. He works for a large
noun A company is a group of people who work together to provide entertainment, such as a ballet company or an opera company. She joined the company in 1990.
noun A company is a group of soldiers forming part of a regiment and numbering about 120.
noun Company is the state of having other people with ~you. Stella likes a bit of companyshe gets lonely when there's no-one around. Thank you for this eveningI've enjoyed your company. I missed your company while you were away.
5 good company If someone is good company, they are entertaining and you enjoy being with them. Felix is really good companyhe's always got plenty to talk about. I'm afraid I'm not very good company tonightI'm just so tired from the week.
6 part company If you part company with someone you have been with, you leave them. We parted company at the shops and I came home by bus. After two years Bogdan and Basia parted company.

form.definition: adjective Research work which is comparative searches out the similarities and differences between things. She is writing a comparative study of three modern Australian writers.

adjective If you qualify a word with comparative, you mean that it applies to an extentespecially considering what one might expect or what has happened beforebut not absolutely and without qualification. Another word for this is relative. After his early struggles he lived a life of comparative luxury. In this group you're a comparative newcomer.

adjective In grammar, the comparative form of an adjective or adverb is the form that shows that it is true in a greater degree. For example, longer is the comparative form of long and more likely is the comparative form of likely.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnomenon is comparatively recent. We're comparatively fortunate.

form.definition: verb If you compare two or more things or compare one thing with another, you examine them to discover to what extent they are alike. I compared the samples of handwriting. For our homework we have to compare the two authors' use of characterisation. He compared the copy carefully with the original.
verb If something compares with something else, it is as good as the other thing. Australian wines compare with any in the world. My photographs can't compare with the work of a professional.

3 compared to You use compared to to point out a contrast between the way something is and some other event or situation. It seems expensive but compared to what ~Sally paid I suppose it's reasonable. The house sold for $1|000|000 compared to $500|000 five years ago.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See comparative.

form.definition: noun If you make a comparison between two or more things, you compare them with each other. A comparison between the breeds of cattle showed that the smaller ones produced more milk.

2 in comparison with You use in comparison with to point out a contrast with the way something is and some other event or situation. Profits have increased by 30% in comparison with last year. June's doing well in comparison with the others, but she could do still better. He was so tall I seemed short in comparison.

noun A compartment is a separate space or section intended to contain something. I keep my passport in a secret compartment in my desk. The drawer is divided into a number of compartments for bits and pieces. The salad compartment is at the bottom of the fridge.
noun A compartment on a train is one of the small rooms that each carriage is sometimes divided into. An elderly gentleman came into our compartment. We booked a sleeping compartment.[qr

dictionary.entry:
compass`kV mp@s
noun A compass is an instrument that you use for finding directions. It has a magnetic needle that points north. Our compass was broken so we had to rely on the sun to show us the right direction.
noun A compass or pair of compasses is a device that you use in geometry for drawing and measuring circles.

form.definition: noun Compassion is a feeling of sympathy or pity. David showed compassion in agreeing not to punish the poor child. We have a duty to treat animals with compassion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective compassionate Tara showed her compassionate nature in forgiving him.

form.definition: adjective If two people are compatible, they get on well together and enjoy each other's company. Tomas and Leila are getting divorced because they just aren't compatible any more. Take this quiz to find out how compatible you are with your partner.
adjective ~If two things are compatible, they work properly together. The computer and the printer aren't compatible. The demands of my work are not compatible with a normal family life.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun compatibility

form.definition: verb If someone compels you to do something, they force you to do it. You can't compel me to give up my rights. The weather compelled us to turn back.
verb If something compels you to do something, it makes you feel that you have to do it. Their dishonesty compelled me to speak out. What compelled you to take up acting?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See compulsion.

form.definition: adjective If something such as a story or someone's personality is compelling, it is fascinating and attractive. The compelling narrative made me keep reading to the end. She fixed a compelling gaze on me.
adjective If someone's argument is compelling, it is convincing. She presented some compelling evidence in support of her case.

verb If you compensate someone for something, you pay them money or do something to make good a loss or wrong that they have suffered. The federal government promised to compensate the landowners for their losses.
verb If you compensate for treating someone badly, you do something to make up for it. Max offered to help with the cleaning up to compensate for arriving late.
verb If something good compensates for something bad, it makes up for it so that overall the situation is acceptable. Her singing was a little harsh, but her excellent acting compensated for it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun compensation She is claiming $40|000 in compensation for wrongful dismissal.

form.definition: noun A compere is the host on a TV show. The compere did his best to make the audience laugh.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb compere She compered the show for years.

form.definition: verb If you compete against someone for something, you try to be the one who is successful in achieving it. The two children are always competing for their mother's attention. Sydney competed against many other cities to host the Olympic Games in 2000.
verb If you compete in a contest or a game, you take part in it and you try to do well. Ray is competing in the one hundred metres sprint.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See competition. adjective See competitive.

form.definition: adjective If you are competent, you are capable of doing things properly. He is a very competent cook. Any competent accountant ought to have spotted the error. It was several weeks before I felt fully competent in my new role.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun competence

form.definition: noun A competition is an organised event which people enter in order to try to win some prize or award. Sheridan came first in the maths competition. Are you going to enter the college squash competition? They held a competition to design the new town hall.

noun Competition is a situation of rivalry which exists between people who are trying to achieve the same goals when only a limited number of them can be successful. The two boys are good friends but there is a lot of competition between them.

noun The competition is the people that you are competing against. Travis won the race easily because the competition was weak. In business you have to be constantly alert to stay ahead of the competition.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun competitor Over seventy competitors took part. She's a keen competitor.

form.definition: adjective If someone is competitive, they are very keen to do better than other people. I don't like playing golf with Darlashe's so competitive that she has to win every hole.
adjective If a situation is competitive, there are several people involved who are all trying to do better than the others. Children's publishing is a very competitive market.
adjective If a price is competitive, it is low enough to encourage people to buy that product rather than another one.

verb If you compile something such as a report, you compose it by putting together many different pieces of information. When you've finished reading all the material, I'd like you to compile a summary of it. I compiled a list of all ~the different tasks I had undertaken during the year.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun compilation

form.definition: adjective If someone is complacent, they are too pleased with themselves and their situation. They are not aware of any danger that might make them need to change anything. I've studied hard, but I don't want to be complacent about my chances in the exam.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun complacency Complacency in a teacher leads to students being bored.

form.definition: verb If you complain, you say that you are not content about something. You protest or grumble about it. The neighbours complained about the noise. If you're not satisfied, complain to the manager. Damian's always complaining about something.
verb If you complain of a certain symptom, you tell a doctor about what you are experiencing. The patient first came to me complaining of severe headaches.

noun If you make a complaint, you state formally that you are not content about something. I wrote a letter of complaint to head office. There is a set procedure for dealing with complaints and grievances.
noun A complaint is also a physical symptom or sickness. This complaint often occurs towards the end of pregnancy.
verb If one thing complements another, the two things go together very well. The light sauce complements the strong flavour of the meat. She complemented the navy suit with a crisp white blouse.
2 full complement A full complement is the number that is required for some purpose. Our cricket team now has its full complement of players.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with compliment. ... WORD FAMILYnoun complement Mustard is the perfect complement to beef.

form.definition: adjective You use complete to emphasise what you are saying. He is a complete fool. We are in complete agreement.
adjective If something is complete, there is nothing missing from it. I have a complete set of golf clubs. Are you sure this is a complete list?
adjective If something is complete, it is finished and ready. Can you have the report complete by Friday?
verb If you complete something, you finish it. ~ You bring it to an end. I hope to complete my degree next year.
verb If you complete something, you supply what is missing. You'll need to add a verb to complete the sentence properly.
verb If you complete a form, you write down answers to the questions in the blank spaces provided. Complete this application and mail it to our nearest branch.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun completely I completely agree with you. It's completely ruined now.noun completion

form.definition: adjective If something is complex, it has many different parts that are connected to each other. The complex pattern in this weaving makes it a work of art.
adjective If something is complex, it is difficult to understand. This is a complex matter and it is not obvious who is in the right.
noun A complex is a group of buildings. The shopping complex is on our left. They are building a new resort complex.
noun In informal language, a complex is a state of being excessively concerned or worried about something. She has a complex about her large nose.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun complexity (complexities)

form.definition: noun Your complexion is the colour and the appearance of your skin, especially on your face. Mario has a dark complexion and doesn't burn easily in the sun. This cream should help to heal your spots and improve your complexion.

adjective If something is complicated, it is hard to understand or deal with because there are many things involved. The questions at the end of the exam paper are more complicated. I think Franco's her second cousintheir family tree is very complicated.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun complicate I wish you wouldn't complicate matters by changing your mind all the time!

form.definition: noun If you pay someone a compliment, you say something nice about them. Peter sent his compliments to the chef on the excellent meal.

If you give or send someone something with your compliments, it is a present for them. In view of the mistake over our booking, the waiter offered us a drink while we waited with the compliments of the manager.~ ... WORD FAMILYadjective See complimentary. verb compliment Bob complimented Anne on her organisation of the conference.
adjective A complimentary remark expresses praise or admiration. The critics have been highly complimentary about her first novel.
adjective If something such as a drink or a meal is complimentary, it is free. You do not have to pay for it. Receive a complimentary bottle of wine with each booking for two or more.

verb If you comply with something such as the law, or regulations, or someone's wishes, you obey. You do what you are supposed to. Her entry was disqualified for failing to comply with the rules about size.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun compliance

form.definition: noun A component is any of the parts that go to make up a whole. It can be hard to get the components needed to repair imported cars. Dealing with customers is an important component of this job.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you compose a letter or a poem, you mean that you create it by thinking of the words that form it. I struggled to compose an effective application for the job.
verb If someone composes a piece of music, they create it. It is an original piece of music that hasn't existed before. Beethoven composed nine symphonies.
3 composed of If something is composed of particular things or people, it is made up of them. They are what form it. The class was composed of ten girls and six boys.
4 compose yourself If you compose yourself, you make yourself quiet and calm by a deliberate effort. His widow asked for a moment to compose herself before the press conference.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective composed He appeared noun composer noun composition [bnThey analysed the composition of the substance.noun composure He struggled to regain his composure.

form.definition: noun Compost is a mixture of rotting material, such as vegetable and fruit scraps, leaves and manure, which is piled into a~~compost heap. The heap is then dug into the ground to make the soil richer.

dictionary.entry:
compound`kOmpa:Und for senses 1-3; for sense
noun A compound is an area of land surrounded by a fence and used for a special purpose. He led the prisoners into the compound.
noun In chemistry, a compound is a substance that consists of two or more elements.
adjective In grammar, if something is described as compound, it is made up of two or more words. In I have eaten, the words have eaten are described as a compound verb.
verb In rather formal language, if you say someone or something compounds a problem, you mean that they make it worse. The difficulty of looking after the children was compounded by the bad weather.

comprehendkOmpr@`hEnd verb In formal language, if you say you comprehend something, you mean that you understand it. I just don't comprehend what made her decide to leave. ... WORD FAMILYadjective comprehensible noun comprehension This exercise tests your comprehension of a spoken dialogue.

form.definition: verb If you compress something, you press it or squeeze it so that it takes up less space. I managed to compress another jumper into my suitcase. The pillows are compressed to save room during transport.

verb If you compress something such as a piece of writing, you make it shorter while still keeping the same structure. I originally wrote six pages but I compressed it into three. The previous speaker had gone over time, so he had to compress his presentation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun compression

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say something comprises various other things, you mean that those are the things that form it. It consists of those things. It is composed of them. The unit comprises a lounge room, bedroom, kitchen and bathroom.
verb In rather formal language, if you say various things comprise something else, you mean that together they form it. Poverty and poor health comprise a situation of grave disadvantage.

noun A compromise is an agreement in which both sides accept something that is between what they ~originally wanted and what the other side wanted. Company and union leaders have worked out a compromise to end the strike. The renovations turned out to be a compromise between the architect's ideas and what we could afford.

verb If you compromise, you agree to accept less than you originally wanted. I wanted to leave at eight and Jenny wanted to stay until ten, so we compromised on nine o'clock. You have to be willing to compromise in your dealings with other people.

verb If someone compromises something, they do something which puts it in doubt or danger. We mustn't compromise quality for the sake of saving time. He refused to compromise his art in the interests of commercial success. We would never compromise the children's safety.

noun A compulsion is a strong feeling that you have to do something, even though you know it may be harmful. She suffered from a compulsion to eat vast quantities of food and then vomit. I felt a sudden compulsion to confront him with the truth.

noun Compulsion is forcing someone to do something. There is no compulsion for you to join the health fund, but it offers good benefits. With no element of compulsion, the voluntary code of practice proved unworkable.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See compulsory.

form.definition: adjective If something is compulsory, you have to do it whether you want to or not. You have no choice about it. In Australia voting is compulsory for all citizens.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is optional.

form.definition: verb If you compute something, you calculate it. You work it out using maths. I computed that he'd spent over $1000 on drink over the year.
noun A computer is an electronic machine that can do mathematical calculations and can store, rearrange and give out information very quickly.
noun A comrade is a close friend or companion. All Pierre's old war comrades were at the service.
noun The word comrade is also used to refer to someone who belongs to a socialist or communist party.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun comradeship

form.definition: noun In informal language, a con is a trick where someone deceives you in order to gain something for themselves. Elise gave the man $100, but she later found out that the whole story was a big con. He claimed that his political rivals were guilty of a massive con on the electorate.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb con (con, conned, conning) They conned us into agreeing to help them.

form.definition: adjective If something is concave, it curves inwards. After weeks of starvation, his cheeks were concave.
verb If you conceal something, you hide it. I concealed the letter under a pile of papers when she entered the room. The wallet is concealed in a drawer at the back of the desk.

verb If you conceal something such as facts or emotions, you keep them secret from other people. He was determined to conceal his illness for as long as possible. She seemed evasiveI'm sure she was concealing something. I could conceal my resentment no longer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun concealment

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say someone concedes that something is the case, you mean that they admit it is true. The bank eventually conceded that they had been at fault. I concede that you were right. She refused to concede defeat. We had to concede victory to our opponents.
verb In rather formal language, if you say someone concedes, you mean that they give up. With everyone protesting against her decision, she had no alternative but to concede graciously.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See concession.

form.definition: noun Conceit is too much pride in yourself. Michael's conceit will lose him friends.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See conceited.

form.definition: adjective If someone is conceited, they have a very high opinion of themselves. His successes have made him conceited.

adjective Something that is conceivable is something that you can imagine as being possible. I see no conceivable reason why you can't come. He brought every conceivable document with him. It's just not conceivable that we should fail.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb conceivably

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say someone conceives a plan or idea, you mean that they think of it or invent it. Eric conceived a brilliant way to solve the design problems of the building.
verb If a woman conceives, she becomes pregnant. Samira is having tests to see why she hasn't conceived. Their first child was conceived on their honeymoon.

3 conceive of In rather formal language, if you say you conceive of something in a certain way, you mean that you imagine it that way. I'd always conceived of her mother as elderly, but in fact she was quite young. I can't conceive of a single instance where I could approve of your behaviour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See conceivable. noun See conception.

form.definition: verb If you concentrate, you give all your attention to a particular matter. You do not let yourself be distracted. Be quiet, I'm trying to concentrate.

verb If you concentrate on something, you make a special effort in dealing with it. In this exercise I want you to concentrate on your pronunciation. The course covers the whole range of literature, but it concentrates on the twentieth century.
noun A concentrate is a substance that has been made stronger by removing liquid from it. I made up a litre of orange juice from the frozen concentrate.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun concentration

form.definition: noun A concept is an abstract idea. Bill finds certain maths concepts difficult to understand.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective conceptual

form.definition: noun Your conception of something is the way you imagine it or think about it. I had only a vague conception of what Australia would be like. He has a very definite conception of how children should behave. The experience altered my conceptions about justice.
noun Conception is the act of conceiving a child.
noun Concern is worry or anxiety that you feel about something. Please don't be upsetthere's no cause for concern.
verb If something concerns you, it worries you or makes you anxious. His casual attitude to work concerns me greatly.
noun If something is your concern, ~you are responsible for doing it. It's my concern to see that we meet the schedule and budget. Issuing the invoices is not my concern.

verb If something concerns you, it is relevant to you or involves you. This issue concerns us all, and we should have a say in the matter. In this case, the parties concerned were able to reach a compromise.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective concerned He was very concerned when she failed to return.

form.definition: preposition Concerning is a formal word for about. Do you have any questions concerning the procedure? I would like to speak to you concerning a personal matter.
noun A concert is a performance of music. We went to a concert at the Opera House.

2 in concert In formal language, if you say people do something in concert, you mean that they do it as part of a shared plan. The major insurance companies were accused of acting in concert to raise premiums.
noun A concession is something that you agree to, even though you don't really want to, usually in order to end an argument. In the end, both parties made concessions.

noun A concession is also something that is agreed to or allowed because of particular circumstances. As a special concession, the children were allowed to stay up and watch the movie. I let Felix sit down, as a concession to his age.
noun A concession is also a reduced price or fare that is charged to people such as school children or pensioners. ADMISSION $5; $3 CONCESSIONS

dictionary.entry: conciliationk@nsIli:`EIS@n noun Conciliation is a way of working out disagreements by encouraging communication and removing distrust between opposite sides. ... WORD FAMILYverb conciliate She attempted to conciliate the rival factions.adjective conciliatory It seems that their offer is a conciliatory gesture.

form.definition: adjective If something is expressed in a concise way, it is expressed effectively without using any unnecessary words. This brochure is concise and gives all the information a tourist would want. Try to be more concise in your explanations.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb concisely

form.definition: verb If you conclude that something is the case, you decide or deduce from the facts or evidence that it is so. Am I right in concluding from your grumpiness that you don't want to come?

verb In formal language, if you say someone concludes something such as a speech, you mean that they bring it to an end. The chairman concluded his report on an optimistic note. And to conclude, I should like to thank you all for coming here tonight.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun conclusion I formed the conclusion that he resented her. The opera neared its conclusion.adjective conclusive There is no conclusive proof that she was involved.

form.definition: noun Concrete is a building material made from a mixture of cement, sand, small stones and water.
adjective If something is concrete, it has physical existence. It is something you can see and touch.

adjective If something is concrete, it is definite. It is not vague. We've had quite a lot of interest in the house, but no concrete offers. He offered sympathy, but no concrete suggestions about what I could do.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb concrete They concreted the drive.

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say you concur with someone, you mean that you agree with them. I concur with you on that point. The judges concurred in awarding Simon first prize.

dictionary.entry: concurrentk@N`kV r@nt adjective If two or more events are concurrent, they occur at the same time. The two projects will be concurrent and will share some personnel. ... WORD FAMILYnoun concurrence adverb concurrently

form.definition: noun If you suffer from concussion, you are dazed for a while after a heavy blow to your head. He was taken to hospital suffering from shock and concussion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb concuss The blow concussed her.

form.definition: verb If you condemn someone or something, you strongly express your disapproval of them. The premier condemned the demonstrators.
verb If a local authority condemns ~a building, they state officially that it is no longer allowed to be used. The council condemned the old bakery because it had become dangerous.
verb If a court condemns someone who has been charged with an offence, the person is found guilty.
verb A prisoner found guilty of a serious crime is condemned or sentenced to a severe punishment such as death or life imprisonment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun condemnation/kndmnen/

form.definition: noun Condensation is the changing of a gas to a liquid. It is what happens when a window or mirror mists up because small particles of water vapour have turned to liquid on its surface. She wiped the condensation from the glass.
verb If you condense something, you make it more compact in structure. The editor asked him to condense the article because it was too long.
verb If a liquid has been condensed, it has been made thicker by removing water from it. This soup is condensedyou have to add an equal quantity of water when you heat it. ...condensed milk.
verb If a gas condenses, it changes into a liquid.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See condensation.

form.definition: verb If someone condescends to do something, they do it even though they think that they are really too grand or important for it. You often use this word sarcastically. It's not often that the boss condescends to have a drink with us.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective condescending She agreed to help me, but she was very condescending about it.

form.definition: noun The condition of a person or thing is the good or bad state that they are in. By exercising regularly, you will soon reach top condition. The house was in a poor condition when we moved in.

noun The conditions under which something is done are the circumstances that exist at the time and that affect it. He's starting a business under the worst possible conditionsthere's a recession, interest rates are high, and his wife is sick.
noun A condition is something that must happen or be true if another thing is to happen or be done. You ~may go to the party but the condition is that you promise to be home early.

4 on condition that If you agree to do something on condition that something else happens, you are only willing to do it if that thing does happen. I'll help you with the move, on condition that we finish by five o'clock. Management agreed to talks on condition that the strike was called off.

adjective If someone is conditioned to the way things are, they are now used to it and don't notice the circumstances. At first it was hard, but now I'm conditioned to getting up at dawn. We'll send the team to Africa early, so they'll be conditioned to the heat when the competition starts.
noun A condom is a contraceptive made of rubber which is worn on the penis during sexual intercourse.

verb In rather formal language, if you say someone condones something bad that is done, you mean that they accept it or excuse it. I cannot condone your behaviour. Surely you do not seek to condone such irresponsibility? In view of the circumstances I am prepared to condone your lateness.

dictionary.entry:
conductk@n`dV kt for the verb; for the noun,
verb In rather formal language, if you say you conduct an activity or task, you mean that you organise it or run it. Prof. Kramer is conducting a seminar on the history of the English language. They conducted a survey of people's opinions. What experiment could you conduct to prove this?
verb When someone conducts an orchestra, they direct the performance by standing in front of the players and signalling to them.
verb In formal language, if you say you conduct someone somewhere, you mean that you go there with them and lead the way. You escort them. The guide conducted us on a tour of the city. The waiter will conduct you to your table.
verb If something conducts heat or electricity, it acts as a channel for it. Metals conduct heat efficiently. Rubber does not conduct electricity.
noun Someone's conduct is their good or bad behaviour. His conduct at the party was unacceptable.
noun The conduct of something is the way it is run or managed. There is to be an inquiry into the conduct ~of the business.
6 conduct yourself If you conduct yourself in a particular way, that is how you behave. I was appalled by the way he conducted himself at the party. She conducted herself with great dignity in difficult circumstances.
... WORD FAMILYnoun conductor Who is the conductor at tonight's concert? ...a lightning conductor.[qr

form.definition: noun A cone is a solid figure with a flat round shape at one end and a point at the other.
noun Anything shaped like this is called a cone. I bought some ice-cream cones at the supermarket.
noun Confectionery is lollies and sweets in general.

verb When people confer, they talk to each other and discuss what to do about a particular situation. I must confer with my wife before accepting an offer that involves relocation. There will be an interval while the judges confer, and the winner will be announced shortly.

verb In formal language, if you say that someone or something confers something on someone, you mean that they grant or bestow it. Degrees are conferred on successful students in the Great Hall of the university. Winning the award confers great prestige.
noun A conference is an event involving lectures and discussions on a particular topic. Doctors from all over the world came to Sydney to attend a medical conference on the liver.

2 in conference If someone is in conference, they are attending a formal meeting. The minister was in conference with her advisors for three hours. 'May I speak to Mr Pappas?' 'I'm afraid he's in conferencecan I take a message?'
verb If you confess, you admit that you have done something wrong. Eventually Johnny confessed that he had broken the window. The suspect confessed as soon as he was brought to the police station.
verb If you confess that something is the case, you state it rather apologetically. I confess I've never liked Brahms. It's ~rather chilly in here, I confess, but I'll put the heater on.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun confession[xp\start\~[ap--confide

form.definition: verb If you confide information to someone, you tell them something that you don't want other people to know. You expect them to keep it a secret and not tell anyone else. He confided the date of the wedding only to his closest friends.

2 confide in If you confide in someone, you tell them about your private problems or secrets. She seemed upset and asked if she could confide in me. It is important for children to have someone they can confide in.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See confidence.

form.definition: noun Confidence is a feeling of self-assurance. She's so full of confidence she can speak without notes.
noun Confidence is also trusting someone and being sure of them. I have complete confidence in Jack's ability to do the job.
noun A confidence is a secret that is not to be told to anyone else. He's very careful who he shares his confidences with.
4 in confidence If someone tells you something in confidence, they trust you not to tell anyone else. This is in confidenceI don't want anyone else to know.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See confidential.

form.definition: adjective If you are confident, you are sure of yourself. You know that you are skilled and that you are not likely to make a mistake. Selina gave a confident performance in the lead role. You should be more confident about your abilities. He is a confident and outgoing child.

adjective If you are confident that something is the case, you are fairly sure that it is true. I'm confident that we'll get there in time. Are you confident the bag was still there when you left? He won't let us down, I'm confident of that.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun confidence

form.definition: adjective If something is confidential, it is secret or private and should not be openly discussed. The files were marked HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL.

adjective A confidential secretary is someone who can be trusted with secrets or private matters. The Prime Minister asked his confidential secretary to sit in on the meeting.~ ... WORD FAMILYnoun confidentiality He passed details to a journalist on condition of confidentiality.adverb confidentially She asked me confidentially what I thought of Teresa's work.
verb If you confine something, you keep it within certain limits. They decided to confine the survey to interviewing recent migrants. We must find some way to confine the amount of work required.
verb If someone is confined in a certain place, they are kept or detained there. The illegal immigrants are confined in an old army camp. It's terrible to be confined indoors on such a lovely day.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun confinement

form.definition: verb If something confirms what you already thought or suspected, it proves that you were right. My fears were confirmed when he returned without the car.

verb If you confirm arrangements, you state that you will definitely go ahead with them. I've booked a room, but I have to confirm it within three days. This is to confirm your promotion to senior sales associate with effect from 1st March.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun confirmation

form.definition: verb If someone in authority confiscates something, they take it and keep it. Customs officers confiscated the illegally imported whisky. The teacher confiscated Bart's whistle till the end of term.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun confiscation

dictionary.entry:
conflict`kOnflIkt for the noun; for the verb,
noun A conflict is an argument or fight with someone. There have been frequent conflicts on the issue between members of the board of directors. The tension between the countries may escalate into armed conflict.
verb If one thing conflicts with another, it disagrees with it. The press report of the demonstration conflicts with what I witnessed.

form.definition: verb If you conform, you behave in the way that people expect or require of you. You'll never be happy at work if you refuse to conform. He refused to conform with the club's dress rules.

verb If something conforms to something else, it fits in with it. The job didn't conform to my expectations. The real estate agent sent a list of properties conforming to my requirements.~ ... WORD FAMILYnoun conformity

verb If you confront someone about something, you speak to them openly about a matter over which you are in conflict. The boss confronted Joanna with the fact that the money was missing. Marco tried to lie, until his mother confronted him with the evidence.

verb If something confronts you, you are faced with a difficult or unpleasant situation and you have to deal with it. First let's consider the problems confronting us. I opened the door and was confronted by a terrible mess.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun confrontation

form.definition: verb If you confuse things, you mistake one for the other. I often confuse Peter with his brotherthey look so much alike. Be careful not to confuse the past tense and the past participle.

verb If someone or somethingconfuses you, they make you feel puzzled or mixed up. The more she tried to explain, the more she confused me. He was confused by the one-way system and drove five kilometres in the wrong direction.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective confused I'm still a bit confused about what he wants. She gave a confused reply.adjective confusing The instructions are rather confusing I can't work out what to do first.noun confusion I stared at him in confusion. One box went missing in the confusion of moving.

form.definition: adjective If a road or an entry is congested, it is full of cars or people, so that it is very difficult to get through. It can take an hour and a half to drive to work on these congested roads.
adjective If your lungs or sinuses become congested when you have a cold, they become blocked with mucus.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun congestion

form.definition: verb If youcongratulate someone, you tell them how pleased you are that they have done well or that something good has happened to them. I congratulated Dick on the birth of his daughter. Don't forget to congratulate Eva for passing her exams.
form.note: ... NOTEA common way of doing this is to say 'Congratulations!'.

form.definition: verb If peoplecongregate somewhere, they gather there in large numbers. A crowd was beginning to congregate at the scene of the accident. Students congregate in this cheap and friendly cafe.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See congregation.

form.definition: noun Acongregation is the group of people gathered in a church for a religious service.

noun A congress is a large meeting or series of meetings, held over several days, to discuss a particular topic. My doctor is away at a medical congress. Delegates from twelve countries attended the peace congress.
form.note: ... A SIMILAR WORDto this is conference.

form.definition: noun In grammar, a conjunction is a word such as and or but which joins parts of a sentence.
2 in conjunction with If you do something in conjunction with someone else, you do it together with them. The architects have worked in conjunction with this firm of builders before.
nounConjunctivitis is an infection of the eye. It makes the white part of your eye look pink or bloodshot.
verb If someone conjures something, they make it appear as if by magic. The magician conjured three rabbits out of his hat. These words are supposed to conjure the spirits of the dead.
