2 conjure up (a) If you conjure something up, you produce it suddenly or unexpectedly. He conjured up a marvellous meal from what happened to be in the fridge. You can't expect them to conjure up the funds at such short notice.

(b) If you conjure someone or something up, you bring them to mind. You remember them or you imagine them. I remember the name, but I can't conjure up his face. The writer has conjured up a rich fantasy world. The word 'family' conjures up visions of cosy domestic life.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun conjurer We hired a conjurer for the children's party.

form.definition: verb If you connect two things, you join them together or link them. Connect this hose to the tap. The new train service will connect Sydney with the Gold Coast. I can't work out how these pieces connect.

2 connected ~with If something is connected with something else, the two things are related in some way. Often one is the cause of the other. It's been proved that smoking is connected with lung cancer. I suspected that his concern for me was connected with Lara's resignation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun connection

form.definition: verb If one country conquers another, it defeats it in battle or a war. The Allies conquered Germany in World War II.
verb If you conquer something, you manage to overcome it, usually with an effort. Ellie seems to have conquered her fear of heights.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun conqueror

form.definition: noun Your conscience is what makes you feel guilty if you do something wrong or bad. My conscience won't allow me to tell a lie. His conscience was troubling him. I've got a bad conscience about neglecting her.
adjective If you are conscientious, you are always very careful to do good work. Tom is too conscientious to leave a job unfinished.

adjective If you areconscious of something, you are aware of it. He was conscious that she was looking at him. I'm very conscious that I could have done more to help. I became conscious of their hostility towards me.
2 adjective If you are conscious, you are awake. You are not in a coma or asleep. The victim was conscious and in great pain.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun consciousness

dictionary.entry:
conscript`kOnskrIpt for the noun; for the verb k@n`skrIpt
noun A conscript is someone who is compelled to serve in the armed forces of their country. They have no choice.
... WORD FAMILYverb conscript He was conscripted into the army.noun conscription The Australian people voted against conscription in 1916 and 1917.

form.definition: adjective If things are consecutive, one directly follows the other in order. There is nothing else of the same kind in between them. The group decided to meet on five consecutive Mondays. This is the third consecutive day the bus has been late.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb consecutively

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say you consent to something, you mean that you allow it or give your permission for it to happen. Did you consent to this man borrowing your car? He claimed that she had consented to sex. They may not enter the house unless you consent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun consent I gave my consent to her request. It was done without his consent.

form.definition: noun Aconsequence is something that happens because of something else. It is the result of the other thing. Jane's illness was the consequence of working too hard. As a consequence of bad weather the show was cancelled. You insisted on leavingnow you must take the consequences.

noun In rather formal language, if you say something is of consequence, you mean that it is important or significant. Don't apologiseit's of no consequence. He seems to be a man of some consequence. Did I miss anything of consequence at the meeting?
noun Conservation is the preservation and protection of nature and of historic buildings. The public has become increasingly aware of the importance of conservation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun conservationist

form.definition: adjective If you are conservative, you like the old way of doing things. You do not like sudden change. His policies are sure to attract the conservative vote.
adjective If you are conservative in what you do or wear, you are very moderate and conventional. He won't wear that red shirthe's far too conservative.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun conservatism

form.definition: verb If you conserve something, you use it carefully and try not to waste it. We should all try to conserve energy. We huddled close together to conserve heat.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See conservation.

form.definition: verb If you consider something, you think carefully about it. I'm considering whether to accept the job offer. He considered a moment before replying. It's time to consider your options.

verb If you consider someone, you bear them in mind and think about how they will be affected by what you do. Don't just help yourself to the best fruit without considering other people! 3 ~verb If you consider someone or something in a certain way, that is what you think or believe about them. I've always considered him a fool. She considered the whole thing to be a waste of time. Only 40% of those surveyed considered that the Prime Minister was doing a good job.

4 considering You use considering to mention the facts that are relevant to an assessment of something. Emine did very well, considering how little time she had to practise. The weather was terrible, but we attracted quite a large audience, considering.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See considerate. noun See consideration.

form.definition: adjective If something is considerable, it is fairly great in amount or degree. We've had a considerable increase in orders recently. His mark is a considerable improvement over last year's result.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb considerably

form.definition: adjective If someone is considerate, they are kind and thoughtful. It was very considerate of you to offer Emma a lift.
nounConsideration is thinking carefully about something. I will give this matter my full consideration. After careful consideration of the facts, we have decided to grant permission.
noun Consideration is also the attention that you give to the needs and rights of other people. He showed absolutely no consideration for my feelings.

noun A consideration is some fact or circumstance that should be taken into account in making a decision. Our most important consideration must be the welfare of the child. He claimed that the committee has overlooked an important consideration.

4 take into consideration If you take something intoconsideration, you bear it in mind when you decide something, because it is important or relevant to the matter. But surely you took the school holidays into consideration when you fixed the dates?

verb If something consists of various other things, it is made up of them. They go together to form it. The cocktail consists of vodka, rum and orange juice. The committee consists of the chairman, secretary, treasurer and five other members.
noun Theconsistency of a liquid is how thick or runny it is, whether it is smooth or has lumps in it, and so on. Stir the mixture until it reaches a fairly firm consistency.
noun Consistency is always acting or thinking in the same way. His public comments on the affair show a certain lack of consistency.

adjective If someone is consistent, they always act or think in the same way. When you discipline children it's important to be consistent. When he's in form he's an excellent player, but he's not consistent.
2 consistent with If one thing is consistent with another, it agrees with it. Her latest explanation is not consistent with what she said earlier.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See consistency.

form.definition: noun A consolation is something that makes you feel better when you are upset. Her support was a consolation to him. It was some consolation to know that I wasn't the only one with the problem. I could offer her no consolation in her distress.
2 consolation prize You sometimes win a consolation prize in a competition if you don't win one of the main prizes but you still do well. As a consolation prize I got six table napkins.

verb If you console someone, you comfort them because they are upset about something. I bent to console the sobbing child. There is little I can say to console you. The fact that he'd done his best consoled him slightly.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See consolation.

form.definition: noun A consonant is a speech sound which obstructs the flow of air through your mouth, or a letter of the alphabet that stands for such a sound.
form.note: ... COMPARE THIS WORDwith vowel.

form.definition: adjective If something is conspicuous, it is very noticeable, often because it is different from other things. You'll recognise his car by the conspicuous orange stripes down the side. He felt a bit conspicuous in a track suit when all the other men were wearing business suits.
noun A conspiracy is a secret plan by a group of people to do something illegal. Police officers have uncovered a conspiracy to import vast quantities of heroin.

noun A ~conspiracy is also an agreement by a group of people to act together against the interests of another group or person. We both voted against her re-election but not as a result of any conspiracy between us.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun conspirator verb conspire

form.definition: noun A constable is a police officer of the lowest rank.
adjective If something is constant, it goes on and on without stopping. It is continuous. The rain has been constant for three days now. I'm sick of her constant criticism.
2 adjective If something is constant, it is steady or unchanging. It does not vary. The wheel rotates at a constant speed.

adjective In formal language, if you say someone is constant, you mean that they are loyal and faithful. He was a constant friend to me through many difficult times. She suspected that he had not been constant during their separation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb constantly The kids are constantly fighting.

form.definition: noun Aconstellation is a group of stars.
nounConsternation is great shock and surprise. The whole school was thrown into consternation when the headmaster died suddenly. Imagine my consternation when she told me she was leaving immediately!
noun Constipation is the medical term for the condition someone has if they can't empty their bowels regularly. These tablets are designed to relieve constipation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective constipated

form.definition: noun If you are elected or appointed to an important job, your constituency is the people you represent or the people you look after. He belongs to a conservation group which has a very wide constituency.
form.note: ... NOTEthat this is the word used in British English to mean electorate. ... WORD FAMILYnoun constituent

form.definition: noun A country's constitution is the body of laws and principles which define how it is governed and the rights and duties of its citizens.~ ... WORD FAMILYadjective constitutional
verb If you constrict something, you make it narrow or tight. This collar is very uncomfortableit's constricting my neck.
If you constrict someone, you limit what they are able or allowed to do. He felt constricted in his new environment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun constriction

form.definition: verb If you construct something, you build it or you make it by putting it together. They've been constructing that bridge for two years. The furniture is sold in pieces, and you have to construct it yourself. She constructed an elaborate lie to save herself.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun construction

form.definition: adjective If something is constructive, it is helpful or useful. He made several constructive suggestions about what I should do. If you can't be constructive, don't come to the meeting.

noun A consul is an official who works overseas as a representative of their country. Consuls do not rank as highly as ambassadors, and some do their work without pay. She spent three years in Montreal as the Australian consul.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective consular noun consulate I phoned the British consulate in Sydney.

form.definition: verb If you consult someone, you talk to them about something and ask for their opinion or advice. I can't agree to change jobs without consulting my family. We consulted an architect before we started our renovations. That's a nasty coughyou should consult a doctor.
2 verb If you consult something such as a book, you refer to it for information. I will have to consult my notes before I can answer that question. He consulted his watch and hurried out of the room.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun consultation

form.definition: noun A consultant is an expert who gives advice. Usually they do not work full time for one company or on one project. They hired a management consultant to look at their work practices.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun consultancy

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you say you consume something, you mean that you eat or drink it. The guests consumed five ~dozen bottles of beer at the party.

verb If someone or something consumes something such as time, energy, or fuel, it uses it up. My studies consume a good deal of my free time. A fluorescent tube consumes much less electricity than a conventional globe.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See consumer. noun consumption I reduced my consumption of fat. This car has excellent fuel consumption.

form.definition: noun A consumer is anyone who uses goods or services. Computer retailers are becoming more aware of the needs of consumers.
noun Contact is the touching of two things. There is friction at the point of contact.
noun Contact is also communication and meeting between people. She's had no contact with her family for years. I'm still in contact with several people I went to college with.
verb If you contact someone, you get in touch with them by telephone, letter or so on. I'll contact you as soon as I get the results. During the day I can be contacted on this number.
noun A contact is someone you know who can be helpful to you. She got the information from one of her contacts in CSIRO.
5 contact lens Contact lenses are small plastic lenses that some people put in their eyes instead of wearing glasses.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is contacts.

form.definition: adjective If a disease is contagious, it is spread from one person to another by direct contact. Hepatitis is a highly contagious disease.
verb If something contains something else, it has that thing inside it. This bottle contains a dangerous poison. The library contains thousands of books.
verb If something contains something else, it has it as one of its parts or ingredients. The book contains exercises and an index as well as the main text. This orange juice contains no added sugar.

contain yourself If you contain yourself, you stop yourself from doing something or showing your real feelings. I longed to hug her, but I managed to contain myself. He could contain himself no longer and burst into tears.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See container.

form.definition: noun A container is anything that holds something. I was looking for a suitable container for the beads. Why don't you pour some of it into another container?
noun A container is also a very large crate for transporting goods on ships, trains or trucks.
verb If something contaminates something else, it makes it dirty or impure. The chemical factory contaminated the creek with toxic waste.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun contamination

form.definition: verb If youcontemplate something, you look at it or think about it carefully for a long time. We sat for a long while, peacefully contemplating the scenery.
verb If you contemplate doing something, you think that you may do it. I'm contemplating a trip to Europe next year. I hope you're not contemplating coming indoors in those muddy boots!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun contemplation adjective contemplative He was lost in contemplative silence.

form.definition: adjective If something is contemporary, it is modern. It exists or is happening now. She chose a fabric with a contemporary design for her new lounge. He's one of the most famous contemporary composers. b adjective If something is contemporary with something else, it exists or happens at the same period of time. Contrary to science fiction movies, the dinosaurs were not contemporary with human beings. The political climate in Australia was influenced by contemporary events in Europe.
2 noun If someone is your contemporary, they live or do something at the same period of time as you. Bach and Handel were contemporaries. I know him wellhe was a contemporary of mine at college.

noun If you feelcontempt for someone or something, you despise them. You dislike them and think that they are insignificant or bad. I have nothing but contempt for youyou're a liar and a cheat. She looked at him with contempt. He tossed the coins onto the table with contempt.

2 beneath yourcontempt If you say that someone or something is beneath contempt or beneath your contempt, you mean that you feel so much contempt for ~them that you don't even want to think about them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective contemptible He's a contemptible person.adjective contemptuous She gave a contemptuous laugh.

form.definition: verb If you have to contend with something such as a problem or difficulty, you have to deal with it. He's had much to contend with in lifehis wife has been sick for years and his son is a criminal.

verb If you contend something, you state firmly that it is true, although other people argue that it is not. She still contends that she wasn't speeding when the police officer booked her for 110 km per hour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun contention His contention is that the plan will save money.

dictionary.entry:
content`kOntEnt for sense 1; for sense 2,k@n`tEnt
noun The content or contents of something is what is contained in it. This cheese has a very high fat content. She emptied the contents of her handbag onto the table.
noun The content or contents of something such as a letter or book is the information contained in it. She took notes on the content of the lectures. After reading the contents of the letter he threw it away. I consulted the table of contents at the front of the book.
2 adjective If you are content, you are satisfied with the way things are. Her life is simple but she seems content.
... WORD FAMILYadjective contented She gave a contented smile.

contest`kOntEst for sense 1; for senses 2-3,k@n`tEst
noun A contest is a competition. Our school came third in the science contest. l[rp$50 000 to be won in our free contest.
noun A contest is also a struggle to win power. He won the contest to be the next leader of the party.
verb If you contest something, you try to win it. She contested the seat of Lowe at the federal election. The championship has been keenly contested this year.
verb If you contest something, you formally object to it. You state that it is untrue or unfair. He contested the accusations that had been made against him. She contested her father's will on the grounds that it made inadequate provision for her as a dependent.~ ... BE CAREFULwith the pronunciation of this word: the noun is pronounced differently from the verb. ... WORD FAMILY
k@n`tEst@nt

form.definition: noun The context of something is all the circumstances that accompany it. His actions must be judged in the context of their desperate situation. The phrase is often used in a financial context.

2 out of context If something such as a remark is taken out of context, it is presented and interpreted on its own without considering the particular circumstances. You have misunderstood her because you have quoted her words out of context.
noun A continent is one of the main land masses of the world, such as Australia, Asia, Europe, Africa, North and South America and the Antarctic.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective continental

form.definition: adjective You say something is continual if it happens repeatedly, over and over again. It's hard to get anything done with these continual interruptions.
form.note: ... A SIMILAR WORDis continuous, which refers to something that does not stop. ... WORD FAMILYadverb continually She's continually complaining about her family.

form.definition: verb If something continues, it keeps on. It doesn't stop. The strike continued into a third week. We continued our conversation late into the night. If the pain continues, you should consult a doctor.
verb If something continues, it starts again after being interrupted. The serial continues next Sunday. We'll have to continue this conversation another time.

verb If you continue when you are going somewhere, you keep moving in a particular direction. Continue along here to the crossroads, then turn right. The flight stops in Bangkok and continues to Sydney.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun continuation We were all looking forward to the continuation of his story.adjective continued Mira was disciplined for her continued failure to meet targets.adjective continuing Termite infestation has been a continuing problem in these units.

form.definition: adjective If something is continuous, it keeps on without stopping. The rain has been continuous for over eight hours. Can ~you connect these points with a continuous line that doesn't cross over itself?
form.note: ... A SIMILAR WORDis continual, which refers to something that happens repeatedly.

form.definition: adjective In grammar, a continuous tense shows that the action takes place over a period of time instead of all at once. It is formed by the verb be and the present participle of the main verb, e.g. 'I am reading', 'He was washing the car'.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb continuously

form.definition: noun The contours of something are its outer shape or outline. We could make out the contours of the building through the mist. The blind woman traced the contours of my face with her fingers.
noun A contour is a line drawn on a map which joins points of equal height. On this map the contours are drawn at fifty metre intervals.

noun Contraband is goods that are moved from one country to another secretly and illegally, usually to avoid paying duties or taxes. He was arrested for dealing in contraband. Customs officers seized a vast haul of contraband.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective contraband ...contraband whisky.

form.definition: nounContraception is taking measures to avoid pregnancy.
noun Acontraceptive is something that is used to prevent a woman from becoming pregnant as a result of sexual intercourse, such as a condom or a diaphragm.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective contraceptive ...a contraceptive device.

dictionary.entry:
contract`kOntrAkt for sense 1; for sense 2, k@n`trAkt
noun A contract is a formal legal agreement, usually in writing, between two people sibilities of each party. Unfair contracts of employment can be overruled by the courts. Our company won the contract to build the new bridge.
verb If you contract to do something, you sign a formal legal agreement stating that you will do it. The builders have contracted to repair the damage within ninety days.
verb When something contracts, it becomes smaller and tighter. The muscle contracts ~when it is electrically stimulated. The economy is contracting.
... WORD FAMILYnoun contraction Observe the contraction of the muscle tissue.

form.definition: verb If you contradict someone, you say the opposite to what they have just said. Stop contradicting me all the time!

verb If two reports contradict each other, they give opposite or different accounts of something. These findings have been contradicted by more recent research. The video evidence contradicted the witness's statement.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun contradiction. adjective contradictory

dictionary.entry:
contrary`kOntr@ri:; <but for sense 2,> /\times,0\kntreri/ 1 adjective Contrary ideas or opinions are completely different or opposite to each other. He has always held contrary views to my own. They published letters giving many contrary points of view. We set off in contrary directions and agreed to meet for
adjective If someone is contrary, they are awkward and difficult to get on with. He's always been a contrary sort of person but now he's actually impossible. Why do you have to be so contrary about the arrangements?
... NOTEthat this sense has a pronunciation different from the others. 3 contrary to You use contrary to to show that what happens is completely different or opposite to what is expected or what someone else says. Contrary to all expectations, I managed to pass my exams. Contrary to Ken's pessimism, we exceeded our target for the year.
4 on or to the contrary You use on the contrary or to the contrary to emphasise that what you say is the exact opposite of some other statement. 'Didn't you hate the movie?' 'On the contrary, I loved it.' We expected sales to decline, but on the contrary they rose. Thea lost money, but our experience has been to the contrary.

form.definition: noun A contrast is a great difference between things. What a contrast between the two brothersone so dark and the other so fair. You can adjust the brightness with this control and the contrast with this one.

verb If two things contrast, they are very different from each other. His cheerfulness contrasted with her despondency. The red carpet contrasts strongly with the blue walls. What you say now contrasts with your earlier opinion.

verb If you contrast things, you compare them to show the differences between them. The exam question asked us to contrast the economies of any two Asian countries. The chairman contrasted the strong showing of his own company with the struggles of his rivals.

4 in contrast You use in contrast to emphasise that two things are very different. Their house in Sydney, in contrast to the one in the mountains, is large and modern. It rained all weekend, but Monday in contrast was bright and sunny.

verb If you contribute to something, you join with other people in donating money or work in order to bring about a certain result. Have you asked Gary to contribute to Helen's present? If we each contribute $10 we'll have enough. He thanked the organising committee for contributing so much time and effort.
verb If something contributes to an event, it is one of the factors which cause it. His wife's sickness contributed to his breakdown. High franchise fees contributed to the failure of the business.
verb If you contribute to a newspaper or magazine, you write articles which are published in it. Jake has been contributing to the society newsletter for years.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun contribution noun contributor

form.definition: noun If you control someone or something, you have power or influence over them and make decisions about what is to happen. She has no opinions of her ownher husband controls her completely. The opposite bank of the river is controlled by the enemy. I was appointed to control our export campaign.

verb If you control someone or something, you manage to make them behave as you wish. The children run wildtheir parents just don't control them. It took me a while to learn how to control the horse. You can control the speed with this knob.

noun Control is power or influence over a situation. It is being in a position to decide what is done. The company was in difficulties until the new manager took control. Control of the country will pass to the civilian government next month.

noun Control ~is also being able to make things happen as you wish. She managed the whole operation with effortless control. He lost control of the car and crashed into a telegraph pole. I was so angry that I nearly lost control and hit the child.

noun A control is a device that allows you to adjust something such as the temperature, speed or size of something. The pilot was sitting at the controls. I never use half of the controls on my video recorder.
6 control yourself If you control yourself, you make yourself act in a calm way even though you are angry or upset. Try to control yourself, there's no point in getting hysterical.

7 out of control If something or someone is out of control, it is impossible to influence what they do. The fire was raging out of control. These kids are completely out of controlthey don't accept any kind of authority.
8 under control If something is under control, it is being dealt with in a suitable way. The fire is still burning, but it's under control. Are the catering arrangements all under control?

dictionary.entry:
controversy`kOntr@v@:si:, k@n`trOv@si: (plural forms\optima0\controversies
noun A controversy is an argument about something because of a difference of opinion. The controversy occupied the letters page of the paper for weeks. Both parties were keen to avoid open controversy. There is controversy among experts about the date of the vase.
... WORD FAMILYadjective controversial It's a controversial topic.

form.definition: noun Convalescence is the period that someone spends gradually building up their strength again after they have been sick. He'll need a long convalescence after such major surgery.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb convalesce She went back to her parents' home to convalesce.

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you convene a meeting, you arrange it. I asked Margaret to convene a meeting of the department heads.
noun Convenience is the state of being convenient or suitable. The furniture is packed flat for convenience of transport.
noun A convenience is a public toilet. Ladies conveniences are situated on the third floor.

3 at your convenience In formal language, if someone asks you to do something at your convenience, ~they mean that it is not very urgent. If they ask you to do it at your earliest convenience, this is a polite way of asking you to do it as soon as possible.
adjective If something is convenient, it suits your needs. Is this a convenient time to talk or are you busy? The sticky tape comes in a convenient dispenser.
adjective If something is convenient, it is near or easy to reach. Our house is convenient to the shops and to public transport.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See convenience.

form.definition: noun A convent is a group of buildings where nuns live.
noun A convent is also a school run by nuns. Both her daughters go to the local convent.
noun Convention is generally accepted standards of social behaviour. She defied convention by wearing pyjamas to the office.
noun A convention is also a large meeting of delegates. She's attending a medical convention at Perth University.
form.note: ... SIMILAR WORDSto this are conference and congress. ... WORD FAMILYadjective See conventional.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is conventional, they abide by generally accepted standards of social behaviour. Do you have to be so conventional?

adjective If something is conventional, it is the usual sort of thing, in contrast with something new or different. These dishes can be used both in microwaves and in conventional ovens. This new system offers much greater efficiency than conventional solar heating.

noun If you have a conversation with someone, you talk with them about something. Tony and Maria seem to be having a serious conversation. After spending all day with the kids I was desperate for some adult conversation.

dictionary.entry:
converse`kOnv@:s for the noun; for the verb,k@n`v@:s
noun In formal language, the converse of something is its opposite. I believe the converse to be true, in fact.
verb In formal language, if you say you converse with someone, you mean that you talk to them. You have a conversation ~with them. I can read Korean quite well now, but I still can't converse fluently.

convertk@n`v@:t for the verb; for the noun,`kOnv@:t
verb If you convert something, you change it from being one thing into another. I converted $300 into Thai currency. This lounge converts easily into a bed for visitors.
verb If you convert someone to your religion, you persuade them to follow the same religion as you. Missionaries were sent to convert the local people. b verb If you convert someone, you make them change their opinion about something so that they have the same opinion as you. I like smokingdon't try to convert me.
noun A convert is someone who has changed their religion or their opinion about something. In his forties he became a convert to Islam. I used not to like health food, but now I'm a convert.
... WORD FAMILYnoun See convertible. noun conversion adjective convertible

form.definition: noun A convertible is a car with a roof that you can fold back or remove in fine weather.
adjective If something is convex, it curves so that it bulges out in the middle.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is concave.

form.definition: verb If something conveys a certain emotion or impression, it makes you feel it or understand it in your mind. I tried to convey a sense of urgency to the meeting. The word 'summer' conveys happy memories. He claims to know me, but his name doesn't convey anything to me.
verb In formal language, if you say you convey something somewhere, you mean that you transport it. The packages will be conveyed to your premises by express delivery.

dictionary.entry:
convictk@n`vIkt for the verb; for the noun,
verb If someone is convicted of a crime, they are found guilty of it. She was convicted of manslaughter and received a four-year prison term.
noun A convict is a prisoner, especially one from the early days of Australian settlement.
... WORD FAMILYnoun See conviction.

form.definition: noun A conviction is a strong belief in something. It is my conviction that the company can be profitable. He insisted ~that he could manage, and I was unable to shake him in his conviction.
noun A conviction is also an occasion of being found guilty of a crime. The prisoner had no previous convictions. This was her fourth conviction for shoplifting.

verb If someone convinces you that something is so, they make you believe that it is true. She finally managed to convince him that his hair was too long. Is there sufficient evidence to convince a jury?

verb If someone convinces you to do something, they persuade you to do it. They make you realise that it would be a good idea to do it. After much talking, I convinced her to buy a new car. Not being able to fit into my swimsuit convinced me to diet. How can we convince them to give us the funds?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective convinced Stella thinks it's OK, but I'm not convinced. I'm convinced it'll work.adjective convincing ...a convincing explanation. ...a convincing disguise.

form.definition: noun A convoy is a number of vehicles travelling together. The convoy of army trucks and tanks pulled up at the side of the road. We moved off in convoy as only Paul knew the way.

verb If you cook food, you expose it to heat until it is ready to eat. Some of the main ways of cooking are boiling, frying, grilling, baking and roasting. She was cooking chops on the barbecue. I don't know what to cook for dinner. He really enjoys cooking for guests. Is the chicken cooked yet? The potatoes are cooked through.
noun A cook is someone who prepares and cooks food for people to eat. My cousin is a great cook. He got a job as a cook in a big hotel.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cookery I went to evening classes in Spanish cookery.noun cooking There's nothing I like better than some real home cooking.

form.definition: noun A cook book is a book containing recipes for many different dishes.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is cookery book.

form.definition: 1 adjective If something is cool, it has a fairly low temperature. The weather is much cooler than yesterday. I splashed my face with cool water.
2 adjective Cool clothes are light and designed to stop you getting too hot. It's a sunny day, so wear ~something cool.
adjective If someone is cool towards you, they are rather unfriendly. We used to be really close, but lately he's seemed cool. My suggestion got a very cool reception.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof senses 1, 2 and 3 is warm.

form.definition: adjective If you are cool in an emergency, you stay very calm and unemotional. Police praised the cool reaction of the residents to the bomb scare.

5 cool down In informal language, if you say someone cools down, you mean that they become less angry. After she had cooled down she apologised for her reaction. Cool down now, there's nothing you can do about it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb cool I put the wine in the fridge to cool. The solution is cooled to -200 degrees.noun cool I preferred to stay indoors in the cool.adverb coolly He greeted me coolly. She coolly summoned the fire brigade.

form.definition: noun A coolabah is a type of gum tree found in inland Australia.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this is coolibah.

form.definition: noun A coop is a cage or enclosure for chickens. A dog got into the chicken coop and killed half our hens and roosters.

2 coop up If you coop a person or animal up, you keep them in a confined space. The children don't like being cooped up inside all day. Conditions on the farm are terriblethe pigs are cooped up with hardly room to turn around.

verb If you cooperate with someone, you work together with them to achieve something. It's nice to see the two boys cooperating so well on the project. We are cooperating with a software company to create the product.
2 verb If you cooperate, you do what someone wants you to do. I asked for more time to pay, but they wouldn't cooperate.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is co-operate. ... WORD FAMILYnoun cooperation adjective cooperative It was a cooperative effort. She was very cooperative when I asked for help.

form.definition: verb If you coordinate things, you manage them so that they work well together. It's quite tricky to coordinate the arm and leg movements. He was appointed to coordinate the relief operation.

adjective In grammar,coordinate clauses are equal in importance to ~each other. The opposite of this is subordinate. 3 noun The coordinates of a point are numbers or letters that indicate its position on a map or a graph. Check your map coordinates carefully, or you'll never find the camp.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun coordination

form.definition: 1 noun In informal English, a cop is a police officer. The lookout signalled the approach of a cop. If he threatens you again you must go to the cops.

verb In informal language, if you say someone cops something unpleasant, you mean that they receive it. He tried to break up the fight and copped a punch on the nose. I copped a lecture from my mother for getting back late. Tamsin copped a nasty infection from the dirty swimming pool.
3 cop it In informal language, if you say someone cops it, you mean that they get into trouble. I told you not to do thatnow you're going to cop it from the boss.
4 cop this In informal language, if someone says cop this, they are telling you to look at something interesting or amazing. Cop this hat coming down the street, will you?

verb If you cope with something, you manage to deal with it successfully although it is rather difficult. She coped well with the increased workload. Three children under five are a lot to cope with. I just can't cope any more.
noun Copper is a fairly soft reddish-brown metal.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective copper ...a copper mine. ...copper pipes.

form.definition: noun A copy is something that is made to be exactly the same as something else. These jeans are copies of designer fashions. She sent me a copy of her memo to the manager. 2 noun A single newspaper, magazine or book is also called a copy. Have you got a copy of today's paper? 5000 copies of the book have been sold already.
verb If you copy something, you make another thing that is exactly like it. I asked the dressmaker to copy my mother's wedding dress. I copied the minutes to every member of the committee.
verb If you copy some writing, you write down exactly the same words. I copied the poem into my diary. The teacher wrote the sentences on the board ~for the class to copy.

verb If you copy from someone in an exam or test, you cheat by looking at their answers and writing down exactly the same. The teacher said that anyone who copied another person's work would fail the assignment.
verb If you copy someone, you do the same thing as them. He copied his brother and became a physicist. It really annoys me the way she copies everything I do.
noun If you hold the copyright on something, nobody else is allowed to reproduce it without your permission.[qr

dictionary.entry:
coral`kOr@l
noun Coral is a hard substance that forms in the sea from the skeletons of thousands of tiny sea creatures.

form.definition: noun Cord is fairly thick and strong string. Their legs were tied together with cord.

noun Electrical cord is wires covered in plastic and surrounded by a flexible tube. It is used to connect electrical appliances to a power point. I tripped over the telephone cord. You'll need to buy an extension cord.
noun Cord is also short for corduroy.
adjective If someone is cordial, they are friendly. We received a most cordial welcome from our host. Relations between the two countries have never been cordial.
noun Cordial is a flavoured syrup that you dilute with water to make a soft drink. I bought a bottle of lemon cordial. The children came into the kitchen to ask for some cordial.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb cordially She greeted us cordially.

form.definition: noun Corduroy is a type of cotton fabric which has thick ridges forming parallel lines.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective corduroy ...corduroy trousers.

form.definition: noun The core of a piece of fruit is the central part which contains seeds or pips. She loves apples and eats them core and all.

noun The core of something is its central or most important part. The earth's core consists of iron. Now we are getting to the core of the problem. The experience shook him to the core.~ ... WORD FAMILYadjective core Every student must take three core subjects.
noun Cork is a very light substance which comes from the bark of a tree. It is used to make stoppers for bottles, and tiles, mats and so on. The bathroom floor was tiled with cork.
noun A cork is a stopper that you put into the neck of a bottle to seal it.
noun A corkscrew is a device that you use to open wine bottles by pulling out the cork.
noun Corn is the seed of various types of grain.
noun A corn is a piece of hard skin which can form on your foot, especially if your shoes are too tight.

noun A corner is the part where the edges of something meet. A triangle has three corners. I took a seat in a corner of the room. There was a speck of dust in the corner of my eye. The artist's name is in the top right corner of the canvas.
noun The corner of a street is the place where it intersects with another street. I'll meet you on the corner of Pitt and Market Street. I spotted a postbox on the next corner.
verb I you corner someone, you trap them so that they cannot get away. The police finally cornered the thief at the end of a closed alley. I was cornered by a real bore at the party.
4 turn the corner If someone turns the corner, they start to recover from an illness. She was very sick but I think she's turned the corner.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb corner This car corners well.

form.definition: noun Cornflakes are a type of breakfast cereal made from cooked maize. Usually you eat them in a bowl with milk.

dictionary.entry: corny`k@:ni:corniercorniest adjective If something such as a story or a joke is corny, it is old-fashioned or sentimental, and obvious. I've heard that corny joke before. The ending of the movie was really corny.

coronary`kOr@nri:coronaries noun A coronary is a sudden serious medical condition caused by a clot of blood in the blood vessels of the heart. She had a coronary and was rushed to hospital. If dad finds out what you've done he'll have a coronary.~ ... ANOTHER EXPRESSIONfor this is heart attack.

form.definition: noun A coronation is a ceremony at which someone is crowned king or queen.
noun A coroner is a public official who inquires into sudden or unexplained deaths.
noun A corporal is a junior officer in the army.
2 corporal punishment Corporal punishment is punishment which involves hitting or beating someone. They campaigned to ban corporal punishment in schools.
noun A corporation is a large company or business. He works for a international corporation that has its head office in New York.
noun A corps is a unit of soldiers assigned to a special task.
noun A corps is a small group of people who all do the same job. The President was followed onto the plane by the press corps. They are appealing for a corps of volunteers to feed the homeless.
noun A corpse is a dead body, especially a human body. Three corpses were washed up on the beach.

adjective If something is correct, it is right. It is not mistaken. No, I'm afraid the correct answer is Venezuela. I got eleven correct out of fifteen questions. Am I correct in believing you come from England?
adjective If something is correct, it is socially acceptable and appropriate. We were worried about taking Bill to the party but his behaviour was perfectly correct.
3 verb If you correct something, you do what is necessary to make it right. I read through the letter to correct the spelling. She wears glasses to correct her short sight.

verb If you correct someone, you point out to them that they have made a mistake. I'm afraid I must correct you thereit was in 1989. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I think we've been here before. I hate it when she corrects my grammar.

verb When a teacher corrects a student's work, they read through it to mark where it is wrong. I've got another five essays to correct before I can go to bed.~ ... WORD FAMILYnoun correction She spelt the word wrongly at first but then made a correction.adverb correctly

verb If something corresponds with something else, it agrees with it or matches it. His version of what happened corresponds closely with mine. The two accounts correspond in most particulars. Each number on this page corresponds with a name on this one.
2 verb If two people correspond, they write to each other. My sister lives in Italy and we correspond regularly.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun correspondence I read through the file of correspondence about the deal.noun correspondent We have a number of correspondents who contribute to the magazine.

form.definition: noun A corridor is a connecting passage in a building or a train. Judy's office is just down the corridor from mine.
noun A corroboree is an Aboriginal gathering with dancing and singing.
verb If something corrodes, it is destroyed or worn away by a chemical action such as rust. The storm water pipes had corroded badly. The fumes from the acid will corrode the metal.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun corrosion adjective corrosive

form.definition: adjective If something is corrugated, it is ridged in parallel lines. Our old house in the country used to have a roof of corrugated iron.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun corrugation

form.definition: adjective If someone is corrupt, they are dishonest. I always suspected that the magistrate in that case was corrupt and now he's up on a bribery charge.

verb If someone corrupts you, they influence you to do dishonest or immoral things. Most of the police in the case had been corrupted by gang bosses. She claimed in her defence that she was corrupted by her elder brothers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun corruption

form.definition: noun Cortisone is a drug that is used to treat arthritis and other medical conditions.
noun A cosmetic is something which is intended to improve the appearance of your face or hair. She had a drawer full of ~expensive cosmetics: foundation, powder, lipstick, mascara and so on.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cosmetic ...cosmetic surgery. The changes are cosmetic and don't solve the problem.

form.definition: adjective If something or someone is cosmopolitan, they are influenced by the culture of many different countries or societies. This restaurant has a very cosmopolitan feel about it. She has a cosmopolitan outlook on life.
noun The cosmos is the universe or outer space. Somewhere out there in the cosmos there may be other intelligent creatures.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cosmic ...cosmic radiation.

dictionary.entry: cossie`kOzi: noun Cossie is an informal word for the costume you wear when you go swimming.

form.definition: noun The cost of something is its price. It is how much you have to pay for it. What was the total cost of your party? We are looking at ways of cutting our costs. Try our system at no cost for thirty days.

noun The cost of something is also what you have to suffer or sacrifice in order to have it. The cost of success at sport is often chronic injury. He succeeded in business, but at great cost to his family life.
verb If something costs a certain amount of money, that is how much you have to pay to buy it. I really like that chairhow much did it cost?
verb If something costs you something, it causes you to lose that thing. The strain of the court case cost him his marriage. The accident cost eight lives.

3 at all costs If something must be done at all costs, it absolutely must be done no matter how difficult it may be. We must have it ready by next week at all costs. At all costs don't let Greg know about the problem.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective costly (costlier, costliest)

form.definition: noun A costume is a special set of clothes that someone wears, especially when they are dressing up or appearing in a play or opera. The costumes and scenery were magnificent. Nicky went to the party in a pirate costume.

2 noun A swimming costume or bathing costume is what you wear when you go swimming. These expressions are used especially for the type of garment that women wear.~ ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is swimsuit. In informal language, you can call it a cossie /\times,0\kzi/. 3 costume jewellery Costume jewellery is jewellery that is not made with precious stones. It is designed to be attractive rather than valuable. My mother left me some nice pieces of costume jewellery.

adjective If something is cosy, it is warm, friendly or comfortable. It was good to come in out of the cold into the cosy room. They seemed to be having a cosy chat. I'd just got nice and cosy in bed when the phone rang.
noun A cosy or tea cosy is a thick cover, often knitted, that you can put over a tea pot to keep the tea hot for longer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb cosily noun cosiness

form.definition: noun A cot is a small bed that babies sleep in. It has high sides so that they can't fall out.
2 cot death Cot death is the sudden unexplained death of a baby who has not previously been ill.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is SIDS, or Sudden Infant Death Syndrome.

form.definition: noun A cottage is a small house.
2 cottage cheese Cottage cheese is a very mild white cheese made from curdled skimmed milk.
3 cottage industry A cottage industry is a small craft business in which people work at home or in workshops rather than in factories.
noun Cotton is a type of yarn or fabric made from the soft white fibres that surround the seeds of the cotton plant. This shirt is 100% cotton.
noun Cotton is thread which you use in sewing. You can use this word even if the thread is not actually made of cotton. I need a reel of blue cotton to sew on this button.

3 cotton on In informal English, if you say you cotton on, you mean that you understand a situation or what someone means. It took me a while to cotton on to what he was saying: the house was on fire. They'd been having an affair for months before her husband cottoned on.

4 cotton wool Cotton wool is raw fibres from the cotton plant. You can buy it in sheets or balls and use it for cosmetic purposes or for packing fragile objects. She removed her make-up with cotton wool.
noun A couch is a piece of furniture like a wide armchair which seats two or more people. I haven't got a spare bed, but you can sleep on the couch.
form.note: ... OTHER WORDSfor this are sofa and lounge.

form.definition: noun A couch is also a piece of furniture like a narrow bed which doctors use to examine patients in their surgery. The doctor asked me to take off my shirt and lie on the couch.

verb When you cough, you expel air from your lungs strongly and make a loud noise. When you have a bad cold you do this often because your lungs are congested. I had to leave the room because I couldn't stop coughing. He coughed discreetly to attract my attention.
2 cough up In informal English, if you say someone coughs up money, you mean that they pay it rather unwillingly. You still owe me $10: come on, it's time to cough up now.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cough She gave a cough. My cold's almost gone, but I've still got a cough.

form.definition: verb Could is a form of the modal verb can. When you use it to make a request, it sounds more polite than can. Could I have the day off on Friday, please? Could you pass the salt, please?
form.note: ... NOTEThis form is regarded as the past tense form of can. See senses 2-7 of that verb.

form.definition: noun A council is the local government body responsible for things such as garbage collection, street cleaning, building regulations and so on. It is controlled by elected representatives of the people who live in the area.

noun A council is also a committee or organisation that discusses problems and decides policy in a particular area of activity. The Arts Council of Australia distributes grants to outstanding writers and painters.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun councillor He was elected to serve another term as councillor.

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say you counsel someone to do something, you mean that you advise them to do it. She counselled me to be cautious in raising the issue with him.
noun In a law court, counsel is the barristers who represent the defence and the ~prosecution. The prisoner's counsel asked for an adjournment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun counsellor She's a counsellor with the local social services.

form.definition: verb If you count, you recite the numbers one, two, three and so on in order. I turned my back and counted to ten.

verb If you count objects, you add them up or work out how many of them there are. I counted the children as they got off the bus. Have you ever counted how many stairs there are? I was counting how much money I'd saved. It's impossible to count the stars.
verb If something counts, it matters. It is important. Every second counts at this stage in the race. It's not the cost of the gift that counts, it's the spirit in which it's given.

verb If you count something, or count it in, you include it. If you're looking for volunteers, count me in. I'd already spent over $200, not counting the transport costs. 5 count on If you count on someone or something, you make your plans relying on them. I was counting on Ann to help and now she's sick. I'll be there in time, you can count on me. He's bought a new car because he's counting on getting a bonus at Christmas.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun count There were ten of us at the last count.

form.definition: noun A counter in a shop, cafe, or bank is the long narrow table from behind which the people who work there serve the customers. Please order and pay for your food at the counter. The assistant fetched several ties and laid them on the counter. You can buy salami at our delicatessen counter.

noun A counter is also a small flat token which is used in playing games. You move your counter forward by the number of spaces that you throw with the dice. Meike was doing very wellshe has amassed a great pile of counters.

adjective If something is counterfeit, it has been made to look exactly like something else in an attempt to deceive people. He was found to be travelling on a counterfeit passport.~ ... WORD FAMILYverb counterfeit Police are seeking the gang responsible for counterfeiting the banknotes.noun counterfeit The statue turned out to be a counterfeit.

noun A country is a nation. It is an area of land which has its own government. People from 18 different countries attended the conference. I'd like to spend some time living in a different country. She collects stamps from all the countries of the world.
noun The country is land which is outside towns and cities. They live on a farm in the country.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is the countryside. ... WORD FAMILYadjective country ...country living.

form.definition: noun A coup occurs when a group of people takes over the government of a country by force.

noun A coup is also a clever plan which succeeds in a surprising way. Getting such a large loan from the bank is quite a coup. You pulled off quite a coup in attracting such an international star to the concert!

noun A couple is two people who are involved in a romantic relationship with each other or who are doing something together. Most of the people at the party were in couples. They have been a couple for over twenty years.
2 noun In informal language, you can use couple to mean a few things, perhaps more than exactly two. I'll only be a couple of minutes. I've got a couple of questions to ask.
noun A coupon is a printed ticket that you can exchange for something instead of paying for it with money. He won a book of movie coupons.

noun A coupon is also a small form that you fill in, for example with your name and address, in order to receive information about something. Fill in the coupon below and return it to us for full details.

adjective Courage is bravery. It is being willing to do something even though it is dangerous or frightening. Standing up in front of all those people took a lot of courage. The firefighters who rescued the child from the burning building were commended for their courage.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective courageous

form.definition: noun A courier is a person or company who delivers letters and parcels as quickly as possible in return for a fee. We sent the letter by courier. She got a job as a bicycle courier. It's possible to get very cheap flights by acting as an international courier.
noun A courier is also someone who is employed by a travel company to help overseas tourists. During the summer holidays I worked as a courier in Bali.
noun A course is one part of a meal, for example the entree, the main or the dessert. Their fixed menu is $25 for two courses or $32 for three. We were served a banquet of seven courses.
noun A course is a series of lessons or lectures. I'm doing a word processing course. Have you chosen your courses for next year yet?

noun A course is also a piece of land or water over which a race takes place. The race is run over a 15 km course. The course this year is especially challenging. Only one third of the entrants were able to complete the course.

noun A course is also the way things naturally develop or follow on from each other. I decided not to intervene, but to let matters follow their course. What is the normal course of events in such a case? We have several possible courses of action open to us.

5 of course Of course means 'naturally'. When you say this you mean that you assume the person you are addressing already knows or understands what you are telling them. Of course it's been a difficult time for him. I don't want to rush you of course. You must of course be familiar with this part of the country.
noun A court is a room where trials and legal cases are held. Sometimes this is also called a court of law or a lawcourt. The accused's mother attended court on every day of the trial.
2 noun The court of a king or queen is their palace and all the people who live and work there.
3 noun A court is an area where you play sport such as tennis, netball, basketball and so on. The apartments have their own swimming pool and tennis court.
noun A court is an area enclosed by buildings on several sides.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is courtyard.

form.definition: verb In rather old-fashioned language, if you say that someone courts someone else, you mean that ~they try to win their love. Frank has been courting Emily for months, but she's just not interested.

6 out of court If a legal matter is settled out of court, it is resolved by an agreement between the parties before the case is due to be heard in court. They settled our claim out of court rather than face the embarrassment of a public hearing.
adjective If someone is courteous, they are polite and have good manners. He was far too courteous to say that it wasn't convenient.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun courtesy She didn't even have the courtesy to thank me.

form.definition: noun A courtyard is an area which is enclosed by buildings on several sides.
noun Your cousins are the sons and daughters of your uncles and aunts. Sometimes you also call more distant members of your family who are about the same age as you your cousins.
noun A cove is a small bay on the shore of a sea or harbour.
noun A covenant is a legal agreement between two people or bodies.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb covenant

form.definition: verb If you cover something, you put something over it, often to protect it or to hide it. We covered the stain on the carpet with a rug. I'd better cover that jug to keep the flies out. She covered her books with plastic. You should keep your head covered in the sun.
verb If something covers something else, it is spread all over it. Snow covered the hills. Dust covered the furniture. The children came home covered in mud. The walls were covered with mould.
verb If something covers an area of land or sea, it spreads or extends over that area. The oil spill covered ten square kilometres of the coastal water. The factory covers about a hectare of land.
verb If you are able to cover your expenses, you have enough money to pay for them. Will $100 cover the cost of the tickets and dinner afterwards?

verb If something such as insurance covers you, you know that it will pay your costs in certain situations, such as fire, theft and so on. My health insurance covers me for private hospitals. We have our house and contents fully covered.
verb If you cover a certain distance when you are travelling, you move ~forward by that amount. We covered 900 km in two days.

verb If you cover a certain topic when you are speaking or writing, you deal with it or include it. We've already covered what to do in an emergency. Now, is there anything I haven't covered? Not all the news programs covered the story.
noun A cover is something that is put over something, often to protect it. He took the cover off his tennis racquet and walked onto the court.

noun The covers of a book or magazine are the thick sheets at the front and back which protect it. I glanced at the cover of the magazine and decided not to buy it. ...the front cover. ...the back cover.
noun Cover is also shelter or a safe place. The children ran for cover from the storm. We dived for cover as the bullets began to fly. I'd like to be able to keep my car under cover.

11 cover up If you cover something up, you try to stop other people from finding out about it. The government was accused of covering up the scandal. 12 cover for If you cover for someone, you do their work while they are away. Who's going to cover for Dasia while she's on maternity leave?
verb If you covet something that someone else has, you are envious or jealous. You wish that you had it.
noun Cows are farm animals which are raised either to produce milk or to be slaughtered for beef.
noun In particular, a cow is a female animal of this kind.
noun A female elephant, seal or whale can also be called a cow.
noun A coward is someone who is not brave. They are afraid and unwilling to face danger or difficult experiences. Don't be such a cowardit'll only hurt for a moment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cowardice

form.definition: noun A crab is a sea creature with a hard shell. It has ten legs, with large claws on the front pair. Some types can be cooked and the flesh inside the shell eaten as food.

verb If something cracks, it splits so that there is a long narrow break in it, although often it doesn't actually fall apart. The cup cracked in the dishwasher. You'll crack the glass if you pour boiling water into it.
verb If something cracks, it makes a sudden sharp sound. The cracking of the twigs indicated that someone was ~approaching. The stockman cracked his whip.
3 verb If you crack something or someone, you suddenly hit it hard. I cracked my knee on the table as I walked past. The old lady cracked him on the head with her umbrella.
verb If you crack something such as a problem, you work out how to solve it. I stared at the puzzle for ages before I finally cracked it. I've cracked it! Why don't we ask Alec to help us?
verb If you crack a joke, you make a joke. You say something funny. Even though he was so ill, he was still cracking jokes.
6 noun A crack is a long narrow break in something. I threw this plate away as there was a crack right across it.
noun A crack is a long narrow gap between two things. The coin rolled down a crack in the floor. I managed to wedge myself into a crack in the rocks.
noun A crack is a sudden sharp sound that something makes. We all heard the crack of the gun.
noun A crack is a sudden hard blow. He gave his egg a sharp crack on the edge of the table.
noun A crack is a nasty or sarcastic comment. I'm sick of her cracks about my weight.
noun In informal language, crack is a form of cocaine.

12 crack up (a) In informal language, if you say someone cracks up, you mean that they have a mental breakdown. She cracked up under the strain. You can't work fifteen hours a day indefinitely without cracking up.

(b) verb phrase In informal English, if you say someone cracks up, you mean that they can't help laughing. I know I shouldn't have, but I just cracked up when he said that. Evan cracked us all up with his jokes. 13 have a crack In informal language, if you say you have a crack at something, you mean that you try your best to do it. I've never done that before but I'm willing to have a crack at it.
noun A cracker is a thin, crisp, savoury biscuit. They served cheese and crackers with the wine.
noun Crackers are also small fireworks that make a loud noise when you let them off.
verb If something crackles, it makes short sharp sounds. The fire was crackling in the fireplace. The parcel crackled when I squeezed it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun crackle

form.definition: noun The crackling on pork is the fat which has become crisp when it is cooked.
noun A cradle is a small bed for a baby that you can rock from side to side. The young mother sat rocking her baby in its cradle.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb cradle He cradled the child in his arms and sang it a lullaby.

form.definition: noun A craft is an activity which involves making things by hand or using only simple machinery. The college offers courses in various crafts such as weaving and pottery.
noun You can also refer to a ship or plane as a craft. The captain brought his craft right up to the wharf.

dictionary.entry: crafty`kra:fti:craftiercraftiest adjective If someone is crafty, they are cunning. They are clever and rather devious in achieving what they want. It was pretty crafty of him to get out of the office by offering to deliver the package.

form.definition: noun A crag is a rough steep rock sticking out from a cliff or mountain.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective craggy ...a craggy mountain top.

form.definition: verb If you cram something into a space, you stuff or push it in there although there is not a lot of room. She crammed her clothes into a suitcase and left at once. We all crammed into a tiny room. He was determined to cram as much as possible into each day.

verb In informal language, if you say that you cram for a test or exam, you mean that you work very hard just before it. He lazed around all year and then crammed madly for three weeks before the exams.
noun Cramp is a sudden painful stiffening of the muscles. She had to pull out of the race because of a cramp in her leg. The doctor was called to see a patient suffering from stomach cramps.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb cramp The muscles in my arm cramped painfully.

form.definition: adjective If something is cramped, it is crowded or squashed up. There isn't enough room. The office was far too cramped for us all to work effectively. It was pretty cramped with twelve of us in the house over Christmas. Her writing was cramped and hard to read.
noun A crane is a large machine which is used for lifting heavy objects. The tree ~blew over in the storm and we needed a crane to remove it.
noun A crane is also a bird with a long neck and long legs.
verb If you crane your neck, you stretch it out as far as you can in order to see something. She craned her neck out of the window to see the procession.
noun A crank is a person who has strange ways of thinking and of doing things. Don't listen to her, she's a food crank. He's a bit of a crank you knowhe collects old tins.
noun A crank is also a handle that you turn to start an engine.
adjective If you're cranky, you're cross, angry or irritated. Don't worry about himhe's just a cranky old man.
noun A crash is a bad accident involving one or more vehicles. The plane crash killed two hundred people. The crash in the tunnel delayed traffic for three hours. She was crippled in a car crash.
verb If something crashes, it falls dramatically and breaks. The vase crashed to the ground. The Australian stock market crashed in October 1987.

verb If a vehicle crashes, or if you crash it, it is involved in an accident. It collides with something. One of the plane's engines caught fire and I was sure we were going to crash. He drove off the road and crashed into a telegraph pole. I crashed the car the first time I drove it.

noun A crash is a loud noise that something makes when it falls or collides with something. The box fell to the ground with a loud crash. We sat listening to the crash of the waves on the rocks below. 5 crash helmet If you ride a bicycle or motorbike you must wear a crash helmet on your head. The helmet protects your head from injury in case you have an accident.
noun A crate is a container used for transporting things such as fruit or vegetables, or cartons of milk or bottles of beer. We stood on old milk crates to watch the procession.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb crate Our furniture was crated up to be sent overseas.

form.definition: noun A crater is the mouth of a volcano, or a very large hole in the ground caused by an explosion or something hitting it. Some of us ventured down into the crater where the volcano ~was belching clouds of steam. The satellite photographed the craters on the moon.
verb If you crave something, you want it very badly. I still occasionally crave a cigarette, even though I gave up smoking months ago.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun craving Pregnant women often develop strange cravings.

form.definition: verb If you crawl, you move forward on your hands and knees. Babies begin to crawl at about seven months. The injured man crawled to the side of the road. You should drop to the ground, where the smoke is less dense, and crawl to the exit.
verb If something such as a car crawls, it moves very slowly. The car crawled up the hill at about ten kilometres an hour. We spent over an hour crawling along in a traffic dam.

verb In informal language, if you say someone crawls, you mean that they act very humbly towards someone and flatter them, often because they want something from them. I'll ask him nicely but I refuse to crawl. It makes me sick the way she's always crawling to the boss.
noun The crawl is a stroke in swimming.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is freestyle. ... WORD FAMILYnoun crawl We moved forward at a crawl for about twenty minutes.noun crawler He's such a crawlerhe agrees with everything the supervisor says.

form.definition: noun A crayfish is an animal that lives in fresh water. It has a hard shell and looks rather like a lobster.
noun A crayon is a coloured pencil or a long thin cylinder of pigment that you use for drawing or colouring.
noun A craze is an activity or fashion that suddenly becomes very popular with a lot of people. He's always keen to follow the latest craze.

adjective If someone is crazy, they are insane or eccentric. In the last years of his life he went crazy and was confined to an asylum. A crazy old woman lives there with about twenty cats. He was half crazy with grief and worry.

adjective If someone is crazy, they behave in a strange or foolish way. Fred goes swimming in winterhe's crazy. It was a crazy idea to try and do it all in ~one day. You must be crazy to ride a motorbike without a helmet.
verb If something creaks, it makes a low-pitched squeaking sound. I could hear the floorboards creaking as he walked around upstairs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective creaky (creakier, creakiest) This door has got very creakyyou'd better oil the hinge.

form.definition: noun Cream is the part of milk which is rich in fat and usually yellowish white in colour. They served us scones with jam and cream. I skimmed the cream off the top of the milk.
2 noun Cream is a yellowish white colour. The walls were painted in cream.
noun If something has the consistency of a thick smooth liquid, it can also be called a cream. Add water to the powder until if forms a cream. She applied face cream before going to bed.
noun The cream of something is the best part of it. The cream of the country's students attend this university.
verb If you cream something, you beat it or stir it until it forms a thick, smooth liquid. Cream the butter and the sugar and then add the flour and milk.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cream The bride wore a cream silk dress.adjective creamy (creamier, creamiest) Beat the mixture to a creamy consistency.

form.definition: noun A crease is a fold in something such as a piece of cloth or paper. He always has neat creases down the front of his trousers. Hang the blouse in the bathroom while you shower and the creases should fall out.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb crease My dress had got creased in the suitcase. Linen creases easily.

form.definition: verb If you create something, you make it or bring it into existence. Some people believe that the world was created by a god. I love the characters that she has created in her new play. He created a magnificent meal from the most humble ingredients.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun creation adjective creative

form.definition: noun A creature is any animal. Elephants are huge creatures. Their puppy is an adorable little creature. The rock pools are full of tiny creatures.

noun A creche is a place where parents can leave their young children to be looked after for a while. I drop my daughter at ~the creche on the way to work. The conference will have a creche supervised by fully trained staff.
adjective If something is credible, it is believable. I found his account entirely credible. She has a gift for creating credible characters. It was hardly credible that she could earn so much money.

noun If you use credit, you don't pay for the things that you buy immediately. You charge them and pay the bill later, often in instalments over several months. Take advantage of our special offer of six months interest free credit. She accused banks of encouraging people to apply for credit they can't afford.
noun Credit is respect or recognition that you get from other people because of something good that you have done. I can't take all the credit for our successit was a team effort.
noun A credit is money that is paid into a bank account. The credit I was expecting still hasn't shown up in my bank statement. At the end of the month I was still a few dollars in credit.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is debit.

form.definition: verb If money is credited to your bank account, it is paid into your account. The funds will be credited to your account immediately, but you can't withdraw them for five working days. My salary is credited to my account twice a month.

verb If you say you credit that something is the case, you mean you believe that it is true. This is used mostly in negative sentences to emphasise how surprising something is. I could hardly credit that I'd travelled to the other side of the world. Tina's lost her bus pass againcan you credit it? You wouldn't credit the trouble I had finding you.

6 credit card A credit card is a card issued by a financial institution which allows you to use credit to buy things. Instead of paying with cash or a cheque, you present the card and sign a docket. You then have to repay the financial institution.

7 give someone credit If you give someone credit for something, you acknowledge that they deserve approval for some good action or quality in their character. She's been honest at least, I'll give her credit for that.
8 on credit If you buy something on credit, you use credit to buy it. You do not pay for it immediately. I bought all my Christmas ~presents on credit and I was still paying off the bill in June.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective creditable It was a very creditable achievement.

form.definition: noun A creek is a small stream.
verb If you creep somewhere, you move along slowly, trying hard not to make a noise. I caught him creeping along the corridor.
2 noun In informal language, a creep is an unpleasant person. Jason's a real creepwhy did he have to tell everyone what she was upset about?

3 the creeps In informal language, if something gives you the creeps, it makes you feel uneasy. I don't like being alone in the house at nightit gives me the creeps. I suddenly got the creeps and called out to Martin. Hearing about his operation gave us all the creeps.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective creepy (creepier, creepiest) They live in a creepy old house full of cobwebs.

form.definition: noun A creeper is a plant that grows up things such as walls. Ivy is a creeper, and so are many types of plant that grow around tree trunks in the jungle.
verb If someone is cremated, their body is burnt to ashes after they die. Do you want to be buried or cremated?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cremation

form.definition: noun Acrematorium is a place where people's bodies are burnt, or cremated, after they have died.
noun Crepe is a very fine, light, crinkly fabric made from cotton or silk.
noun Crepe or crepe paper is coloured paper that has been wrinkled like crepe. You use it for making decorations and wrapping presents.
noun A crepe is also a type of thin pancake served with a savoury or sweet filling. After the movie we all went to a cafe for apple crepes.
noun The crest of something is the top of it, below which the sides fall away steeply. At last we reached the crest of the hill. The crests of the waves were white with foam.
noun A crevice is a deep, narrow crack. The coin fell through a crevice between the floor boards. Plants can be found growing in the crevices of the rocks.
noun The crew of a ship or plane is made up of all the people who work on it.
2 noun In informal language, you can use crew to refer to any group of people who work together or spend time together. There's no way I'd trust Borek and that crew.
