form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb crew The ship is crewed largely by sailors from the Philippines.

dictionary.entry:
cribkrIbcribscribbingcribbed 1 noun Crib is a rather old-fashioned word for a
verb If you crib something from someone, you cheat by copying their work. Tom never does his own workhe's always cribbing answers from me.
noun A crib is a small book which contains information about a famous work of literature. Students use it to help them study for exams.

form.definition: noun Cricket is an outdoor game played between two teams of eleven people. Each team has a turn to bat while the other team fields. Each member of the team has a turn to bat and tries to score as many runs as they can before being out.
noun A cricket is an insect which can jump a long way and makes a loud chirping sound.
noun A crime is an action which is against the law. Drunk driving is a crime. The police are determined to reduce crime in the neighbourhood. No-one was ever arrested for this crime.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun criminal He is a notorious criminal.adjective criminal ...the criminal justice system. The way they treat the animals is criminal.

form.definition: noun Crimson is a deep purplish red colour. She painted her lips a ripe crimson.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective crimson ...a crimson rose.

form.definition: verb If a person or animal cringes, they crouch down or shy away because they are afraid of being beaten. The dog had obviously been mistreatedit would cringe whenever it heard a raised voice.
verb If you cringe, you feel very embarrassed about something, often on behalf of someone else. I cringe every time I remember the incident. We all cringed when he insisted on singing at the party.
verb If something crinkles, it becomes slightly wrinkled or creased. The pages had crinkled where they'd got wet. She wore a blouse of crinkled silk.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun crinkle I rather like the crinkles around his eyes.adjective crinkly (crinklier, crinkliest)

form.definition: noun A cripple is someone who is physically handicapped, especially if they have difficulty in walking. Note that most people who are physically handicapped do not like to be referred to as cripples. The accident left him a helpless cripple. She came home in tears because the other children had called her a cripple.

verb If you are crippled by something, you are badly affected by it, especially financially or emotionally. They claimed that the new tax would cripple their business. He was crippled by the death of both his sons within three years.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb cripple She was crippled in a car accident.adjective crippling The strike last year was a crippling blow to the company.

form.definition: noun A crisis is a very serious event or emergency which causes great concern. The minister's resignation caused a crisis in the government. The country is facing economic crisis. My sister was an enormous support to me in this time of crisis.
noun A crisis is also the most dramatic or dangerous point in a series of events. The crisis comes in the fifth chapter of the book. The crisis is over and the patient should start to recover now.
adjective If something is crisp, it is firm and fresh. It is not soggy or floppy. The salad was full of lovely crisp vegetables. It was bliss to slide between the crisp white sheets.
adjective If the weather is crisp, it is cool and bright. We woke up to a beautiful crisp spring day.
noun Crisps is another word for potato chips.
form.note: ... SEEchip, sense 3.

form.definition: noun A critic is someone who judges artistic works and writes reviews about them for other people to read. Did you read what the critics had to say about the movie? He's a respected art critic.

noun A critic is someone who disagrees with a particular person, policy or decision and attacks them in public. She is one of ~the Premier's loudest critics. It seems that this time he has silenced the critics.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See critical. verb criticise I hate the way she's always criticising my clothes.noun criticism The group listened carefully to Ming-Lee's criticism of the project.

form.definition: adjective If something is critical, it is extremely serious, dangerous or important. The town is experiencing a critical shortage of food. The doctors said her condition was critical. This is a critical point in the negotiations. It's critical you should be there.
adjective If someone is critical of other people or of things, they find fault with them. I'm doing my best, there's no need to be so critical.
adjective If you write a critical appreciation of something, you study it carefully and assess its good and bad points.
verb When frogs croak, they make their typical low, hoarse sound. He had such a bad cold that he could hardly speakall he could do was croak.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun croak

form.definition: noun Croatian is the language of the people of Croatia.
adjective If someone or something comes from Croatia, you describe them as Croatian.
noun Crockery is cups, saucers, plates, dishes, bowls and so on which are made of china. I dried and put away the cutlery and the crockery.
noun A crocodile is a large meat-eating animal which lives in tropical waters.
noun A crook is a criminal or a dishonest person. You can't trust himhe's a crook. I'd like to get my hands on the crooks who sold me this car.
noun Something that has a curved or bent part can be called a crook. She was nursing the baby in the crook of her arm.
3 adjective In informal language, if you say you are crook, you mean that you are sick. I've been crook all week with a stomach bug. You still look pretty crookyou'd better stay in bed.
adjective In informal language, if you say you are crook at someone, you mean that you are cross with them. Don't go crook at me, mateit's not my fault.

adjective If something is crooked, it is bent or not straight. The picture's ~slightly crooked on the wall, I thinkit needs to go up a bit on the right. Could you draw that line again please? It's supposed to be straight, not crooked.
verb If you croon, you sing or hum quietly in a low voice. She was crooning to the baby to try to get it to sleep.

noun A crop is plants or their products that are grown as a commercial activity. Our wheat crop was ruined by the rains. This year's crop should fetch record prices. The most important crops grown in Australia are wheat, sugar cane and cotton.
2 verb If you crop something, you cut it short. Louisa has had her hair cropped. I cropped the edges of the photo to fit it on the page.

3 crop up If something crops up, it happens unexpectedly or by chance. George had to go in to the office on Sunday because a problem cropped up. The disease isn't common, but cases do crop up occasionally.

verb If you cross an area, you move from one side of it to the other. She crossed the room to meet him. The train took four hours to cross the desert. I crossed the bridge into the old part of the city. Be careful when you cross the road.
verb If something crosses a space, it extends from one side of it to the other. The bridge crosses the river at Fisherman's Creek. This road crosses the Nullarbor Plain.
verb If two things cross, they meet and go across each other at an angle. The two roads cross at an intersection a couple of kilometres away.
verb If you cross two things, you place them across each other at an angle. I crossed the sticks in the fireplace and piled up newspaper on top of them.

verb If you cross a cheque, you draw two parallel lines on it. This means that the bank is not allowed to pay cash but must pay it into the account of the person it is made out to, or to their order. You can also get cheques printed like this. It is safer always to cross your cheques in case they go astray.

noun A cross is a written mark consisting of two short lines drawn across each other at an angle. Sometimes you use a cross to show that something is wrong (a tick shows that it is right), or sometimes it draws attention to an item in a list. They were playing noughts and crosses. My work came back to me covered in red crosses.
noun If something ~is a cross between two things, it has features which are like each of them. The show is a cross between straight drama and the circus.
adjective If someone is cross, they are angry or annoyed. I can see by your face that you're cross. I'm cross that they didn't bother to consult me.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is cranky.

form.definition: cross out If you cross something out in a piece of writing, you draw a line through it because you think it is wrong or no longer relevant or you don't agree with it. I wrote three pages in the exam but I crossed out half of it.
If you cross swords with someone, you have an argument or disagreement with them, often in public. The two ministers have crossed swords on the issue before.

If you cross your fingers, you cross your middle finger over your forefinger. Usually you do this as a sign that you wish for good luck. Sometimes people do this when they know that they are lying. I'll keep my fingers crossed for you. Well, fingers crossed, here goes! I said I'd love to see her again but I had my fingers firmly crossed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun crossing There's a pedestrian crossing a little further on. We had a rough crossing.

form.definition: noun In the Christian religion, the Cross refers to the structure on which Jesus Christ was crucified.

verb If you cross-examine someone, you ask them a lot of detailed questions about something. Counsel for the prosecution cross-examined the witness on her testimony for the defence. As soon as I get in my mother cross-examines me about where I've been and who I've been with.
noun A crossroads is a place where two roads meet or cross.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is intersection.[qr

form.definition: noun A crossword or crossword puzzle is a word puzzle where you have to solve clues and write the answers in a grid of squares. When you have written some answers in, this helps you because you know certain of the letters in the other words.

verb If you crouch, you bend or stoop down so that you are not so tall or ~conspicuous. We had to crouch to get through the low doorway. He crouched behind the bookcase when she came in so that she wouldn't see him.
noun A croupier is a person whose job is to work at a gaming table in a club or casino.
noun A crow is a large black bird with a loud screeching cry.

verb In informal language, if you say someone crows about something, you mean that they boast or show off about it. They are very pleased with themselves because of it. He made himself very unpopular by crowing about his victory. OK, so you were rightthere's no need to crow.
noun A crowbar is a heavy iron bar which is used as a lever, for example to force something open. He opened the crate with a crowbar.
noun A crowd is a large number of people in the same place. The crowd had been waiting for many hours to see the parade. I can't stand the crowds in town on Saturday afternoon.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb crowd The children crowded around their teacher. We all crowded into the room.adjective crowded The lecture hall was very crowded.

form.definition: noun A crown is a large heavy piece of jewellery that a king or queen wears on their head on special occasions.
verb When a king or queen is crowned, a crown is put on their head at a special ceremony to show that they have just become the monarch.
noun You can use the Crown to refer to the monarchy, or the king or queen of England. He insisted that Australia would remain loyal to the Crown.
noun The crown of something is the top part of it. He hit the crown of his head on the beam. I could see her standing on the crown of the hill.
noun A crown on your tooth is a new false tooth that the dentist has made and fitted over what is left of the old natural tooth.

adjective If something is crucial, it is extremely important. Your decision is crucial to your future, so think carefully about it. It's crucial that we should win this contract. She was disciplined by her party for missing the crucial vote.~ ... WORD FAMILYadverb crucially ...crucially important.
verb When Jesus Christ was crucified, he was killed by being nailed to a structure made from two intersecting pieces of wood. This was a common form of execution in the Roman Empire at the time.

verb If you say someone or something crucifies you, you mean that they treat you very harshly or make you undergo a very unpleasant experience. The barrister absolutely crucified that witness. We'll be crucified if they catch us herelet's go. Low income earners have been crucified by rising interest rates.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun crucifixion

form.definition: adjective If something is crude, it is very basic and simple. I made several crude attempts at drawing a tree. The prototype is still relatively crude, but is shows how the software will work.
adjective If someone is crude, they have bad manners and offend people. I decided to be really crude and eat with my fingers. He shocked us all by telling a string of crude jokes.
adjective If something is described as crude, it is in its raw or natural state. Australia exports crude oil to Japan.
adjective If someone is cruel, they enjoy hurting or upsetting people or animals. Stop beating that poor dog, you cruel beast. She made some cruel remarks about his performance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cruelty

form.definition: noun If you go on a cruise, you take a holiday on a ship or boat which sails around to different places. She won a cruise of the South Pacific in the Easter draw.
verb If you cruise somewhere, you travel there in a leisurely fashion. You are enjoying yourself and not in a hurry. We were cruising along in the car admiring the scenery.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb cruise They went cruising in the Mediterranean.

form.definition: noun A crumb is a small piece of something such as bread, cake or biscuit. She swept up the crumbs off the floor. The recipe uses half a cup of bread crumbs.

verb If something crumbles, it falls apart into small pieces or powder. The old wall is crumbling underneath the ivy. The paper crumbled to dust as soon as it was exposed to the ~air. I crumbled the biscuits into the base of the dish.

adjective In informal language, if you say something is crummy, you mean that it is very bad. You do not like it at all. Her flat is really crummyI'd hate to live there. It was a crummy movie. He expected me to work all day for a crummy twenty bucks.
noun A crumpet is a sort of thin, flat bun with lots of holes in it. You toast it and eat it with butter.

verb If you crumple something, you accidentally cause it to become creased. Don't crumple that dressI have to wear it tonight. I sat down on her copy of the speech and crumpled it. I was feeling pretty crumpled by the end of the twenty-hour flight.

verb If something crumples, it collapses or folds in on itself. The floor crumpled under the weight of the machinery. You can't work fifteen hours a day for long without crumpling under the strain. Her face crumpled and she began to cry.
3 crumple up If you crumple something up, you screw it up. You compress it into a very small space. She crumpled up the letter and threw it into the waste paper basket.

verb If something crunches, it makes a harsh crushing or grinding noise when it comes into contact with something. We shot forward and crunched into the car in front. I crunched on the bone and broke my tooth.

2 if it comes to the crunch In informal language, you say if it comes to the crunch to introduce what you will do if the situation becomes very serious. If it comes to the crunch and she's not well enough to travel, we could all visit her in Perth. I was wondering how much it would cost, but fortunately it never came to the crunch.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun crunch We all heard a crunch as the parcel hit the floor.adjective crunchy (crunchier, crunchiest) I like the vegetables to be nice and crunchy, not overcooked.

form.definition: noun A crusade is a campaign against something or in favour of something. Her crusade against drink driving has occupied most of her energy for years. At last the campaign crusade was over and we could only wait for the results.~ ... WORD FAMILYverb crusade

verb If you crush something, you squeeze or compress it, usually so that it is broken. He crushed the beer can and threw it away. The car was crushed under the toppled crane. The rock is crushed to extract the gold. The crowd crushed me against the barrier.
verb If someone is crushed, they suffer severely. She was crushed by the news of her father's death.
verb If someone is crushed, they are humiliated or disappointed. I was crushed by his lack of interest in my proposal.
noun A crush is a large crowd of people. We became separated in the crush. I did my Christmas shopping early to avoid the crush.
noun When a young person has a crush on someone, they like them very much and spend a lot of time thinking about them. I used to have a crush on my tennis coach when I was a teenager.

noun A crust is a hard dry part on the surface of something that is otherwise moist. I particularly like the crusts at the ends of the loaf. Put the pastry on top of the fruit to form the pie crust. The paint had begun to dry out and form a crust.
noun Crustaceans are shellfish such as crabs, lobsters and prawns.
noun A crutch is a specially designed stick which you use for support if you have injured your leg. She limped into the room on crutches.
noun A crutch is anything that you use as a help or support, especially mentally or emotionally. I decided I had to strike out on my own without the crutch of living at home.

noun The crux of something is its most important part. The crux of the matter is that he doesn't want to go. The article was so vague that it was hard to grasp the crux of her argument. He summarised the crux of the issue in a paragraph.

verb If you cry, tears form in your eyes and run down your face. Usually this happens because you are unhappy, but sometimes because you are relieved and happy about something. When Tom got home, he found his mother crying. She cried in relief when she passed her exams.
2 cry out If you cry out, you shout or call out loudly. We cried out in order to attract his attention. He was crying out ~in pain. I cried out for help. She cried out his name.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cry We all heard the cry from the next house.

form.definition: adjective If something is cryptic, it is difficult to understand. He rang and left a cryptic message. I don't know what she's planningshe's been very cryptic lately.
noun A crystal is a mineral that has formed into a regular shape. In our chemistry lessons we looked at different crystals.
2 noun Crystal is a type of rock that is transparent and looks like ice. Sometimes it is coloured.
3 noun Crystal is also an expensive type of glass with patterns cut into it. They served fine wines in the best crystal.

4 crystal ball A crystal ball is a large glass ball which fortune tellers look into in order to see the future. Looking into my crystal ball, I reckon Miriam and Scott will be married in another couple of years.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb crystallise

form.definition: noun A cub is the young of certain animals, such as lions, tigers and bears. The mother lion is fierce in defending her cubs.[qr

dictionary.entry:
cubekju:b
noun A cube is a solid shape with six square faces.
2 noun The cube of a number is the number you get when you multiply it by itself twice, for example 3 x 3 x 3. The cube of 3 is 27.
... WORD FAMILYadjective See cubic. verb cube Three cubed is twenty-seven.

form.definition: adjective Cubic measurement is to do with the volume of solid objectsthe amount of space that they take up. We had to work out how many cubic metres of concrete we needed for the driveway.
noun A cubicle is a small enclosed area inside a larger room or public building. There are cubicles at the swimming pool where you can get changed. The phone is in a cubicle at the end of the hall.
noun A cucumber is a long, thin, green vegetable which is usually eaten raw in salads.
2 as cool as a cucumber If you say someone is as cool as a cucumber, you mean that they are very calm. They do not panic or get ~cross even in situations of great stress.
verb If you cuddle someone, you hug them and hold them tightly in your arms to comfort them or show them affection. He sat his daughter on his knee and cuddled her.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun cuddle Her mother gave her a cuddle.

form.definition: adjective If something such as a toy or animal is cuddly, it looks soft and cute, and you feel like cuddling it.
noun A cue is anything that serves as a signal that some action is to be taken. The actor missed his cue and had to be prompted. When my mother coughs, that's my cue to start clearing the table.
noun A cue is also a long stick that you use to hit the balls in games such as billiards, pool and snooker.
noun The cuffs of a shirt or blouse are the parts at the end of the sleeves. You may need to scrub the collars and cuffs.
verb If someone cuffs you, they hit you. He cuffed his team mate playfully on the shoulder. When my father was young he regularly got cuffed on the ear for breaking rules.
noun A cul-de-sac is a short street which you can enter only from one end. You cannot drive right through it.
noun Culinary means relating to food or cooking. The banquet was a culinary delight. For a new culinary experience, try kangaroo meat.

verb If somethingculminates in a certain result or situation, it finishes up like that because of everything that happened before. I'm writing to say I hope all your hard work will culminate in a brilliant exam result.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun culmination

form.definition: noun A culprit is a person responsible for a crime or for doing something wrong. Janek was cleared of any involvement, but the real culprit was never discovered. So you ate the last of the biscuitsI wondered who the culprit was.
noun The culprit can also be the thing that is responsible for a problem. Hundreds of people die on our roads each year and drink driving is a major culprit.
noun A cult is a small religious group which has quite different beliefs from any of the main religions.
noun A cult is also a very strong enthusiasm that a group of people share for a particular person, idea or fashion. The legend of Elvis Presley has become a cult.
verb If you cultivate land, you grow crops on it. Only a small part of Australia's vast territory is cultivated.
verb If you cultivate plants, you grow them, especially as a commercial activity. Recently they have switched to cultivating cotton.
verb If you cultivate something, you make an effort to develop or improve it. She tried hard to cultivate a love of reading in her children.
verb If you cultivate someone, you try hard to make them like you. You put effort into developing a friendship with them, usually because you hope to get some benefit.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cultivation

form.definition: noun The culture of a group of people is the customs and way of life that they share. What's good about Australia is all the different cultures represented in the population. Most white Australians know far too little about Aboriginal culture.
noun Culture also refers to artistic or intellectual activities. I feel like a bit of culturelet's go to the theatre. It used to be said that Australia lacked culture.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cultural ...a cultural group. ...a cultural event.

form.definition: adjective If something is cumbersome, it is large or heavy, and awkward to carry or to use. She struggled up the stairs with a cumbersome package. I like my portable computer because it's less cumbersome than the one in the office.
noun A cumquat is a small citrus fruit.

adjective If someone is cunning, they are very clever at getting what they want, even if it means tricking or deceiving other people. He's as cunning as a fox. She came up with a cunning plan to get him to agree. ... A SIMILAR WORDto this is crafty. ... WORD FAMILYnoun cunning You have to admire his cunning.
noun Cunt is an informal word for vagina.
noun If someone calls someone else a cunt, they mean that they strongly dislike them, often because of their behaviour.
form.note: ... NOTE that using this word will offend many people.

form.definition: noun A cup is a small round container with a handle from which you drink things such as coffee and tea. Cups are usually made of china and have matching saucers.
noun In cooking, a cup is the amount that can fit into a standard cup. For liquids it is equal to a quarter of a litre. The recipe uses one cup of sugar, two cups of flour, butter and two eggs.

noun A cupboard is a piece of furniture that you use for storing things. Usually it has doors and shelves. I put the sheets in the linen cupboard. I took a new pad from the stationery cupboard. The kitchen has built-in cupboards.
verb If you curb something, you keep it under control or within fixed limits. She must learn to curb her temper. The government is keen to curb spending on social security.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun curb There is a strict curb on funding for new projects.

form.definition: verb When milk curdles, it becomes sour. I left the milk out of the fridge and it curdled overnight.

verb If you cure someone of something, you make them better, usually by giving them medical treatment. The doctor gave me antibiotics to cure my infected foot. Now over 50% of patients with this cancer can be cured. The experience cured me of my fear of flying.

verb If you cure something, you treat it in some way in order to preserve it. Urine used to be used to cure leather. Strips of meat are hung up in the smoke to cure. After you pour concrete it's important to cure it well so it doesn't crack.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun cure Do you know a cure for colds?

form.definition: adjective If someone is curious, they are anxious or eager to learn. They want to find out about something. Young children are very curious about the world around them. I was curious to know what was in the letter.
adjective If something is curious, it is unusual or strange. On ~our way to the dinner a curious thing happened. She showed me a curious black carving.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun curiosity I was filled with curiosity about the contents of the parcel.adverb curiously He looked at me curiously. You're curiously silent tonight.

form.definition: noun A curl is a small ring of hair, or anything that has a similar curved shape. The little boy had lovely golden curls. Curls of smoke rose from the chimney. Curls of wood shavings littered the floor.
2 curl up If you curl up somewhere, you put your body into a comfortable curved shape. The cat curled up on my lap. There's nothing I like better than to curl up with a good book.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb curl I notice you've curled your hair.adjective curly (curlier, curliest) Her hair is naturally curly.

form.definition: noun Currants are small, dried berries, often used in cakes.
noun A currawong is a large, black and white Australian bird which has a loud, shrill call.
noun A country's currency is the money that is used there. I changed $100 into Indonesian currency.
noun The current in an ocean or river is the way the water flows. Never try to swim against the currentyou'll only exhaust yourself.
noun A current is also the flow of electricity through a circuit. Be sure and turn off the current before you fiddle around inside the appliance.

adjective If something is current, it is happening at the present moment. Have you seen the current movie at the local cinema? What is the current situation in the Andrews case? In my current position I supervise five staff.

4 current affairs Current affairs are important events which are taking place in the world. Young people ought to take more of an interest in current affairs. She transferred from the light entertainment department to news and current affairs.

dictionary.entry:
curriculumk@`rIkj@l@m ( plural forms curricula or\optima0\curriculums
noun A curriculum is all the different courses that are available and taught in a school or university.

curriculum vitaericulum vitae is a written account of your education and experience which you submit when you apply for a job. It is often called a CV for short, and CVs is used for the plural form. ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is r;aaesum;aae.

form.definition: noun Curry is a hot spicy dish which is typical of Asian cooking.
verb If someone curses, they use crude or violent language, usually because they are angry about something. I left the room when he started to curse. He kicked the wall and cursed.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is swear.

form.definition: verb If you curse someone, you wish that something bad would happen to them, because you are very upset and angry with them. The old man shook his stick at her and cursed her. He believed that his family had been cursed by a witch.
noun A curse is an angry and offensive expression. When he realised they'd gone without him, he let out a string of curses.
noun A curse is a call to a spirit or god for something bad to happen to someone. With all the trouble we've had you'd think there was a curse on us. The family was under a curse never to prosper.
noun A curse is also a cause of misfortune or worry. Kangaroos are a curse to the Australian farmer. Mass immunisation has largely banished the curse of polio.
adjective If someone is curt, they speak in an abrupt and rather rude way. She greeted me with a curt 'good morning'. You should try not to be so curt when you answer the phone.
verb If you curtail something, you cut back on it or restrict it. Our holiday plans were greatly curtailed by the plane strike.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun curtailment

form.definition: noun A curtain is a large piece of cloth which hangs at a window on a rod attached to the wall. It is used for decoration or for privacy. I decided to put blinds instead of curtains in our family room.
noun In a theatre, the curtain is the large piece of cloth which hangs in front of the stage before the show begins.
verb If a woman curtsies, she crosses and bends her knees and holds the sides of her skirt. This is an old-fashioned way of showing ~respect. As the Queen walked into the room, the women curtsied.[qr
noun A curve is a gentle bend that's shaped like a part of a circle. Watch out for the curve in the road just past the crossroads. The ball flew through the air in a curve.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb curve The wall curves outwards slightly. The edges are curved, not straight.

form.definition: noun A cushion is a small pillow which you put on a chair or lounge, for decoration and also to be more comfortable to sit on or lean against. I bought cushions in a fabric to match the curtains.
noun A cushion is any pad of something which is soft. He fell backwards and his plump bottom acted as a cushion. The nurse put a cushion of gauze underneath the bandage.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb cushion Words can't cushion the blow. The snow cushioned his fall.

dictionary.entry: cushy`kUSi:cushiercushiest adjective In informal English, if you say something is cushy, you mean that it is easy and pleasant. It doesn't demand much effort. She's got a really cushy jobgood pay and no hassles. Tariq's got a cushy deal still living at home with his parents.

form.definition: noun Custard is a sweet sauce made of milk, eggs and sugar. Most children love apple and custard.
noun If you have custody of a child, you have the legal right to look after them and to keep them with you. When they were divorced Brenda was given custody of the two children.
noun If someone is held in custody, they are imprisoned. The prisoner is in custody until bail is set.

noun A custom is a habit or a practice which has been going on for a long time. It was his custom to go for a stroll before breakfast. The wedding followed Greek custom. Remember to respect local customs when you travel.

noun Customs is the officials at a border who check that you are not importing anything illegally or without paying the appropriate tax or duty. It took us four hours to get past customs. I declared the watch at customs and had to pay $200. Effie's nephew's got a job with the customs.

adjective If something is customary, it is what usually happens. When you are invited out to dinner, it is customary to take a bottle of wine. She asked the manager if it was customary to be kept waiting so long. I left home at my customary time.

noun A customer is a person who buys goods or services. They know me in that newsagent because I'm a regular customer. Acme Pty is one of our best customers. There was a queue of customers waiting to be served.
noun In informal language, you can refer to a person as a certain type of customer. He's a cool customerhe never gets upset. Frieda's an odd customerI just can't work her out.

verb If you cut something, you use a knife or similar object to divide it or to take a piece off it. She cut the cake and handed us each a slice. Could you cut me a slice of cheese? He always cuts the crossword out of the newspaper. I cut up the cardboard into small squares.

verb If you cut something, you damage it or mark it, either accidentally or on purpose. She cut her fingers while chopping up the vegetables. Cut a notch to show where the other piece should join. They use tools tipped with diamond to cut the glass.
verb If you cut something, you reduce it. Melanie's father cut her allowance. I've cut the amount of time I spend on housework. All the stores will be cutting prices in the January sales.
verb If something such as a line cuts something else, it intersects with it or crosses it. The line AB cuts CD at right angles.

5 cut off (a) If you cut something off, you prevent it from continuing. The rebels have cut off supplies to the capital. The electricity was cut off while they made the repair. We'll have to cut off our meeting at six o'clock.
(b) If you cut someone off when they are speaking, you interrupt them. I started to speak but he cut me off.
6 cut out If you say you are not cut out for something, you mean that you are not a suitable person to be doing it. I don't think I'm cut out to be a teacherI'm too impatient.

If you cut something short, you end it before it is properly complete. Our vacation was cut short by Michael's father's illness.~ ... WORD FAMILYnoun cut I've got a cut on my foot. There was a cut in the price of oil.adjective cutting She made a cutting remark about Leon's appearance.
adjective If a child or animal is cute, they are sweet and appealing. They've got a really cute little puppy. It was so cute the way he wagged his little tail.
adjective You can also describe someone as cute if they are trying to be clever or cunning. He's a bit too cute for his own good. Don't get cute with me!
noun Your cuticles are the skin at the base of your finger nails.
noun Cutlery consists of knives, forks and spoons.
noun A cutlet is a slice of meat which is cooked and served still attached to the rib of the animal. We're having lamb cutlets for tea. ...a veal cutlet.

dictionary.entry: CVsi:`vi: <abbreviation> for curriculum vitae.

form.definition: noun Cycle is another word for bicycle.
verb If you cycle, you ride a bicycle. I cycled to the beach. I do a lot of cycling to keep fit.

noun A cycle is also a series of events which go through a definite sequence and often are repeated again and again. At the moment the trade cycle is in a phase of expansion. Water evaporates from the sea and is deposited as rainfall in a balanced cycle.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective cycle ...a cycle track. ...a cycle helmet.noun cyclist

form.definition: noun A cyclone is a violent storm with strong winds.
noun A cylinder is a solid shape with two circular ends of the same size, connected by straight sides.
noun A cylinder is also the part of an engine where the piston moves backwards and forwards.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY

form.definition: noun A cynic is someone who distrusts other people and always assumes that they have bad motives. Tom is such a cynicjust talking to him is depressing. In political life it pays to be a cynic.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See cynical.

form.definition: adjective If you are cynical, you distrust other people. I was pretty cynical about her motives.
adjective If someone is cynical, they are unscrupulous. They are willing to exploit other people to gain an advantage for themselves. It was a cynical attempt to manipulate the voters.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb cynically He laughed cynically. They cynically took advantage of her inexperience.

form.definition: noun A cyst is a lump under the skin which is full of fluid.
noun Cystitis is an infection of the bladder. It can be very painful.
noun Czech is the language of the Czech Republic.
adjective If someone or something comes from the Czech Republic, you describe them as Czech.~[fa[xp
